senses.definition: to put clothes, etc. into a bag in preparation for a trip away from home

examples.en: I haven't packed yet.
I have to start packing for my trip.
I haven't packed my suitcase yet.
I packed my bags and left.
Did you pack the camera?
He packed a bag with a few things and was off.
He packed a few things into a bag.
I've packed you some food for the journey.

senses.definition: to put something into a container so that it can be stored, transported or sold

examples.en: The pottery was packed in boxes and shipped to the US.
I carefully packed up the gifts.
Ryan busied himself packing everything up into bags.
He found a part-time job packing eggs.

senses.definition: to protect something that breaks easily by surrounding it with soft material

examples.en: The paintings were carefully packed in newspaper.

senses.definition: to preserve food in a particular substance

examples.en: fish packed in ice

senses.definition: to fill something with a lot of people or things

examples.en: We all packed together into one car.

senses.definition: to press something such as snow or soil to form a thick hard mass

examples.en: Pack the earth down around the plant.

senses.definition: to carry a gun

examples.en: to pack a gun

senses.definition: to have something

examples.en: A storm packing 75 mph winds swept across the area last night.

senses.definition: to leave a person or place permanently, especially after an argument
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
to have a powerful effect on somebody

examples.en: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

senses.definition: to tell somebody clearly or rudely to go away

examples.en: She tried to interfere but I sent her packing.

senses.definition: a container, usually made of paper, that holds a number of the same thing or an amount of something, ready to be sold

senses.definition: a set of different things that are supplied together for a particular purpose

senses.definition: a number of things that are wrapped or tied together, especially for carrying

examples.en: donkeys carrying packs of wool

senses.definition: a large bag that you carry on your back

examples.en: We passed a group of walkers, carrying huge packs.

senses.definition: a group of animals that hunt together or are kept for hunting

examples.en: packs of savage dogs

a pack of hounds

senses.definition: a group of similar people or things, especially one that you do not like or approve of

examples.en: We avoided a pack of journalists waiting outside.

senses.definition: all the people who are behind the leaders in a race, competition, etc.

examples.en: measures aimed at keeping the company ahead of the pack

variants.text: (also deck North American English, British English)
variants.html: (also deck North American English, British English)

examples.en: a pack of cards

senses.definition: an organized group of cubs / Cub Scouts or brownies

examples.en: to join a Brownie pack

senses.definition: a hot or cold piece of soft material that holds liquid, used for treating a wound
a person or thing that could change the way that things will happen in a way that cannot be predicted

variants.html: (also parcel especially in British English)

senses.definition: something that is wrapped in paper or put into a thick envelope so that it can be sent by mail, carried easily, or given as a present

examples.en: A large package has arrived for you.

senses.definition: a box, bag, etc. in which things are wrapped or packed; the contents of a box, etc.

senses.definition: a set of items or ideas that must be bought or accepted together

senses.definition: a set of related programs for a particular type of task, sold and used as a single unit

examples.en: The system came with a database software package.

senses.definition: to put something into a box, bag, etc. to be sold or transported

examples.en: packaged food/goods
The glasses had been carefully packaged for the journey to England.

senses.definition: to present somebody/something in a particular way

examples.en: politicians who are packaged and presented to the public

senses.definition: a small container made of paper or card in which goods are packed for selling

examples.en: a packet of biscuits/cigarettes/crisps

senses.definition: a small object wrapped in paper or put into a thick envelope so that it can be sent by mail, carried easily or given as a present

examples.en: A packet of photographs arrived with the mail.

variants.html: (British English sachet)

senses.definition: a closed plastic or paper package that contains a very small amount of liquid or a powder

examples.en: a packet of instant cocoa mix

senses.definition: a large amount of money

examples.en: That car must have cost a packet.

senses.definition: a piece of information that forms part of a message sent through a computer network

examples.en: The data transmission is split into a number of packets of equal size.

senses.definition: a set of documents that are supplied together for a particular purpose

examples.en: a training packet

senses.definition: a thick piece of soft material that is used, for example, for cleaning or protecting something or for holding liquid

examples.en: medicated cleansing pads for sensitive skin

senses.definition: a number of pieces of paper for writing or drawing on, that are fastened together at one edge

examples.en: a sketch/writing pad

senses.definition: the soft part under the foot of a cat, dog, etc.

examples.en: A cat detects vibrations through the pads of its feet.

senses.definition: a small piece of rough material used for cleaning pans, surfaces, etc.

examples.en: a scouring pad

senses.definition: a flat surface where a spacecraft or a helicopter takes off and lands

senses.definition: a piece of thick material that you wear in some sports, for example football and cricket, to protect parts of your body

senses.definition: the large flat leaf of some water plants, especially the water lily

examples.en: floating lily pads

senses.definition: the place where somebody lives, especially a flat

senses.definition: to put a layer of soft material in or on something in order to protect it, make it thicker or change its shape

senses.definition: to walk with quiet steps

examples.en: She padded across the room to the window.

senses.definition: to dishonestly add items to bills to obtain more money

examples.en: to pad bills/expense accounts

senses.definition: one side or both sides of a sheet of paper in a book, magazine, etc.

the title/index page
the sports/news pages of the newspaper
the letters/opinion page

senses.definition: a section of data or information that can be shown on a computer screen at any one time

examples.en: to visit/view a page

senses.definition: an important event or period of history

examples.en: a glorious page of Arab history

variants.text: (also pageboy British and North American English)
variants.html: (also pageboy British and North American English)

senses.definition: a small boy who helps or follows a bride during a marriage ceremony
a boy or young man, usually in uniform, employed in a hotel to open doors, deliver messages for people, etc.
a student who works as an assistant to a member of the US Congress
a boy or young man who worked for a knight while training to be a knight himself
if two or more people or groups are on the same page, they agree about what they are trying to achieve

examples.en: Are employers and employees on the same page when it comes to retirement benefits?

senses.definition: what is published in books, newspapers, etc.

examples.en: the power of the printed word

senses.definition: to begin doing things in a different way and thinking in a more positive way after a period of difficulties

examples.en: It’s time to turn the page and make a fresh start.

examples.en: Why don't you have him paged at the airport?

senses.definition: to contact somebody by sending a message to their pager

senses.definition: the feelings that you have in your body when you have been hurt or when you are ill

patients suffering from back pain
stomach/chest/abdominal/back pains

senses.definition: mental or emotional difficulty

examples.en: the pain of separation

a life full of pain and suffering

senses.definition: a person or thing that is very annoying

senses.definition: used to say that you need to suffer if you want to achieve something
with the threat of having something done to you as a punishment if you do not obey

examples.en: They were required to cut pollution levels, on pain of a £10 000 fine if they disobeyed.

variants.text: (British English also a pain in the arse/backside)
variants.html: (British English also a pain in the arse/backside)

senses.definition: a person or thing that is very annoying

examples.en: That man's a pain in the neck!

senses.definition: to cause somebody pain or make them unhappy

examples.en: She was deeply pained by the accusation.

examples.en: It pains me to see you like this.

senses.definition: causing you pain

examples.en: Is your back still painful?

senses.definition: unpleasant or difficult to do

examples.en: a famous painter

examples.en: a date palm

examples.en: One of the glass panels in the front door was cracked.

senses.definition: a piece of cloth that forms part of a piece of clothing

examples.en: The trousers have double thickness knee panels for extra protection.

senses.definition: a group of specialists who give their advice or opinion about something; a group of people who discuss topics of interest on television or radio

senses.definition: underpants or knickers

ski/sweat/dress pants

senses.definition: the thin material that you write and draw on and that is also used for wrapping and packing things

senses.definition: having no value, especially legally, or because one of the people involved has no intention of doing what they said they would
when you put something on paper, you write it down

senses.definition: to write or start to write something

a public celebration of a special day or event, usually with bands in the streets and decorated vehicles

examples.en: the Lord Mayor’s parade

senses.definition: to come together, or to bring soldiers together, in order to march (= walk formally) in front of other people

examples.en: The crowds applauded as the guards paraded past.
The colonel paraded his men before the King.

senses.definition: to pretend to be, or to make somebody/something seem to be, good or important when they are not

examples.en: myth parading as fact
He paraded himself as a loyal supporter of the party.

variants.html: (abbreviation par., para.)

senses.definition: a section of a piece of writing, usually consisting of several sentences dealing with a single subject. The first sentence of a paragraph starts on a new line.

examples.en: an opening/introductory paragraph
Write a paragraph on each of the topics given below.
See paragraph 15 of the handbook.
The basic idea is summarized in the following paragraphs.

senses.definition: two or more lines that are parallel to each other are the same distance apart at every point

examples.en: parallel lines
The road and the canal are parallel to each other.

senses.definition: very similar or taking place at the same time

examples.en: parallel trends
Though still a committed painter, in 1978 she launched a parallel career as a photographer.
Two poisonings have been reported recently in London and now there has been a parallel case in the Netherlands.

senses.definition: involving several computer operations at the same time

examples.en: parallel processing

senses.definition: two or more lines that run parallel to each other are the same distance apart at every point

examples.en: The road and the canal run parallel to each other.
The plane flew parallel to the coast.

senses.definition: in a way that is very similar or takes place at the same time

examples.en: The team's findings run parallel to those of other researchers.

senses.definition: a person, a situation, an event, etc. that is very similar to another, especially one in a different place or time

examples.en: These ideas have parallels in Freud's thought too.
This tradition has no parallel in our culture.
This is an achievement without parallel in modern times.

senses.definition: similar features

examples.en: There are interesting parallels between the 1960s and the late 1990s.
It is possible to draw a parallel between (= find similar features in) their experience and ours.

variants.text: (also line of latitude, parallel of latitude)
variants.html: (also line of latitude, parallel of latitude)

senses.definition: an imaginary line around the earth that is always the same distance from the equator; this line on a map

examples.en: the 49th parallel

senses.definition: with and at the same time as something/somebody else

examples.en: The new degree and the existing certificate courses would run in parallel.
Ann wanted to pursue her own career in parallel with her husband’s.

senses.definition: to be similar to something; to happen at the same time as something

examples.en: Their legal system parallels our own.
The rise in unemployment is paralleled by an increase in petty crime.

senses.definition: to be as good as something

examples.en: a level of achievement that has never been paralleled

senses.definition: something that decides or limits the way in which something can be done

examples.en: to set/define the parameters
We had to work within the parameters that had already been established.

senses.definition: a person’s father or mother

examples.en: He's still living with his parents.
Sue and Ben have recently become parents.
It can be difficult to be a good parent.
her adoptive parents (= who have legally adopted her as their child)
It's not easy being a foster parent (= who looks after a child for a period of time without legally adopting him/her) to these children.
his biological/birth parents (= natural parents, not ones who adopt or foster)
Emma is a lone parent with two children.
More childcare options and more paid leave will improve the lives of working parents.

senses.definition: an animal or a plant which produces other animals or plants

examples.en: the parent bird/tree

senses.definition: an organization that produces and owns or controls smaller organizations of the same type

examples.en: a parent bank and its subsidiaries
The subsidiary eventually outgrew its parent company and took it over.

senses.definition: to care for your child or children

examples.en: They'd never parented a toddler and a newborn at the same time before.
We have an intuitive ability to parent.

senses.definition: connected with a parent or parents

examples.en: parental responsibility/rights
parental choice in education
the parental home

senses.definition: an area that has its own church and that a priest is responsible for

examples.en: a parish church/priest
He is vicar of a large rural parish.

senses.definition: (in England) a small country area that has its own elected local government

examples.en: This area in the north of the county comprises 26 parishes.

senses.definition: the people living in a particular area, especially those who go to church

examples.en: The parish was/were very welcoming when I first arrived.

senses.definition: a county
an area of public land in a town or a city where people go to walk, play and relax

examples.en: Hyde Park
We went for a walk in the park.
A public park will be built around the complex.
a park bench
the park entrance/gates

senses.definition: an area of land used for a particular purpose

examples.en: a business/science park
a wildlife park
a park ranger
She lives in a trailer park in Tucson, Arizona.

senses.definition: (in the UK) an area of land, usually with fields and trees, attached to a large country house

examples.en: The cottage is set within the park of a country house.
The houses and parks in Georgian Sussex represented leisured society at its peak.

senses.definition: a piece of land for playing sports, especially baseball

examples.en: With a mighty swing he hit the ball right out of the park.

senses.definition: a football (soccer) or rugby field

examples.en: the fastest man on the park

senses.definition: the position of the gears in a car with automatic transmission (= a system that changes the gears by itself so the driver does not have to) in which they are locked so that the engine cannot send any power to the wheels

examples.en: She put the car in park, pulled out the key and got out.

senses.definition: a thing that is very easy to do or deal with

examples.en: The role isn't exactly a walk in the park.
The next game will be a walk in the park.

senses.definition: to leave a vehicle that you are driving in a particular place for a period of time

examples.en: He parked and went inside.
You can't park here.
He's parked very badly.
You can't park the car here.
a badly parked truck
A red van was parked in front of the house.
I am parked (= my vehicle is parked) just outside.
My mother parked the car.
a parked car
They saw his vehicle parked in the driveway.
Several police vans were parked outside their home.

senses.definition: to leave something in a convenient place until you need it

examples.en: Just park your bags in the hall until your room is ready.

senses.definition: to sit or stand in a particular place for a period of time

examples.en: She parked herself on the edge of the bed.

senses.definition: to decide to leave an idea or issue to be dealt with or considered at a later meeting

examples.en: Let's park that until our next meeting.

senses.definition: the act of stopping a vehicle at a place and leaving it there for a period of time

examples.en: There is no parking here between 9 a.m. and 6 p.m.
I managed to find a parking space.
I got there early to grab a parking spot.
I pulled the car over into a parking bay.
a parking fine (= for parking illegally)

senses.definition: a space or an area for leaving vehicles

examples.en: The hotel is centrally situated with ample free parking.
parking for 300 cars
There is off-street parking at the front of the house.
The town has free on-street parking.
The public did not vote for increased car parking charges.
The hotel has six levels of underground parking.

senses.definition: the group of people who are elected to make and change the laws of a country

examples.en: The German parliament is called the ‘Bundestag’.
The Scottish parliament is expected to vote in favour of a ban.
The exit polls predicted a hung parliament (= in which no political party has more elected members than all the other parties added together).

senses.definition: the parliament of some countries, including the United Kingdom. In the UK, Parliament consists of the House of Commons and the House of Lords

examples.en: a Member of Parliament
an Act of Parliament
The issue was debated in Parliament.
to win a seat in Parliament
The party is set to win a majority in Parliament (= the most votes) in October's election.
to be elected to Parliament
He practised law briefly before standing for Parliament (= becoming a candidate in an election).
The plans are included in a bill currently before Parliament (= that is being discussed in Parliament).

senses.definition: a particular period during which a parliament is working; Parliament as it exists between one general election and the next

examples.en: We are now into the second half of the parliament.
to dissolve Parliament (= formally end its activities) and call an election
The legislation is expected to be introduced early in the next session of parliament.

senses.definition: connected with a parliament; having a parliament

examples.en: parliamentary elections
a parliamentary democracy

senses.definition: some but not all of a thing

examples.en: We spent part of the time in the museum.
Part of the building was destroyed in the fire.
Part of the problem is that more and more people live alone.
Voters are given only part of the story (= only some of the information).
Part of me feels sorry for him (= I feel a little sorry for him, but not very sorry).
We spent a good part of the day rehearsing.

senses.definition: a section, piece or feature of something

examples.en: The mountains are covered with snow for a large part of the year.
The early part of her life was spent in Paris.
the latter part of the 19th century
Making mistakes is an integral part of the learning process.
We've done the difficult part of the job.
an important/essential part of the project
Wool production was a key part of the economy.
The novel is good in parts.
The procedure can be divided into two parts.
The worst part was having to wait three hours in the rain.

senses.definition: an element or member of something; a person or thing that helps to make up a whole or belongs in it

examples.en: Snacks can be part of a healthy eating plan.
You need to be able to work as part of a team.
Under the Saxons, Westmorland formed part of the Kingdom of Northumberland.
Antibiotics have become part of our daily existence.

senses.definition: a separate piece or area of a human or animal body or of a plant

examples.en: The cancer could spread to other parts of the body.
It may one day be possible to grow new body parts in the laboratory.
Different insects feed on different parts of the plant.

senses.definition: a piece of a machine or structure

examples.en: The factory manufactures aircraft parts.
car/machine/engine parts
the working parts of the machinery
Where can I get spare parts for my bike?

senses.definition: an area or a region of the world, a country, a town, etc.

examples.en: The island is mostly flat, but there are some hilly parts.
the northern part of town
different parts of the world/country
Which part of Japan do you come from?
Come and visit us if you're ever in our part of the world.

senses.definition: a region or an area

examples.en: She's not from these parts.
He's just arrived back from foreign parts.

senses.definition: a section of a book, television series, etc., especially one that is published or broadcast separately

examples.en: The documentary was screened in four parts.
Henry IV, Part II
The final part will be shown next Sunday evening.

senses.definition: a role played by an actor in a play, film, etc.; the words spoken by an actor in a particular role

examples.en: She played the part of Juliet.
He's always playing a part (= pretending to be something that he is not).
Have you learned your part yet?
He got a small part in a West End play.
She was very good in the part.

senses.definition: the way in which somebody/something is involved in an action or situation

examples.en: Luck played a big part in their success.
She plays an active part in local politics.
We all have a part to play in the fight against crime.
He had no part in the decision.
I want no part of this sordid business.

senses.definition: music for a particular voice or instrument in a group singing or playing together

examples.en: the clarinet part
The first two verses of the song are set in four-part harmony.
I can play the guitar part to that song.

senses.definition: a unit of measurement that allows you to compare the different amounts of substances in something

examples.en: Add three parts wine to one part water.
fluoride levels of 0.2 parts per million

variants.html: (British English parting)

senses.definition: a line on a person’s head where the hair is divided with a comb

idioms.word: be greater/more than the sum of its parts

senses.definition: to be better or more effective as a group than you would think just by looking at the individual members of the group

examples.en: The team is greater than the sum of its parts.

senses.definition: most of something, especially a period of time; more than half of something

examples.en: He drank the best part of a bottle of Scotch waiting for her to get home.
The journey took her the better part of an hour.

idioms.word: discretion is the better part of valour

senses.definition: you should avoid danger and not take unnecessary risks
mostly; usually

examples.en: The contributors are, for the most part, professional scientists.

idioms.word: for my, his, their, etc. part

senses.definition: used to express your own, his, their, etc. opinion or feelings about something

examples.en: For my part, I would reject all these arguments.

idioms.word: in large part | in large measure

senses.definition: to a great extent

examples.en: Their success is due in large part to their determination.

senses.definition: partly; to some extent

examples.en: Her success was due in part to luck.
Your salary depends in part on your qualifications.

senses.definition: to have an appearance or wear clothes suitable for a particular job, role or position

examples.en: He acts and dresses the part of a gentleman.
He was a pirate in the school play and certainly looked the part.

senses.definition: a person with many skills

idioms.word: on the part of somebody/on somebody’s part

senses.definition: made or done by somebody

examples.en: It was an error on my part.

senses.definition: a normal part of something

examples.en: Keeping the accounts is part and parcel of my job.

senses.definition: a person or thing that you are so used to seeing that you no longer notice them

examples.en: I worked there so long that I became part of the furniture.

senses.definition: to accept something slightly unpleasant without complaining or being offended

examples.en: He took the teasing in good part.

senses.definition: to be involved in something

examples.en: to take part in a discussion/demonstration/fight/celebration
How many countries took part in the last Olympic Games?
They took little part in the discussion.

senses.definition: to support somebody, for example in an argument

examples.en: His mother always takes his part.

senses.definition: if a person parts from another person, or two people part, they leave each other

examples.en: We parted at the airport.
I hate to part on such bad terms.
He has recently parted from his wife (= they have started to live apart).

senses.definition: to prevent somebody from being with somebody else

examples.en: I hate being parted from the children.
The puppies were parted from their mother at birth.
I refused to be parted from my sisters.

senses.definition: if two things or parts of things part or you part them, they move away from each other

examples.en: The crowd parted in front of them.
The elevator doors parted and out stepped the President.
Her lips were slightly parted.
She parted the curtains a little and looked out.

senses.definition: to divide your hair into two sections with a comb, creating a line that goes from the back of your head to the front

examples.en: He parts his hair in the middle.

idioms.word: a fool and his money are soon parted

senses.definition: a person who is not sensible usually spends money too quickly or carelessly, or is cheated by others

variants.html: (also part ways (with/from somebody))

senses.definition: to leave somebody; to end a relationship with somebody

examples.en: This is where we part company (= go in different directions).
The band have parted company with their manager.
The band and their manager have parted company.
He parted ways with the team at the end of the season.

senses.definition: to disagree with somebody about something

examples.en: Weber parted company with Marx on a number of important issues.
The two leaders parted ways on this question.

senses.definition: consisting of two things; to some extent but not completely

examples.en: She's part French, part English.
His feelings were part anger, part relief.
The course is part funded by the European Commission.
He is part owner of a farm in France.

senses.definition: not complete or whole

examples.en: It was only a partial solution to the problem.
a partial eclipse of the sun

senses.definition: liking somebody/something very much

examples.en: I'm not partial to mushrooms.

senses.definition: showing or feeling too much support for one person, team, idea, etc., in a way that is unfair

examples.en: The resulting assessment is necessarily partial and subjective.

senses.definition: partly; not completely

examples.en: The road was partially blocked by a fallen tree.
It’s only partially true.

senses.definition: a person who is taking part in an activity or event

examples.en: The average age of study participants was 48 years.
workshop/conference/seminar participants
He has been an active participant in the discussion.
The child must be a willing participant in the therapy.
Participants in the study completed a short questionnaire.

senses.definition: to take part in or become involved in an activity

examples.en: Anyone who wishes to participate is welcome.
She didn't participate in the discussion.
to participate in a study/programme
to participate in an activity/event
We encourage students to participate fully in the running of the college.
The women actively participated in the creation of the artwork.
Other countries were invited to participate in the project.
All employees at least 21 years old are eligible to participate.
Details of the competition are available at all participating stores.

senses.definition: the act of taking part in an activity or event

examples.en: a show with lots of audience participation
A back injury prevented active participation in any sports for a while.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you are referring to one individual person, thing or type of thing and not others

examples.en: There is one particular patient I'd like you to see.
Is there a particular type of book he enjoys?
Each village has its own particular charm.
In this particular case, the owners were not local but Indian.
specialized advice tailored to your particular circumstances

senses.definition: greater than usual; special

examples.en: We must pay particular attention to this point.
These documents are of particular interest.
I went into town for no particular reason.
The high inflation rates were of particular concern.

senses.definition: very definite about what you like and careful about what you choose

examples.en: She's very particular about her clothes.

senses.definition: especially or particularly

examples.en: He loves science fiction in particular.

senses.definition: special or specific

examples.en: Peter was lying on the sofa doing nothing in particular.
Is there anything in particular you'd like for dinner?
She directed the question at no one in particular.

senses.definition: belonging to one individual person, place or thing and not others

examples.en: cheeses that are particular to this area (= that are made there and nowhere else)

senses.definition: a fact or detail, especially one that is officially written down

examples.en: The police officer took down all the particulars of the burglary.
The nurse asked me for my particulars (= personal details such as your name, address, etc.).
The new contract will be the same in every particular as the old one.

senses.definition: written information and details about a property, business, job, etc.

examples.en: Application forms and further particulars are available from the Personnel Office.
the particulars of a house in Bury

senses.definition: especially; more than usual or more than others

examples.en: particularly useful/important/interesting
I particularly like the colour of the walls.
The story focuses particularly on the character of Nelly.
Traffic is bad, particularly in the city centre.
I enjoyed the play, particularly the second half.
The task was not particularly (= not very) difficult.
‘Did you enjoy it?’ ‘No, not particularly (= not very much).’
I don't particularly care (= I don't care very much) what happens to him.

senses.definition: to some extent; not completely

examples.en: Some people are unwilling to attend the classes partly because of the cost involved.
These low prices were partly due to excess supply.
He was only partly responsible for the accident.
The story is partly based on fact.
It was partly my fault.
Two factors at least partly explain her success.
Her eyes were partly open.

senses.definition: a person that you are doing an activity with, such as dancing or playing a game

examples.en: a dance/tennis partner
The teacher asked the students to choose a partner for the next activity.

senses.definition: the person that you are married to or having a sexual relationship with

examples.en: Come to the New Year disco and bring your partner!
This is my partner, Mark.
a sexual/romantic partner
a male/female/same-sex partner
She still hasn't found her perfect partner.

senses.definition: one of the people who owns a business and shares the profits, etc.

examples.en: a partner in a law firm
a junior/senior partner
Maintain good relationships with your customers, employees and business partners.
He is the founder and managing partner of the gallery.
Teresa became a full partner in 2020.

senses.definition: a country or an organization that has an agreement with another country or organization

examples.en: a trading partner
The party was unable to find a coalition partner.
India remains an important strategic partner for the United States.

senses.definition: to be somebody’s partner in a dance, game, etc.

examples.en: Gerry offered to partner me at tennis.

senses.definition: to be involved in a business project with another company

examples.en: Freshfoods usually partners with other companies to share risk.
We are very excited to be partnering with such a vibrant and dynamic company.

senses.definition: the state of being a partner in business

examples.en: to be in/to go into partnership
He developed his own program in partnership with an American expert.

senses.definition: a relationship between two people, organizations, etc.; the state of having this relationship

examples.en: Marriage should be an equal partnership.
the school’s partnership with parents
a partnership between the United States and Europe

senses.definition: a business owned by two or more people who share the profits

examples.en: a junior member of the partnership

senses.definition: a social occasion, often in a person’s home, at which people eat, drink, talk, dance and enjoy themselves

examples.en: a dinner/tea/cocktail party
I was at a birthday party for my friend's five-year-old daughter.
to have/throw/give a party
to hold/host a party
Did you go to the party?
party games

senses.definition: a political organization that you can vote for in elections and whose members have the same aims and ideas

examples.en: Do you belong to a political party?
the ruling/opposition party
the Democratic/Republican/Conservative/Labour Party
The party is/are completely united on this issue.
the party leader/conference
a party member/activist/official

senses.definition: a group of people who are doing something together such as travelling or visiting somewhere

examples.en: The school is taking a party of 40 children to France.
The theatre gives a 10 per cent discount to parties of more than ten.
a rescue/wedding/hunting party
A party of tourists was/were photographing the monument.

senses.definition: one of the people or groups of people involved in a legal agreement or argument

examples.en: the guilty/innocent party
The contract can be terminated by either party with three months' notice.
The judge’s decision satisfied most of the parties concerned.

senses.definition: to be involved in an agreement or action

examples.en: to be party to a decision
He refused to be a party to any violence.

senses.definition: to contribute something useful to a discussion, project, etc.

examples.en: What Hislop brought to the party was real commitment and energy.

senses.definition: to enjoy yourself, especially by eating, drinking alcohol and dancing

examples.en: They were out partying every night.
That guy Jake—he really knows how to party!

senses.definition: to achieve the required standard in an exam, a test, etc.

examples.en: I'm not really expecting to pass first time.
She passed with flying colours (= very easily).
She hasn't passed her driving test yet.
pass an exam/examination

senses.definition: to test somebody and decide that they are good enough, according to an agreed standard

examples.en: The examiners passed all the candidates.

senses.definition: to move past or to the other side of somebody/something

examples.en: Several people were passing but nobody offered to help.
I hailed a passing taxi.
The security guard refused to let us pass.
to pass a barrier/sentry/checkpoint
You'll pass a bank on the way to the train station.
She passed me in the street without even saying hello.
Nobody has passed this way for hours.
There was a truck behind that was trying to pass me.

senses.definition: to go or move in the direction mentioned

examples.en: The procession passed slowly along the street.
We passed through a security checkpoint.
A plane passed low overhead.
The air cools as it passes along the pipe.
After passing through tall gates, you follow a long curving drive.
We passed through the Spanish Quarter on our way here.
Almost 7 million people pass through the museum's doors each year.
The number of people passing through British airports rose 3%.
The train passes through a desolate industrial landscape.
As the water passes through, the membrane filters out most of the impurities.
As they passed under the bridge they heard a noise above them.
As water passes over rocks, it dissolves many minerals.
They passed down winding streets.
A train was passing noisily over the bridge.
They became used to hearing warplanes pass overhead.

senses.definition: to make something move in the direction or into the position mentioned

examples.en: He passed the rope around the post three times to secure it.
She passed her hand across her forehead.

senses.definition: to give something to somebody by putting it into their hands or in a place where they can easily reach it

examples.en: Pass the salt, please.
Pass that book over.
He passed a note to his friend.
Pass me the salt.
Pass me over that book.

senses.definition: to give somebody information or a message

examples.en: His wife had been passing information to the police.
They devised a method of passing secret messages.

senses.definition: to kick, hit or throw the ball to a player of your own side

examples.en: She passed the ball to Kerr.
Why do they keep passing back to the goalie?
They should pass more.

senses.definition: when time passes, it goes by

examples.en: Almost fifty years have passed since that day.
Six months passed and we still had no news of them.
The time passed quickly.
We grew more anxious with every passing day.

senses.definition: to spend time, especially when you are bored or waiting for something

examples.en: We sang songs to pass the time.
How do you pass the long winter nights?

senses.definition: to come to an end; to be over

examples.en: They waited for the storm to pass.
It's just a phase which will eventually pass.
This is a record of an era long since passed (= that ended a long time ago).

senses.definition: to change from one state or condition to another

examples.en: She had passed from childhood to early womanhood.

senses.definition: to be given to another person after first belonging to somebody else, especially after the first person has died

examples.en: On his death, the title passed to his eldest son.

senses.definition: to become greater than a particular total

examples.en: Unemployment has now passed the three million mark.

senses.definition: to accept a proposal, law, etc. by voting; to be accepted in this way

examples.en: to pass a bill/law/resolution
The Kansas State House narrowly passed the legislation last year.
In 1996, Congress unanimously passed the Food Quality Protection Act.
The bill is expected to pass the Senate.
The bill passed by 360 votes to 280.

senses.definition: to be allowed

examples.en: I don't like it, but I'll let it pass (= will not object).
Her remarks passed without comment (= people ignored them).

senses.definition: to happen; to be said or done

examples.en: They'll never be friends again after all that has passed between them.
His departure passed unnoticed.

senses.definition: to say that you do not know the answer to a question, especially during a quiz

examples.en: ‘What's the capital of Peru?’ ‘I'll have to pass on that one.’
‘Who wrote ‘Catch-22’?’ ‘Pass (= I don't know).’

senses.definition: to say that you do not want something that is offered to you

examples.en: Thanks. I'm going to pass on dessert, if you don't mind.

senses.definition: to say or state something, especially officially

examples.en: The court waited in silence for the judge to pass sentence.
It's not for me to pass judgement on your behaviour.
The man smiled at the girl and passed a friendly remark.

senses.definition: to go beyond the limits of what you can believe, understand, etc.

examples.en: It passes belief (= is impossible to believe) that she could do such a thing.

senses.definition: to refuse to play a card or make a bid when it is your turn
to send something out from the body as or with waste matter

examples.en: If you're passing blood you ought to see a doctor.

senses.definition: to happen

examples.en: How did such a disaster come to pass?
I wondered how it came to pass that a thinking man bore the prejudices of his unthinking parents.

senses.definition: if words do not pass your lips, you say nothing
if food or drink does not pass your lips, you eat or drink nothing
to collect money from a number of people, for example to buy a present for somebody
to be accepted as of a good enough standard

idioms.word: pass the time of day (with somebody)

senses.definition: to say hello to somebody and have a short conversation with them
to urinate
an official document or ticket that shows that you have the right to enter or leave a place, to travel on a bus or train, etc.

examples.en: a boarding pass (= for a plane)
There is no admittance without a security pass.
We had backstage passes to the show.

senses.definition: a successful result in an exam or test

examples.en: She got a pass in French.
12 passes and 3 fails
Two A-level passes are needed for this course.
The pass mark is 50 per cent.
The school has a 90 per cent pass rate (= 90 per cent of students pass their exams).

senses.definition: (in some sports) an act of hitting or throwing the ball to another player in your team

examples.en: a long pass to Turner

senses.definition: a road or way over or through mountains

examples.en: a mountain pass
They came over the top of the pass and started down towards the coast.
