not involving a war, violence or argument

examples.en: a peaceful protest/demonstration
a peaceful resolution to the war
They hope for a peaceful settlement of the dispute.
The only way ahead was via diplomatic and peaceful means.
people of different religions living in peaceful coexistence
The time without her in the house had been blissfully peaceful.

senses.definition: quiet and calm; not worried or upset in any way

examples.en: a peaceful atmosphere
peaceful sleep
It's so peaceful out here in the country.
She lives a peaceful existence in a mountain village.
He had a peaceful life.
a peaceful place
You looked so peaceful that we didn't want to wake you.

senses.definition: trying to create peace or to live in peace; not liking violence or argument

examples.en: a peaceful religion/society
The aims of the organization are wholly peaceful.

senses.definition: the point when somebody/something is best, most successful, strongest, etc.

examples.en: Traffic reaches its peak between 8 and 9 in the morning.
the peaks and troughs of married life
She's at the peak of her career.
Membership of the club has fallen from a peak of 600 people in 2022.

senses.definition: the pointed top of a mountain; a mountain with a pointed top

examples.en: a mountain peak
snow-capped/jagged peaks
The climbers made camp halfway up the peak.
We looked up at the rocky peaks towering above us.

senses.definition: any narrow and pointed shape, edge, etc.

examples.en: Whisk the egg whites into stiff peaks.
He combed his hair into a peak.

variants.html: (North American English bill, visor)

senses.definition: the stiff front part of a cap that sticks out above your eyes
to reach the highest point or value

examples.en: Oil production peaked in the early 1980s.
Unemployment peaked at 17 per cent.
an athlete who peaks (= produces his or her best performance) at just the right time

senses.definition: used to describe the highest level of something, or a time when the greatest number of people are doing something or using something

examples.en: It was a time of peak demand for the product.
March is one of the peak periods for our business.
The athletes are all in peak condition.
We need extra help during the peak season.

senses.definition: relating to the moment when something is at its most popular or fashionable

examples.en: Everyone thought we'd reached peak beard (= the time when beards are most popular), but the trend shows no sign of slowing down.
The movie is a straightforward peak millennial (= for or by people born towards the end of the 20th century) romcom.

senses.definition: (especially in the past, or in poorer countries) a farmer who owns or rents a small piece of land

examples.en: peasant farmers
a peasant family
peasant revolts

senses.definition: a person who is rude, behaves badly or has little education
strange or unusual, especially in a way that is unpleasant or makes you worried

examples.en: a peculiar smell/taste
The meat tasted rather peculiar.
There was something peculiar in the way he smiled.
I had a peculiar feeling we'd met before.
He died in very peculiar circumstances.
For some peculiar reason, she refused to come inside.

senses.definition: belonging or relating to one particular place, situation, person, etc., and not to others

examples.en: a humour that is peculiar to American sitcoms
a species of bird peculiar to Asia
He has his own peculiar style which you'll soon get used to.
the family’s peculiar importance in the affair
the peculiar properties of mercury

senses.definition: slightly ill

examples.en: I don’t think I’ll eat anything—I’m feeling a bit peculiar.

variants.html: (US English funny weird/strange)

senses.definition: used to show that ‘funny’ is being used with the meaning of ‘strange’
a person who is the same age or who has the same social status as you

examples.en: She enjoys the respect of her peers.
A peer review system is being introduced to help teachers who are experiencing difficulty.
Children are worried about failing in front of their peers.
Peer pressure is strong among young people (= they want to be like other people of the same age).

senses.definition: (in the UK) a member of the nobility or the House of Lords

examples.en: MPs and peers from all parties met to discuss the issue.

senses.definition: to look closely or carefully at something, especially when you cannot see it clearly

examples.en: We peered into the shadows.
He went to the window and peered out.
She kept peering over her shoulder.
He peered closely at the photograph.

senses.definition: an instrument made of plastic or metal used for writing with ink (= coloured liquid for writing, etc.)

examples.en: an ink pen
Let me grab a pen.
to use pen and paper
pen and ink
a message written in red pen (= using a red pen)
a new book from the pen of (= written by) Zadie Smith

senses.definition: a small piece of land surrounded by a fence in which farm animals are kept

examples.en: a sheep pen

senses.definition: a penitentiary (= a prison)
a penalty (= a chance to score a goal without any defending players, except the goalkeeper, trying to stop it)

examples.en: That was a terrible pen.

idioms.word: the pen is mightier than the sword

senses.definition: people who write books, poems, etc. have a greater effect on history and human affairs than soldiers and wars
to write or start to write something
a small mistake in something that you write or say

examples.en: Sorry, it was a slip of the pen—I meant to write ‘pheasants’, not ‘peasants’.

senses.definition: to write something

examples.en: He penned a letter to the local paper.

senses.definition: to shut an animal or a person in a small space

examples.en: At clipping time sheep need to be penned.
The whole family were penned up in one room for a month.

senses.definition: a punishment for breaking a law, rule or contract

examples.en: to impose a penalty
Assault carries a maximum penalty of seven years' imprisonment.
The penalty for travelling without a ticket is £200.
Contractors who fall behind schedule incur heavy financial penalties.
Harsher penalties are being imposed for crimes involving firearms.
a penalty clause in a contract
You can withdraw money from the account at any time without penalty.
The Romans prohibited the teaching of the Torah on penalty of death.

senses.definition: a disadvantage suffered as a result of something

examples.en: One of the penalties of fame is loss of privacy.

senses.definition: a disadvantage given to a player or a team when they break a rule

examples.en: He incurred a ten-second penalty in the first round.

senses.dis_g: (in football (soccer) and some other similar sports)
senses.definition: a chance to score a goal or point without any defending players, except the goalkeeper, trying to stop it; the goal or point that is given if it is successful. This chance is given because the other team has broken the rules.

examples.en: Two minutes later Ford equalized with a penalty.
We were awarded a penalty after a late tackle.
I volunteered to take the penalty (= be the person who tries to score the goal/point).
He missed a penalty in the last minute of the game.

idioms.word: pay the/a penalty/price (for something/for doing something)

senses.definition: to suffer because of bad luck, a mistake or something you have done

examples.en: He looked terrible this morning. I think he's paying the penalty for all those late nights.
They're now paying the price for past mistakes.
She thinks that any inconvenience is a price worth paying for living in such a beautiful place.

senses.definition: a narrow piece of wood, or a metal or plastic case, containing a black or coloured substance, used for drawing or writing

examples.en: I'll get a pencil and paper.
coloured pencils
I need to sharpen my pencil.
She scribbled a note in pencil.
margin notes in pencil
Each picture was carefully drawn with pencil and then colour was added.
a pencil drawing/sketch

senses.definition: to write, draw or mark something with a pencil

examples.en: a pencilled portrait
A previous owner had pencilled ‘First Edition’ inside the book's cover.

senses.definition: a small British coin and unit of money. There are 100 pence in one pound (£1).

examples.en: He had a few pennies in his pocket.
That will be 45 pence, please.
They cost 20p each.

senses.definition: a British coin in use until 1971. There were twelve pennies in one shilling and twenty shillings in a pound.
a cent

examples.en: The fee ranges from a few pennies to $30 or more.

senses.definition: all of the money

examples.en: We collected £700 and every penny went to charity.
She’s on a high salary but I’m sure she deserves every penny.

idioms.word: in for a penny, in for a pound

senses.definition: used to say that since you have started to do something, it is worth spending as much time or money as you need to in order to complete it
no money at all

examples.en: It didn't cost a penny.
He has never paid me a penny.
She hasn’t got a penny to her name.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody has finally understood or realized something that they had not understood or realized before

examples.en: I had to explain the joke to her a couple of times before the penny dropped.

idioms.word: a penny for your thoughts | a penny for them

senses.definition: used to ask somebody what they are thinking about
to try to spend as little money as possible
a lot of money

examples.en: I bet that cost you a pretty penny.

senses.definition: people say ‘spend a penny’ to avoid saying ‘use the toilet’

idioms.word: turn up like a bad penny

senses.definition: to appear when they are not welcome or not wanted, especially when this happens regularly

variants.text: (North American English a dime a dozen)
variants.html: (North American English a dime a dozen)

senses.definition: very common and therefore not valuable

examples.en: Teachers of history are ten a penny.

senses.definition: a first name for girls, short for Penelope
human beings; men, women and children

examples.en: At least ten people were killed in the crash.
There were a lot of people at the party.
Many young people are out of work.
older people
They are just ordinary people.
Millions of working people are struggling.
It is important to involve local people in the project.
poor/rich people
people of faith (= people who are religious)

senses.definition: humans in general; everyone

examples.en: We want to change the way people think.
People want fresh, local food.
He wanted to help people fulfil their potential.
She tends to annoy people.

senses.definition: all the people who live in a particular place or belong to a particular country, ethnic group, etc.

examples.en: the American/French people
black/white people
the indigenous peoples of Mexico

senses.definition: men and women who work in a particular type of job or are involved in a particular area of activity

examples.en: a meeting with business people and bankers
These garments are intended for professional sports people.

senses.definition: the ordinary citizens of a country rather than those who govern or have a special position in society

examples.en: the life of the common people
It was felt that the government was no longer in touch with the people.

senses.definition: the men, women and children that a person leads

examples.en: The king urged his people to prepare for war.
the story of the Zulu leader who died while attempting to free his people

senses.definition: the men and women who work for you or support you

examples.en: I've had my people watching the house for a few days.
Our people are all highly trained and motivated.

senses.definition: guests or friends

examples.en: I'm having people to dinner this evening.

senses.definition: the men, women and children that you are closely related to, especially your parents, grandparents, etc.

examples.en: She's spending the holidays with her people.

idioms.word: be all things to all men/people

senses.definition: to please everyone by changing your attitudes or opinions to suit different people
to be understood or used in different ways by different people
a man/woman who understands and supports ordinary people

examples.en: He is not only a statesman, but also a man of the people.

senses.definition: when you say of all people, you are emphasizing that somebody is the person you would most or least expect to do something

examples.en: She of all people should know the answer to that.

idioms.word: people (who live) in glass houses shouldn’t throw stones

senses.definition: you should not criticize other people, because they will easily find ways of criticizing you
to live in a place or fill it with people

examples.en: The town was peopled largely by workers from the car factory and their families.
The ballroom was peopled with guests.
Her novels are peopled with interesting, complex characters.

senses.definition: a popular US magazine published each week. It contains photographs of and articles about film and television stars, as well as news stories. It was begun in 1974.
The Sunday People
a powder made from dried berries (called peppercorns), used to give a hot, spicy taste to food

examples.en: Season with salt and pepper
freshly ground pepper
sirloin steak with a pepper sauce

variants.text: (also sweet pepper British English, North American English)
variants.html: (also sweet pepper British English, North American English)

senses.definition: a hollow fruit, usually red, green or yellow, eaten as a vegetable either raw or cooked

examples.en: He gave me a great recipe for stuffed peppers.
peppers stuffed with meat and rice

senses.definition: to put pepper on food

examples.en: peppered steak
Salt and pepper the potatoes.

senses.definition: used to express the cost or amount of something for each person, number used, distance travelled, etc.

examples.en: Rooms cost £50 per person, per night.
60 miles per hour
France consumes around 200 000 tonnes of cocoa per year.
This country has a higher crime rate per 100 000 of the population than most other European countries.

senses.definition: following something that has been decided

examples.en: The work was carried out as per instructions.

senses.definition: in the way that is normal or usual; as often happens

examples.en: Everyone blamed me as per usual.

senses.definition: to understand or think of somebody/something in a particular way

examples.en: This discovery was perceived as a major breakthrough.
I do not perceive myself as an expert.
A science degree and artistic interests are often perceived as incompatible.
They were widely perceived to have been unlucky.

senses.definition: to notice or become aware of something

examples.en: I perceived a change in his behaviour.
She perceived that all was not well.
The patient was perceived to have difficulty in breathing.

senses.definition: the number, amount or rate of something, expressed as if it is part of a total that is 100; a part or share of a whole

examples.en: What percentage of the population is/are overweight?
A high percentage of the female staff are part-time workers.
a large/small/low percentage
The figure is expressed as a percentage.
The results were analysed in percentage terms.
Interest rates are expected to rise by one percentage point (= a unit of one per cent).

senses.definition: a share of the profits of something

examples.en: He gets a percentage for every car sold.
The artist's agent receives commission on a percentage basis.

senses.definition: an idea, a belief or an image you have as a result of how you see or understand something

examples.en: a campaign to change public perception of the police
There is a general public perception that standards in schools are falling.

senses.definition: the way you notice things, especially with the senses

examples.en: Everyone's perception of reality is slightly different.
visual perception

senses.definition: the ability to understand the true nature of something

examples.en: She showed great perception in her assessment of the family situation.
They have little perception of how ordinary people live their lives.

senses.definition: having everything that is necessary; complete and without faults or weaknesses

examples.en: in perfect condition
He smiled, revealing a perfect set of teeth.
Well I'm sorry—but nobody's perfect (= used when somebody has criticized you).
In a perfect world, everybody would have everything they needed.
What's your idea of the perfect partner?

senses.definition: completely correct; exact and accurate

examples.en: She speaks perfect English.
a perfect fit/match
What perfect timing!

senses.definition: the best of its kind

examples.en: a perfect example of the painter’s early style
the perfect crime (= one in which the criminal is never discovered)

senses.definition: excellent; very good

examples.en: The weather was perfect.
I have this dress that would just look perfect on you!

senses.definition: exactly right for somebody/something

examples.en: Hawaii is the perfect place for a honeymoon.
She's the perfect candidate for the job.
You and Jeff are perfect for each other.
‘Will 2.30 be OK for you?’ ‘Perfect, thanks.’

senses.definition: total; complete

examples.en: I don't know him—he's a perfect stranger.
I have a perfect right to ask you—and you have the right not to answer.

senses.definition: connected with the form of a verb that consists of part of the verb have with the past participle of the main verb, used to express actions completed by the present or a particular point in the past or future

examples.en: ‘I have eaten’ is the present perfect tense of the verb ‘to eat’, ‘I had eaten’ is the past perfect and ‘I will have eaten’ is the future perfect.

senses.definition: used to say that something is what you would like to happen or what should happen, but you know it cannot

examples.en: In an ideal world we would be recycling and reusing everything.

senses.definition: a way of encouraging people by telling them that if you do an activity regularly and try to improve your skill, you will become very good at it
to make something perfect or as good as you can

examples.en: As a musician, she has spent years perfecting her technique.
They have perfected the art of winemaking.

senses.definition: the form of a verb that expresses actions completed by the present or a particular point in the past or future, formed in English with part of the verb have and the past participle of the main verb
completely

examples.en: It's perfectly normal to feel like this.
It's perfectly good as it is (= it doesn't need changing).
I thought he'd be upset, but he seems perfectly fine.
You know perfectly well what I mean.
To be perfectly honest, I didn't want to go anyway.
He stood perfectly still until the danger had passed.
‘Do you understand?’ ‘Perfectly.’
How perfectly awful!
They’re perfectly within their rights to ask to see the report.
He is perfectly suited to the role.
Sparkling wine is a perfectly acceptable alternative to champagne.

senses.definition: in a perfect way

examples.en: The TV works perfectly now.
This dress fits perfectly.

senses.definition: to entertain an audience by playing a piece of music, acting in a play, etc.

examples.en: to perform a song/dance/play
The play was first performed in 2007.
Visiting artists will perform their music and poetry.
I'm looking forward to seeing you perform.
I'd love to see them perform live (= in a live show, not a recording).
What do you like about performing on stage?

senses.definition: to do something, such as a piece of work, task or duty

examples.en: She performs an important role in our organization.
A computer can perform many tasks at once.
to perform a function/duty
to perform an analysis/a test/an experiment
to perform a ceremony/ritual
to perform an operation/a procedure/surgery
The procedure was performed safely on ten patients.

senses.definition: to work or function well or badly

examples.en: The engine seems to be performing well.
The company has been performing poorly over the past year.
England's players perform better for their clubs than for their country.
to perform admirably/brilliantly/strongly
She performed less well in the second test.
They gather information on how businesses are performing.
If James performs (= performs well) then I believe Wales can win.

senses.definition: to achieve very good results

examples.en: Her exercise programme has worked miracles for her.
You can work miracles with very little money if you follow our home decoration tips.
He performed miracles to get everything ready in time.

senses.definition: the act of performing a play, concert or some other form of entertainment

examples.en: The performance starts at seven.
an evening performance
They put on performances for the tourists.
This was one of the band's rare live performances.
They gave a performance of Ravel’s String Quartet
a series of performances by the Kirov Ballet

senses.definition: the way a person performs in a play, concert, etc.

examples.en: She gave the greatest performance of her career.
Both actors deliver outstanding performances.
an excellent/a fine/an impressive performance

senses.definition: how well or badly you do something; how well or badly something works

examples.en: the country's strong economic performance over the last two years
It was an impressive performance by the French team.
He criticized the recent poor performance of the company.
Her academic performance has been inconsistent.
Profits continue to grow, with strong performances in South America and the Far East.
The team has continued to improve performance.
This machine delivers excellent performance at a very competitive price.
to measure/evaluate the performance of somebody/something
high-performance (= very powerful) cars
performance indicators (= things that show how well or badly something is working)

senses.definition: the act or process of performing a task, an action, etc.

examples.en: She has shown enthusiasm in the performance of her duties.
He did not want a repeat performance of the humiliating defeat he had suffered.
The party are dreading a repeat performance of their defeat in the last election.

senses.definition: an act that involves a lot of effort or trouble, sometimes when it is not necessary

examples.en: It's such a performance getting the children off to school in the morning.
He always goes through the whole performance of checking the oil and water even if we’re in a hurry.

senses.definition: possibly

examples.en: ‘Are you going to come?’ ‘Perhaps. I'll see how I feel.’
Perhaps he's forgotten.

senses.definition: used when you want to make a statement or opinion less definite

examples.en: This is perhaps his best novel to date.
He had a difficult upbringing, which perhaps explains why he behaves like that.

senses.definition: used when making a rough estimate

examples.en: a change which could affect perhaps 20 per cent of the population

senses.definition: used when you agree or accept something unwillingly, or do not want to say that you think something is bad

examples.en: ‘You could do it yourself.’ ‘Yeah, perhaps.’

senses.definition: used when making a polite request, offer or suggestion

examples.en: Perhaps it would be better if you came back tomorrow.
I think perhaps you've had enough to drink tonight.
Perhaps you’d like to have a shower before the others arrive.
Perhaps you would be good enough to let him know we are on our way.

senses.definition: a particular length of time

examples.en: a long/an extended period
a short/brief period
a period of transition/uncertainty/expansion
a period of two years/six months/four weeks
a two-year/six-month/four-week period
All these changes happened over a period of time.
A year-to-year lease has no fixed time period.
The offer is available for a limited period only.
This compares with a 4% increase for the same period last year.
The project will run for a six-month trial period.
The hall will be closed over a 2-year period.
We know little of her life during that period.
The aim is to reduce traffic at peak periods.
Tomorrow will be cold with sunny periods.

senses.definition: a length of time in the life of a particular person or in the history of a particular country

examples.en: Which period of history would you most like to have lived in?
This textbook covers the post-war period.
The church dates from the Norman period.
We are currently studying the early medieval period.
Like Picasso, she too had a blue period.
Most teenagers go through a period of rebelling.

senses.definition: a length of time which is a division of an era. A period is divided into epochs.

examples.en: the Jurassic period
Dinosaurs died out during the Cretaceous period.

senses.definition: any of the parts that a day is divided into at a school, college, etc. for study

examples.en: ‘What do you have next period?’ ‘French.’
a free/study period (= for private study)

senses.definition: the flow of blood each month from the body of a woman who is not pregnant

examples.en: period pains
monthly periods
When did you last have a period?

variants.html: (British English full stop)

senses.definition: the mark ( . ) used at the end of a sentence and in some abbreviations, for example e.g.

variants.html: (British English also full stop)

senses.definition: used at the end of a sentence to emphasize that there is nothing more to say about a subject

examples.en: The answer is no, period!

senses.definition: having a style typical of a particular time in history

examples.en: period costumes/furniture

senses.definition: lasting for a long time or for all time in the future; existing all the time

examples.en: She was unable to find a permanent job.
Holiday camps employ only a very small number of permanent staff.
They are now living together on a permanent basis.
The accident has not done any permanent damage.
a permanent fixture (= a person or an object that is always in a particular place)
a permanent resident of the United States
She doesn't intend to make London her permanent home.
The gallery hosts various exhibitions and a permanent collection.
We decided to make the arrangement permanent.

senses.definition: a perm (= a way of changing the style of your hair by using chemicals to create curls that last for several months)
in a way that lasts for a long time or for all time in the future; in a way that exists all the time

examples.en: The stroke left his right side permanently damaged.
She had decided to settle permanently in France.
This door is kept permanently locked.

senses.definition: the act of allowing somebody to do something, especially when this is done by somebody in a position of authority

examples.en: You must ask permission for all major expenditure.
After much persuasion, permission was granted to speak to the refugees at the camp.
The school has been refused permission to expand.
All minors must seek parental permission to marry.

examples.cf: permission for somebody/something to do something
examples.en: No official permission has been given for the event to take place.
You shouldn't rent out your property without seeking permission from your mortgage lender.

examples.cf: permission from somebody/something to do something
examples.en: He had to get permission from his parents to audition for the show.
She took the car without permission.
With your permission, I'd like to say a few words.
poems reprinted by kind permission of the author

senses.definition: an official written statement allowing somebody to do something

examples.en: The publisher is responsible for obtaining the necessary permissions to reproduce illustrations.
The report recommends that all planning permissions for quarrying in national parks should expire in ten years.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to do something or to allow something to happen

examples.en: Mobile phones are not permitted in the examination room.
We were not permitted any contact with each other.
Visitors are not permitted to take photographs.
The owners have been unwilling to permit the use of their land.
There are fines for exceeding permitted levels of noise pollution.
Jim permitted himself a wry smile.
The bill was designed to permit new fathers to take time off work.
She would not permit herself to look at them.
Permit me to offer you some advice.

senses.definition: to make something possible

examples.en: We hope to visit the cathedral, if time permits.
I'll come tomorrow, weather permitting (= if the weather is fine).
The password permits access to all files on the hard disk.
The length of the report does not permit a detailed discussion of the problems.
Cash machines permit you to withdraw money at any time.

senses.definition: an official document that gives somebody the right to do something, especially for a limited period of time

examples.en: a parking/building permit
to apply for a permit
The agency issued permits for exploratory drilling.
The company failed to obtain the necessary permits for the landfill project.
You cannot enter the military base without a permit.

senses.definition: to continue to do something despite difficulties or opposition, in a way that can seem unreasonable

examples.en: Why do you persist in blaming yourself for what happened?
She persisted in her search for the truth.
He persisted with his questioning.
‘So, did you agree or not?’ he persisted.

senses.definition: to continue to exist

examples.en: The belief that the earth was flat persisted for many centuries.
If the symptoms persist, consult your doctor.

senses.definition: determined to do something despite difficulties, especially when other people are against you and think that you are being annoying or unreasonable

examples.en: How do you deal with persistent salesmen who won't take no for an answer?
a persistent offender (= a person who continues to commit crimes after they have been caught and punished)
She can be very persistent when she wants something.

senses.definition: continuing for a long period of time, or repeated frequently, especially in a way that is annoying and cannot be stopped

examples.en: Persistent heavy rain held up work on the bridge for more than a week.
The most common symptom is a persistent cough.
I can’t take much more of this persistent criticism.
He resigned over persistent rumours of his affair with an actress.
Famine is a persistent problem in many parts of the world.

senses.definition: a human as an individual

examples.en: What sort of person would do a thing like that?
He's a fascinating person.
What is she like as a person?
He's just the person we need for the job.
She's the only person I can talk to about my problems.
Gary was the last person I expected to see when I answered the doorbell.
I had a letter from the people who used to live next door.
I'm not really a city person (= I don't really like cities).

senses.definition: a human, especially one who is not identified

examples.en: A certain person (= somebody that I do not wish to name) told me about it.
The price is $40 per person.
This vehicle is licensed to carry 4 persons. (= in a notice)
The verdict was murder by a person or persons unknown.
The virus is spread from person to person.

senses.definition: a person working in the area of business mentioned; a person connected with the thing mentioned

examples.en: a salesperson
a spokesperson

senses.definition: any of the three classes of personal pronouns. The first person (I/we) refers to the person(s) speaking; the second person (you) refers to the person(s) spoken to; the third person (he/she/it/they) refers to the person(s) or thing(s) spoken about.
if you have or carry something about/on your person, you carry it about with you, for example in your pocket

examples.en: Relatives of the dead man were traced through an address found on his person.

idioms.word: be no respecter of persons, age, class, etc.

senses.definition: to treat everyone in the same way, without being influenced by their importance, wealth, etc.

examples.en: Death is no respecter of persons.

senses.definition: if you do something in person, you go somewhere and do it yourself, instead of doing it by letter, asking somebody else to do it, etc.

examples.en: You have to pick up the package in person.
She appeared in person to collect her prize.

senses.definition: in the form or shape of somebody

examples.en: Help arrived in the person of his mother.
The firm has an important asset in the person of the sales director.

senses.definition: a person who is believed to be involved in a crime, but who has not been arrested

examples.en: Police have said they do have a person of interest in the case.

senses.definition: your own; not belonging to or connected with anyone else

examples.en: The novel is written from personal experience.
a personal account of her experiences
personal effects/belongings/possessions
I take personal responsibility for the incident.
Of course, this is just a personal opinion.
a personal preference/view
Her art is deeply personal.
intensely/highly personal
I need my own personal space.
The software is for personal use only (= no one else can use it).

senses.definition: between individual people who know each other

examples.en: Having good personal relationships is the most important thing for me.
She is a personal friend of mine.

senses.definition: connected with a person’s private life, rather than their job or official position

examples.en: I try not to let work interfere with my personal life.
personal information/data/details (= information about you that not everyone can know)
The letter was marked ‘Personal’.
I'd like to talk to you about a personal matter.
Please keep personal phone calls to a minimum.
I'd rather not talk about it, it's personal.
He moved to San Francisco for personal reasons.

senses.definition: done by a particular person rather than by somebody who is acting for them

examples.en: The President made a personal appearance at the event.
I shall give the matter my personal attention.
She takes a personal interest in the work of the charity.
The Principal has little personal contact with the students.

senses.definition: made or done for a particular person rather than for a large group of people or people in general

examples.en: We offer a personal service to all our customers.
a personal pension plan (= a pension organized by a private company for one particular person)
Will you do it for me as a personal favour?

senses.definition: referring to a particular person’s character, appearance, opinions, etc. in a way that is offensive

examples.en: Try to avoid making personal remarks.
I felt the criticism crossed the line and became a personal attack.
Then he got personal and brought my family into it.
It's nothing personal (= I do not wish to offend you) but I have to correct you on that point.

senses.definition: connected with a person’s body

examples.en: personal cleanliness/hygiene
She's always worrying about her personal appearance.
This insurance policy covers you against personal injury or death.

senses.definition: physically very close to somebody; getting to know them well

examples.en: Get up close and personal with the koalas at the San Diego Zoo.
For the last 30 years, I’ve been up close and personal with people whose lives were in crisis.

senses.definition: the various aspects of a person’s character that combine to make them different from other people

examples.en: His wife has a strong personality.
My outgoing personality has definitely helped me succeed.
He maintained order by sheer force of personality.
normal human personality traits (= qualities), such as shyness
Participants identified their own personality type and explored the implications.
The characters' names reflect their personalities.
There are likely to be tensions and personality clashes in any social group.
People’s clothes are often an expression of their personality.

senses.definition: the qualities of a person’s character that make them interesting and attractive

examples.en: We need someone with lots of personality to head the project.

senses.definition: a famous person, especially one who works in entertainment or sport

examples.en: a well-known TV/radio/sports personality
Various personalities from the world of music were invited.

senses.definition: a person whose strong character attracts attention

examples.en: Their son is a real personality.

senses.definition: the qualities of a place or thing that make it interesting and different

examples.en: The problem with many modern buildings is that they lack personality.
Interesting displays can add personality to your store window.

senses.definition: used to show that you are giving your own opinion about something

examples.en: Personally, I prefer the second option.
‘Is it worth the effort?’ ‘Speaking personally, yes.’
I personally think it would be the wrong thing to do.

senses.definition: by a particular person rather than by somebody acting for them

examples.en: All emails will be answered personally.
Do you know him personally (= have you met him, rather than just knowing about him from other people)?
I’ll deal with the matter personally.
He’s no longer personally involved in the day-to-day running of the company.
He did not benefit personally from the fraud.
I have never personally witnessed public violence.

senses.definition: in a way that is connected with one particular person rather than a group of people

examples.en: He was personally criticized by inspectors for his incompetence.
You will be held personally responsible for any loss or breakage.

senses.definition: in a way that is intended to be offensive

examples.en: I'm sure she didn't mean it personally.

senses.definition: in a way that is connected with somebody’s personal life rather than with their job or official position

examples.en: Have you had any dealings with any of the suspects, either personally or professionally?

senses.definition: to be offended by something

examples.en: I'm afraid he took your remarks personally.
Please don’t take this personally, but would you mind leaving us alone for a few moments?

senses.definition: the people who work for an organization or one of the armed forces

examples.en: There is a severe shortage of skilled personnel.
sales/technical/medical/security/military, etc. personnel

senses.definition: the department in a company that deals with employing and training people

examples.en: the personnel department/manager

senses.definition: a particular attitude towards something; a way of thinking about something

examples.en: a global perspective

a report that looks at the education system from the perspective of deaf people
The exhibition provides us with a unique perspective on her work.

senses.definition: the ability to think about problems and decisions in a reasonable way without making them seem worse or more important than they really are

examples.en: She was aware that she was losing all sense of perspective.

Talking to others can often help to put your own problems into perspective.
It is important not to let things get out of perspective.

senses.definition: the art of creating an effect of depth and distance in a picture by representing people and things that are far away as being smaller than those that are nearer the front

examples.en: The artist plays with perspective to confuse the eye.

senses.definition: a view, especially one in which you can see far into the distance

examples.en: a perspective of the whole valley

senses.definition: to make somebody do something by giving them good reasons for doing it

examples.en: Try to persuade him to come.
Please try and persuade her.
She's always easily persuaded.

There was no way to persuade him out of it (= persuade him not to do it).

examples.cf: persuade somebody out of doing something
examples.en: My sister persuaded me out of dying my hair.

senses.definition: to make somebody believe that something is true

examples.en: It will be difficult to persuade them that there's no other choice.

No one was persuaded by his arguments.
I am still not fully persuaded of the plan's merits.

senses.definition: an animal, a bird, etc. that you have at home for pleasure, rather than one that is kept for work or food

examples.en: Do you have any pets?
a pet dog/hamster
a family pet
exotic pets
pet food

a pet shop (= where animals are sold as pets)

senses.definition: a person who is given special attention by somebody, especially in a way that seems unfair to other people

examples.en: She's the teacher's pet.

senses.definition: used when speaking to somebody to show kind feelings or to be friendly

examples.en: What's wrong, pet?

senses.definition: to touch or move your hand gently over an animal or a child in a kind and loving way

examples.en: He petted the dog and ruffled its fur.

senses.definition: to kiss and touch each other in a sexual way
that you are very interested in

examples.en: his pet subject/theory/project, etc.

variants.html: (North American English somebody’s pet peeve)

senses.definition: something that you particularly dislike
an artificial substance used to make materials for packaging food, including plastic drinks bottles (the abbreviation for ‘polyethylene terephthalate’)
a process that produces an image of your brain or of another part inside your body (the abbreviation for ‘positron emission tomography’)

examples.en: a PET scan

senses.definition: a British test, now called ‘B1 Preliminary’, that measures a person’s ability to speak and write English as a foreign language at an intermediate level (the abbreviation for ‘Preliminary English Test’)
a written document signed by a large number of people that asks somebody in a position of authority to do or change something

examples.en: Would you like to sign our petition against experiments on animals?

to present/deliver a petition
to start/launch a petition

senses.definition: an official document asking a court to take a particular course of action

examples.en: a bankruptcy petition

senses.definition: a formal prayer to God or request to somebody in authority
to make a formal request to somebody in authority, especially by sending them a petition

examples.en: Local residents have successfully petitioned against the siting of a prison in their area.

examples.en: His wife has petitioned for divorce.

variants.html: (North American English gas, gasoline)

senses.definition: a liquid obtained from petroleum, used as fuel in car engines, etc.

to run out of petrol

the petrol tank of a car

leaded/unleaded petrol

senses.definition: working/not working together in the right way

examples.en: The traffic lights were out of phase.

senses.definition: to arrange to do something in stages over a period of time

examples.en: Closure of the hospitals was phased over a three-year period.
the phased withdrawal of troops from the area

senses.definition: a fact or an event in nature or society, especially one that is not fully understood

examples.en: cultural/natural phenomena

senses.definition: a person who studies or writes about philosophy

examples.en: We studied the writings of the Greek philosopher Aristotle.

senses.definition: a person who thinks deeply about things

examples.en: He seems to be a bit of a philosopher.

philosophic debate

senses.definition: having a calm attitude towards a difficult or disappointing situation

examples.en: He was philosophical about losing and said that he'd be back next year to try again.

senses.definition: the study of the nature and meaning of the universe and of human life

examples.en: the philosophy of science
a professor of philosophy
a degree in philosophy

senses.definition: a particular set or system of beliefs resulting from the search for knowledge about life and the universe

examples.en: Buddhist/Eastern/Hindu philosophy
the philosophy of Aristotle
the development of different philosophies

senses.definition: a set of beliefs or an attitude to life that guides somebody’s behaviour

examples.en: Her philosophy of life is to take every opportunity that presents itself.

xylophone

senses.definition: speaking a particular language; a person who does this

examples.en: anglophone

senses.definition: a sound made in speech, especially when not considered as part of the sound system of a particular language
to be using the phone

senses.definition: a picture that is made by using a camera that stores images in digital form or that has a film sensitive to light inside it

a photo-sharing website

senses.definition: connected with light

colour/black-and-white photographs

a framed photograph of her grandchildren

to publish/release a photograph

examples.en: a workshop on photographing wildlife
a beautifully photographed book (= with very good photographs in it)

examples.en: Her hobbies include hiking and photography.
digital photography
colour/black-and-white photography
aerial/underwater photography
fashion photography by David Burn

senses.definition: a small group of words (usually without a finite verb) that together have a particular meaning and that typically form part of a sentence. ‘the green car’ and ‘on Friday morning’ are phrases.

senses.definition: a short series of notes that form a unit within a longer passage in a piece of music

examples.en: Oh well, no news is good news, to coin a phrase.

senses.definition: a particular way of describing something

senses.definition: an amount of something that has been cut or separated from the rest of it; a standard amount of something

examples.en: She wrote something on a small piece of paper.
a piece of wood/metal
a large piece of land
a piece of cake
a piece of cheese/meat/bread
I've got a piece of grit in my eye.
a small/little/tiny piece of something
He cut the pizza into bite-sized pieces.

senses.definition: one of the bits or parts that something breaks into

examples.en: There were tiny pieces of glass all over the road.
The boat had been smashed to pieces on the rocks.
The building was blown to pieces.
tear/rip something to pieces
The vase lay in pieces on the floor.

senses.definition: one of the parts that something is made of

examples.en: He took the clock to pieces.
a missing piece of the puzzle
The bridge was taken down piece by piece.
She's been doing a 500-piece jigsaw.

senses.definition: a single item of a particular type, especially one that forms part of a set

examples.en: a piece of equipment/furniture
a piece of clothing/luggage
a piece of machinery
a 28-piece dinner service

senses.definition: used with many uncountable nouns to describe a single example or an amount of something

examples.en: a piece of information/evidence/advice/news/legislation
a piece of software
This is a superb piece of work.
It was an interesting piece of research.
The building is a piece of history (= of historical interest or importance).
Isn't that a piece of luck?
You should eat at least two pieces of fruit a day.

senses.definition: a single item of writing, art, music, etc. that somebody has produced or created; a short item of writing from a longer work

examples.en: a piece of music/art
a fine piece of writing
They performed pieces by Bach and Handel.
The painting is a companion piece to (= is closely related to and intended to be displayed with) an earlier work.
They have some beautiful pieces (= works of art, etc.) in their home.
She read a piece from ‘Alice in Wonderland’.

senses.definition: an article in a newspaper or magazine or a broadcast on television or radio

examples.en: The Washington Post ran a series of opinion pieces criticizing the policy.
Did you see her piece about the internet in the paper today?

senses.definition: a coin of the value mentioned

examples.en: a 50p piece
a five-cent piece

senses.definition: one of the small figures or objects that you move around in games such as chess
a part or share of something

examples.en: companies seeking a piece of the market

senses.definition: a gun
a short distance

examples.en: She lives down the road a piece from here.

senses.definition: small objects or items of various kinds

examples.en: She stuffed all her bits and pieces into a bag and left.
I just need to get a few bits and pieces at the supermarket.

senses.definition: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely

examples.en: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

senses.definition: to become very old and in bad condition because of long use

examples.en: Our car is falling to pieces, we've had it so long.
My old dictionary is falling to pieces.

senses.dis_g: (of a person, an organization, a plan, etc.)
senses.definition: to stop working; to be destroyed

examples.en: He's worried the business will fall to pieces without him.

idioms.word: give somebody a piece of your mind

senses.definition: to tell somebody that you think their behaviour is bad or are angry with them
to be so upset or afraid that you cannot manage to live or work normally

examples.en: After his wife died he just went to pieces.

idioms.word: how long is a piece of string?

senses.definition: used to say that there is no definite answer to a question

examples.en: ‘How long will it take?’ ‘How long's a piece of string?’

senses.definition: safe; not damaged or hurt, especially after a journey or dangerous experience

examples.en: They were lucky to get home in one piece.

senses.definition: a person who is unpleasant, unkind or dishonest

examples.en: Don’t trust him; he’s a nasty piece of work.
He's a thoroughly nasty piece of work.

senses.definition: all the same or similar

examples.en: The houses are all of a piece.

senses.definition: all at the same time

examples.en: The house was built all of a piece in 1754.

senses.definition: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely
to return or to help somebody return to a normal situation, particularly after a shock or a disaster

examples.en: You cannot live your children's lives for them; you can only be there to pick up the pieces when things go wrong.

senses.definition: a thing that is very easy to do

variants.text: (British English also a slice/share of the cake)
variants.html: (British English also a slice/share of the cake)

senses.definition: a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to

examples.en: The company is demanding a larger slice of the corporate pie.

senses.definition: a thing that is very easy to do
used to express the fact that you admire somebody or find them funny, often when they have done something that surprises you

examples.en: You're some piece of work, Jack, do you know that?

senses.definition: a share or role in an interesting or exciting activity, especially one that makes money

examples.en: Foreign firms will all want a piece of the action if the new airport goes ahead.

senses.definition: to say exactly what you feel or think
the person or thing that is responsible for all the trouble in a situation

examples.en: It’s hard to identify the real villain of the piece in this case.

variants.text: (also hog especially in North American English)
variants.html: (also hog especially in North American English)

senses.definition: an animal with pink, black or brown skin, short legs, a broad nose and a short curly tail. Pigs are kept on farms for their meat (called pork) or live in the wild.

examples.en: a pig farmer
Pigs were grunting and squealing in the yard.
to breed/rear pigs

senses.definition: a person who you find unpleasant or offensive; a person who you think is dirty or greedy

examples.en: Arrogant pig!
Don't be such a pig!
The greedy pig's eaten all the biscuits!
She made a pig of herself with the ice cream (= ate too much).
He's a real male chauvinist pig (= a man who does not think women are equal to men).
We cooked up a load of pasta and all made pigs of ourselves.

senses.definition: an offensive word for a police officer

idioms.word: make a pig’s ear (out) of something

senses.definition: to do something badly; to make a mess of something
if you buy a pig in a poke, you buy something without seeing it or knowing if it is good enough

examples.en: Buying online can mean buying a pig in a poke.

senses.definition: a difficult or unpleasant thing or task

examples.en: I've had a pig of a day.

variants.html: (North American English when pigs fly)

senses.definition: used to show that you do not believe something will ever happen

examples.en: ‘With a bit of luck, we'll be finished by the end of the year.’ ‘Yes, and pigs might fly!’

senses.definition: to make small changes to something, especially its outside appearance, to try and hide the fact that it has problems

examples.en: The change of policy doesn't go far enough—it's just putting lipstick on a pig.

senses.definition: to eat too much of something

examples.en: I had a whole box of chocolates and pigged the lot!
Don't give me cakes—I'll just pig myself.

senses.definition: a number of things that have been placed on top of each other

examples.en: a pile of clothes/paper
I found it in a pile of documents on his desk.
The hats were stacked in neat piles.
I've sorted the books into three separate piles.

senses.definition: a mass of something that is high in the middle and wider at the bottom than at the top

examples.en: piles of dirty washing
The house was reduced to a pile of rubble.
He threw the remaining stones onto the pile.

senses.definition: a lot of something

examples.en: He made a pile of cash on the sale of his house.
He walked out leaving a pile of debt behind him.
I have got piles of work to do.

senses.definition: the short threads, pieces of wool, etc. that form the soft surface of carpets and some types of cloth such as velvet

examples.en: a deep-pile carpet
Corduroy is the poor man’s velvet; its pile is made of cotton rather than silk or satin.

senses.definition: a large wooden, metal or stone post that is fixed into the ground and used to support a building, bridge, etc.
a large impressive building

examples.en: a Victorian pile built as a private hospital
her family's ancestral pile

senses.definition: in the least/most important position in a group of people or things

examples.en: It’s been 20 years since a British player was top of the pile.
The government is doing little to help those at the bottom of the social pile.

senses.definition: to make a lot of money

examples.en: The family made its pile from oil.
I bet they made an absolute pile out of the deal.

senses.definition: to put things one on top of another; to form a pile

examples.en: She piled the boxes one on top of the other.
The clothes were piled high on the chair.
Snow was piled up against the door.
We piled the boxes up neatly.
We piled sandbags against the doors.
She was sitting at her desk with books piled around her.

senses.definition: to put something on/into something; to load something with something

examples.en: The sofa was piled high with cushions.
He piled his plate with as much food as he could.
He piled as much food as he could onto his plate.
She piled everything into her suitcase.

senses.definition: to go somewhere quickly without order or control

examples.en: The coach finally arrived and we all piled on.
Children were piling out of the school bus.
The bell rang and kids started piling into the classroom.

senses.definition: to make an unpleasant situation worse

examples.en: Bosses piled on the agony with threats of more job losses.

senses.definition: a small flat round piece of medicine that you swallow whole, without biting it

examples.en: a vitamin pill
Take three pills daily after meals.
pill-popping (= the act of taking too many pills or using illegal drugs)
The doctor prescribed her some pills to help her sleep.
I was on various pills for my heart condition.

variants.html: the pill, the Pill

senses.definition: a pill that some women take to prevent them becoming pregnant

examples.en: the contraceptive pill
to be/go on the pill
Her doctor put her on the pill at 16.

senses.definition: an annoying person
a fact or an event that is unpleasant and difficult to accept

examples.en: The election defeat was a bitter pill for the party to swallow.

senses.definition: to do something that makes an unpleasant situation seem less unpleasant

senses.dis_g: (of a piece of clothing, especially one made of wool)
senses.definition: to become covered in very small balls of fibre
a person who operates the controls of an aircraft, especially as a job

examples.en: an airline pilot
a fighter/helicopter pilot
The accident was caused by pilot error.
The pilot bailed out as the aircraft crashed into the ocean.
He has his own plane and a pilot's licence.

senses.definition: a person with special knowledge of a difficult area of water, for example, the entrance to a harbour, whose job is to guide ships through it
a single television programme that is made in order to find out whether people will like it and want to watch further programmes
a small flame that burns all the time, for example on a gas boiler, and lights a larger flame when the gas is turned on
to fly an aircraft or guide a ship; to act as a pilot

examples.en: The plane was piloted by the instructor.
The captain piloted the boat into a mooring.

senses.definition: to guide somebody/something somewhere, especially through a complicated place or system

examples.en: She piloted a bill on the rights of part-time workers through parliament.

senses.definition: to test a new product, idea, etc. with a few people or in a small area before it is introduced everywhere

examples.en: Several centres have been asked to pilot the new qualification.
The recycling boxes have been successfully piloted in a number of areas.
The scheme is already being piloted in Germany.

senses.definition: done on a small scale in order to see if something is successful enough to do on a large scale

examples.en: a pilot project/study/survey
a pilot episode (= of a radio or television series)

senses.definition: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and a round head at the other, used especially for fastening together pieces of cloth when sewing

examples.en: Use pins to keep the patch in place while you sew it on.

senses.definition: a short thin piece of stiff wire with a sharp point at one end and an item of decoration at the other, worn as jewellery

examples.en: a diamond pin

variants.html: (also brooch especially in British English)

senses.definition: a piece of jewellery with a pin on the back of it, that can be fastened to your clothes
a type of badge that is fastened with a pin at the back

examples.en: He supports the group and wears its pin on his lapel.
an American flag lapel pin

senses.definition: a piece of steel used to support a bone in your body when it has been broken

examples.en: The pin in her spine will have to be changed as she grows.

senses.definition: one of the metal parts that stick out of an electric plug and fit into a socket

examples.en: a 2-pin plug

senses.definition: a wooden or plastic object that is like a bottle in shape and that players try to knock down in games such as bowling
a stick with a flag on top of it, placed in a hole so that players can see where they are aiming for

examples.en: The ball stopped five feet short of the pin.

senses.definition: a person’s legs

examples.en: He’s not as quick on his pins as he used to be.

senses.definition: a small piece of metal on a hand grenade that stops it from exploding and is pulled out just before the hand grenade is thrown

variants.text: (also (be) on tenterhooks British and North American English)
variants.html: (also (be) on tenterhooks British and North American English)

senses.definition: (to be) very anxious or excited while you are waiting to find out something or see what will happen

examples.en: I've been on pins and needles all week waiting for the results.

senses.definition: used to say that you would like to do something, even though you know that it would not be sensible

examples.en: I'd kill him for two pins.

idioms.word: you could hear a pin drop

senses.definition: it was extremely quiet

examples.en: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

senses.definition: to attach something onto another thing or fasten things together with a pin, etc.

examples.en: She pinned the badge onto her jacket.
A message had been pinned to the noticeboard.
Pin all the pieces of material together.
She always wears her hair pinned back.
I am trying to pin up the hem of this dress.

senses.definition: to make somebody unable to move by holding them or pressing them against something

examples.en: They pinned him against a wall and stole his wallet.
Her arms were pinned behind her back.
They found him pinned under the wreckage of the car.

variants.html: (also pin your faith on somebody/something)

senses.definition: to rely on somebody/something completely for success or help

examples.en: The company is pinning its hopes on the new project.

senses.definition: a number given to you, for example by a bank, so that you can use a plastic card to take out money from a cash machine (the abbreviation for ‘personal identification number’)
pale red in colour

examples.en: pale pink roses

The sun was now just a pink glow in the evening sky.
She was wearing a hot (= bright) pink top.
Outside, the sky is turning pink.

senses.definition: connected with gay people

examples.en: the pink pound (= money spent by gays and lesbians as an influence in the economy)

senses.definition: having or showing slightly left-wing political views

examples.en: pale pink politics

senses.definition: the colour that is produced when you mix red and white together

examples.en: She was dressed in pink.
She frowned as her cheeks flushed a light shade of pink.
The bedroom was decorated in pale pinks.

senses.definition: a garden plant with pink, red or white flowers that have a sweet smell
in good health

variants.html: (North American English ping)

senses.definition: to make knocking sounds because the fuel is not burning correctly
a person who is the first to study and develop a particular area of knowledge, culture, etc. that other people then continue to develop

examples.en: a pioneer in the field of microsurgery
a computer pioneer
a pioneer aviator
a pioneer design (= one that introduces new ideas, methods, etc.)

senses.definition: one of the first people to go to a particular place, especially in order to live and work there

examples.en: Early pioneers settled on both sides of the Maple River.
the pioneer spirit
The history of our nation isn't just about hardy pioneers and peaceful settlement, it's about violence and dispossession.

senses.definition: when somebody pioneers something, they are one of the first people to do, discover or use something new

examples.en: a new technique pioneered by surgeons in a London hospital

senses.definition: a tube through which liquids and gases can flow

examples.en: Both hot and cold water pipes should be properly insulated.
steel/copper pipes
a burst pipe
The house was blown apart by an explosion, caused by a leaking gas pipe.
PVC pipe is commonly used in building and construction.
a drainage/sewage pipe
Insulation may reduce the danger of pipes bursting in winter.

senses.definition: a narrow tube with a bowl at one end, used for smoking tobacco

examples.en: to smoke a pipe
He puffed on his pipe.
pipe tobacco
He knocked out his pipe in the big glass ashtray.

senses.definition: a musical instrument in the shape of a tube, played by blowing
any of the tubes from which sound is produced in an organ
a musical instrument played especially in Scotland. The player blows air into a bag held under the arm and then slowly forces the air out through pipes to produce a noise.
to send water, gas, oil, etc. through a pipe from one place to another

examples.en: to pipe oil across the desert
Water is piped from the reservoir to the city.

senses.definition: to send sounds or signals through a wire or cable from one place to another

examples.en: The speech was piped over a public address system.

senses.definition: to play music on a pipe or the bagpipes, especially to welcome somebody who has arrived

examples.en: Passengers were piped aboard ship at the start of the cruise.

senses.definition: to speak or sing in a high voice or with a high sound

examples.en: Outside a robin piped.

senses.definition: to decorate food, especially a cake, with thin lines of icing, etc. by forcing it out of a special bag or tube

examples.en: The cake had ‘Happy Birthday’ piped on it.

senses.definition: a series of pipes that are usually underground and are used for carrying oil, gas, etc. over long distances

examples.en: There are plans to lay a gas pipeline through the region.
The pipeline runs through central Mozambique.

senses.definition: something that is in the pipeline is being discussed, planned or prepared and will happen or exist soon

examples.en: Important new laws are already in the pipeline.

senses.definition: (especially in the past) a person on a ship who attacks other ships at sea in order to steal from them

examples.en: There were reports that a pirate ship had come looking for treasure in the cove.

senses.definition: a person who makes illegal copies of books, computer programs, etc., in order to sell them

examples.en: a pirate edition
software pirates

senses.definition: a person or an organization that broadcasts illegally

examples.en: a pirate radio station

senses.definition: to copy and use or sell somebody’s work or a product without permission and without having the right to do so

examples.en: pirated computer games
Jones was accused of having pirated the scientist’s work.

senses.definition: a large deep hole in the ground

examples.en: We dug a deep pit in the yard.

The human mind is a dark, bottomless pit.

senses.definition: a deep hole in the ground from which minerals are dug out

examples.en: a chalk/gravel pit

senses.definition: a place underground where coal is dug

examples.en: pit closures
He went down the pit (= started work as a miner) when he left school.

senses.definition: a small shallow hole in the surface of something, especially a mark left on the surface of the skin by some disease, such as chickenpox

variants.html: (also stone especially in British English)

senses.definition: a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit

examples.en: a peach pit

senses.definition: a place near the track where cars can stop for fuel, new tyres, etc. during a race
the place in a theatre just in front of the stage where the orchestra sits and plays for an opera, a ballet, etc.
an armpit (= the part of the body under the arm where it joins the shoulder)
the area of a stock exchange where a particular product is traded

examples.en: the corn pit

senses.definition: to be very bad or the worst example of something
a thing or situation which seems to have no limits or seems never to end

examples.en: There isn't a bottomless pit of money for public spending.
the bottomless pit of his sorrow

senses.definition: the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear

examples.en: He had a sudden sinking feeling in the pit of his stomach.
I felt a sickening feeling in the pit of my stomach when I saw the ambulance.

senses.definition: to make marks or holes on the surface of something

examples.en: Smallpox scars had pitted his face.
The surface of the moon is pitted with craters.

variants.html: (British English also stone)

senses.definition: to remove the stone from the inside of a fruit

examples.en: pitted olives

variants.text: (also field North American English, British English)
variants.html: (also field North American English, British English)

senses.definition: an area of ground specially prepared and marked for playing a sports game

examples.en: a football pitch
a cricket/rugby/hockey pitch
an artificial pitch
After the game fans invaded the pitch.
The rugby tour was a disaster both on and off the pitch (= they lost their matches and the players behaved badly while on tour, getting bad news reports).

senses.definition: how high or low a sound is, especially a musical note

examples.en: A basic sense of rhythm and pitch is essential in a music teacher.

senses.definition: the degree or strength of a feeling or activity; the highest point of something

examples.en: a frenetic pitch of activity
