to reach a high pitch of excitement

senses.definition: talk or arguments used by a person trying to sell something or persuade people to do something

examples.en: an aggressive sales pitch
the candidate’s campaign pitch
Each company was given ten minutes to make its pitch.

senses.definition: an act of throwing the ball; the way in which it is thrown
a black sticky substance made from oil or coal, used on roofs or the wooden boards of a ship to stop water from coming through
a place in a street or market where somebody sells things, or where somebody performs in order to entertain people outdoors

variants.html: (North American English campsite)

senses.definition: a place in a campsite where you can put up one tent or park one caravan, etc.

examples.en: Pitches to rent from only £15 per night.

senses.definition: the movement of a ship up and down in the water or of an aircraft in the air
the degree to which a roof slopes

examples.en: The pitch of the roof is 45 degrees.

idioms.word: make a pitch for somebody/something | make a pitch to somebody

senses.definition: to make a determined effort to get something or to persuade somebody of something

examples.en: He made a pitch to black voters in Alabama.

idioms.word: queer somebody’s pitch | queer the pitch (for somebody)

senses.definition: to cause somebody’s plans to fail or to destroy their chances of getting something
to throw somebody/something with force

examples.en: The explosion pitched her violently into the air.
The new government has already been pitched into a crisis.

senses.definition: to throw the ball to the person who is batting

examples.en: He pitched against UCLA last week.
My dream was to pitch for the Yankees.

senses.dis_g: (of the ball in the games of golf or cricket)
senses.definition: to hit the ground; to make the ball hit the ground

examples.en: The ball pitched a yard short of the hole.

senses.definition: to hit the ball in a high curve
to fall heavily in a particular direction

examples.en: With a cry she pitched forward.

senses.definition: to move up and down on the water or in the air

examples.en: The sea was rough and the ship pitched and rolled all night.
The boat pitched violently in a heavy swell.

senses.definition: to set something at a particular level

examples.en: They have pitched their prices too high.
The test was pitched at too low a level for the students.

senses.definition: to aim or direct a product or service at a particular group of people

examples.en: The new software is being pitched at banks.
The product is pitched primarily at telecommunications companies.
Orange juice is to be pitched as an athlete's drink.

senses.definition: to try to persuade somebody to buy something, to give you something or to make a business deal with you

examples.en: Representatives went to Japan to pitch the company's newest products.
We were pitching against a much larger company for the contract.

senses.definition: to produce a sound or piece of music at a particular level

examples.en: You pitched that note a little flat.
The song was pitched too low for my voice.
Her voice was pitched low.

senses.definition: to set up a tent or a camp for a short time

examples.en: We could pitch our tent in that field.
They pitched camp for the night near the river.

senses.definition: to tell somebody a story or make an excuse that is not true
used to show that you are disappointed about something

examples.en: It's a pity that you can't stay longer.
‘I've lost it!’ ‘Oh, what a pity.’
What a pity that she didn't tell me earlier.
This dress is really nice. Pity it's so expensive.
Oh, that's a pity.
It would be a great pity if you gave up now.
It seems a pity to waste this food.

senses.definition: a sad feeling caused by the pain and troubles of others

examples.en: I took pity on her and lent her the money.
I beg you to have pity on him.
I don't want your pity.
a look/feeling/surge of pity
I could only feel pity for what they were enduring.
He had no pity for her.

senses.definition: unfortunately

examples.en: ‘Was the bicycle insured?’ ‘No, more's the pity!’

senses.definition: to feel sorry for somebody because of their situation; to feel pity for somebody

examples.en: He pitied people who were stuck in dead-end jobs.
Compulsive gamblers are more to be pitied than condemned.
I pity her having to work such long hours.

senses.definition: a particular position, point or area

examples.en: Keep your purse in a safe place.
I can't be in two places at once.
They organized several demonstrations in public places.
I happened to be in the right place at the right time.
Is this the place where it happened?
This would be a good place for a picnic.
There is a time and place for these questions, but not right here and now.
If you're looking for a new service provider, this list is a good place to start.

senses.definition: a particular city, town, building, etc.

examples.en: I can't remember all the places we visited in Thailand.
I used to live in York and I'm still fond of the place.
The police searched the place.
Let's get out of this place!
We were looking for a place to eat.
a place to live/stay
Please write your full name and date and place of birth.

senses.definition: a building or an area of land used for a particular purpose

examples.en: The town has many excellent eating places.
I couldn't find a parking place anywhere.
churches and other places of worship
He can usually be contacted at his place of work.
They seem to have no fixed employment or place of residence.

senses.definition: a particular area on a surface, especially on a person’s body

examples.en: He broke his arm in three places.
The paint was peeling off the wall in places.
The footbath is bumpy in places.

senses.definition: a point in a book, speech, piece of music, etc., especially one that somebody has reached at a particular time

examples.en: She had marked her place with a bookmark.
Excuse me, I seem to have lost my place.
The audience laughed in all the right places.
The film is scary in places.
This is one of the few places in his work where he mentions his childhood.

senses.definition: the natural or correct position for something

examples.en: Is there a place on the form to put your address?
There is a place to sign and date at the bottom of the form.
Put it back in its place when you've finished with it.
He remembered the saying ‘A place for everything and everything in its place.’

senses.definition: a position, seat, etc., especially one that is available for or being used by a person or vehicle

examples.en: Come and sit here—I've saved you a place.
I don't want to lose my place in the line.
Would you like to change places with me so you can see better?
I've set a place for you at the table.

senses.definition: an opportunity to take part in something, especially to study at a school or university or on a course

examples.en: She's been offered a place at Bath to study Business.
There are very few places left on the course.

senses.definition: the position of being a member of a sports team

examples.en: She has won a place in the Olympic team.
He lost his place in the first team.

senses.definition: a position among the winners of a race or competition; a position in the next stage of a competition

examples.en: She took third place.
He finished in third place.
Victory earned them a place in the final.

senses.definition: the role or importance of somebody/something in a particular situation, usually in relation to others

examples.en: He is assured of his place in history.
They felt that they had no place in society and nowhere to go.
It took her a while to find her place in the world.
Anecdotes have no place in (= are not acceptable in) an academic essay.
Accurate reporting takes second place to lurid detail.
My father believed that people should know their place (= behave according to their social position).
It's not your place (= your role) to give advice.

senses.definition: a house or flat; a person’s home

examples.en: What about dinner at my place?
I'm fed up with living with my parents, so I'm looking for a place of my own.
I thought I’d better clean the place up.

senses.definition: a suitable or safe area for somebody to be

examples.en: These streets are no place for a child to be out alone at night.

senses.definition: the position of a figure after a decimal point

examples.en: Convert the decimal to a percentage by moving the decimal point two places to the right.

senses.definition: used as part of a name for a short street or square

examples.en: 66 Portland Place

variants.text: (British English also all over the shop)
variants.html: (British English also all over the shop)

senses.definition: everywhere

examples.en: New restaurants are appearing all over the place.

senses.definition: not neat or tidy; not well organized

examples.en: Your calculations are all over the place (= completely wrong).

senses.definition: to be getting more and more successful in your life or career

examples.en: a young architect who’s really going places

idioms.word: behave/act as if you own the place | think you own the place

senses.definition: to behave in a very confident way that annoys other people, for example by telling them what to do

examples.en: She was acting as if she owned the place.

idioms.word: be in a good, bad, dark, etc. place

variants.text: (also less frequent be in a good, bad, dark, etc. space)
variants.html: (also less frequent be in a good, bad, dark, etc. space)

senses.definition: to be feeling happy, sad, worried, etc. about something; to be in a good, bad, unhappy, etc. state

examples.en: I'm happy now. I'm in a good place.
Me and Ed are in a good space right now.
The economy is in a better place than it was a year ago.
He was in a bad place, mentally and emotionally.
She was in a dark place after her mother's death.

idioms.word: be in the right place at the right time

senses.definition: to be able to take advantage of opportunities when they come

examples.en: His success was down to being in the right place at the right time.

idioms.word: (caught/stuck) between a rock and a hard place

senses.definition: in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to be in somebody else’s situation

examples.en: I'm perfectly happy—I wouldn't change places with anyone.

senses.definition: if something complicated or difficult to understand falls or slots into place, it becomes organized or clear in your mind

examples.en: Then I found his diary and it all began to fall into place.

idioms.word: friends, people, etc. in high places

senses.definition: friends, people, etc. in positions of power and influence

examples.en: He has friends in high places.

senses.definition: to be replaced by somebody/something

examples.en: Houses and factories gave place to open fields as the train gathered speed.

idioms.word: have/hold a place in somebody's heart

senses.definition: to be very dear to somebody

examples.en: He'll always have a place in my heart.

idioms.word: somebody’s heart is in the right place

senses.definition: used to say that somebody’s intentions are kind and sincere even though they sometimes do the wrong thing

idioms.word: if I was/were in your place

senses.definition: used to introduce a piece of advice you are giving to somebody

examples.en: If I were in your place, I'd resign immediately.

senses.definition: used at the end of a sentence to talk about why something was done or whether it should have been done or not

examples.en: I still don't understand why you chose that name in the first place.
I should never have taken that job in the first place.

idioms.word: in the first, second, etc. place

senses.definition: used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce the different points you are making in an argument

examples.en: Well, in the first place he has all the right qualifications.

senses.definition: in my, your, etc. situation

examples.en: I wouldn't like to be in your place.

senses.definition: in the correct position; ready for something

examples.en: Carefully lay each slab in place.
He allowed the curtain to swish back into place.

senses.definition: working or ready to work

examples.en: All the arrangements are now in place for their visit.
How long has the import ban been in place?

variants.text: (also on the spot British and North American English)
variants.html: (also on the spot British and North American English)

senses.definition: in one exact place, without moving in any direction

examples.en: Running in place is good exercise.

idioms.word: in (the) place of somebody/something | in somebody’s/something’s place

senses.definition: instead of somebody/something

examples.en: You can use milk in place of cream in this recipe.
He was unable to come to the ceremony, but he sent his son to accept the award in his place.

idioms.word: lightning never strikes (in the same place) twice

senses.definition: an unusual or unpleasant event is not likely to happen in the same place or to the same people twice

idioms.word: not have a hair out of place

senses.definition: to look extremely clean and neat
not in the correct place

examples.en: Some of these files seem to be out of place.

senses.definition: not suitable for a particular situation

examples.en: Her remarks were out of place.
I felt completely out of place among all these successful people.

senses.definition: a position in which you are comfortable or have an advantage over other people
the position in which something is most easily seen, that is given to the most important thing in a particular group

examples.en: The photo was given pride of place on the mantelpiece.

senses.definition: to make somebody feel stupid or embarrassed for showing too much confidence

examples.en: At first she tried to take charge of the meeting but I soon put her in her place.

idioms.word: put yourself in somebody else’s/somebody’s place

senses.definition: to imagine that you are in somebody else’s situation

examples.en: Of course I was upset—just put yourself in my place.

senses.definition: to stay indoors during an emergency in order to protect yourself and others

examples.en: Residents of the city have been ordered to shelter in place for at least the next three weeks.

senses.definition: to happen, especially after previously being arranged or planned

examples.en: The film festival takes place in October.
We may never discover what took place that night.

idioms.word: take somebody’s/something’s place | take the place of somebody/something

senses.definition: to replace somebody/something

examples.en: She couldn't attend the meeting so her assistant took her place.
Computers have taken the place of typewriters in most offices.

senses.definition: to go to the physical position that is necessary for an activity

examples.en: Take your places for dinner.

senses.definition: to take or accept the status in society that is correct or that you deserve
to put something in a particular place, especially when you do it carefully or deliberately

examples.en: He placed his hand on her shoulder.
A bomb had been placed under the seat.
The parking areas in the town are few, but strategically placed.

senses.definition: used to express the attitude somebody has towards something/somebody

examples.en: They place a high value on punctuality.
Great importance is placed on education.
The blame was placed squarely on the doctor.
We have always placed emphasis on delivering customer satisfaction.

senses.definition: to give instructions about something or make a request for something to happen

examples.en: to place an order/a bet
We placed an advertisement for the position on an online jobs portal.

senses.definition: to put somebody/yourself in a particular situation

examples.en: to place somebody in command
She was placed in the care of an uncle.
His resignation placed us in a difficult position.
The job places great demands on me.
He has placed himself above party politics.
highly placed officials in the government
You will be placed on the waiting list.
to place restrictions/a burden on somebody
They are placing lives at risk.

senses.definition: to find a suitable job, home, etc. for somebody

examples.en: The agency placed about 2 000 secretaries last year.
The children were placed with foster parents.
children who are difficult to place in foster homes

senses.definition: to decide that somebody/something has a particular position or rank compared with other people or things

examples.en: I would place her among the top five tennis players in the world.
Nursing attracts people who place relationships high on their list of priorities.

senses.definition: used to describe a person, a team, a horse, etc. finishing in a particular position in a race

examples.en: He was placed fifth in last Saturday's race.
My horse has been placed several times (= it was among the first three or four to finish the race).
His horse placed in the last race (= it was among the first three to finish the race, usually in second place).

senses.definition: to recognize somebody/something and be able to identify them/it

examples.en: I've seen her before but I just can't place her.
His accent was impossible to place.

idioms.word: be well, ideally, uniquely, better, etc. placed for something/to do something

senses.definition: to be in a good, very good, etc. position or have a good, etc. opportunity to do something

examples.en: Engineering graduates are well placed for a wide range of jobs.
The company is ideally placed to take advantage of the new legislation.
The company is ideally placed to win the contract.

senses.definition: to be located in a pleasant or convenient place

examples.en: The hotel is well placed for restaurants, bars and clubs.

idioms.word: put/place something on (the) record | be/go on (the) record (as saying…)

senses.definition: to say something publicly or officially so that it may be written down and repeated

examples.en: He didn't want to go on the record as either praising or criticizing the proposal.
I should like to place on record my sincere thanks to all those who have given support.

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is particularly important or valuable

examples.en: The company places a high premium on initiative.
They put a high premium on customer loyalty.

idioms.word: to put/place somebody on a pedestal

senses.definition: to admire somebody so much that you do not see their faults
the act of finding somebody a suitable job or place to live

examples.en: a job placement service
placement with a foster family

senses.definition: a job, often as part of a course of study, where you get some experience of a particular kind of work

examples.en: The course includes a placement in Year 3.
The third year is spent on placement in selected companies.

senses.definition: the act of placing something somewhere

examples.en: This procedure ensures correct placement of the catheter.

senses.definition: not decorated or complicated; simple

examples.en: a plain but elegant dress
plain food
The interior of the church was plain and simple.
plain yogurt (= without sugar or fruit)

senses.definition: without marks or a pattern on it

examples.en: covers in plain or printed cotton
Write on plain paper (= without lines).

senses.definition: easy to see or understand

examples.en: He made it plain that we should leave.
She made her annoyance plain.
The facts were plain to see.
It was a rip-off, plain and simple.
It is all very plain to me.
It was plain that she wanted to leave.

examples.cf: it is plain (to somebody) how, what, etc….
examples.en: It was plain to everyone just how dangerous the site could be.
What is quite plain from the evidence before me is (that) the figures are false.

senses.definition: not trying to trick anyone; honest and direct

examples.en: The plain fact is that nobody really knows.
a politician with a reputation for plain speaking
a plain, straightforward sort of man

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is very ordinary, not special in any way

examples.en: You don't need any special skills for this job, just plain common sense.

senses.definition: not beautiful or attractive

examples.en: I've always had quite a plain face.
a rather plain woman

senses.definition: describing a simple stitch used in knitting

variants.html: (North American English be clear/smooth sailing)

senses.definition: to be simple and free from trouble
simply and clearly expressed, without using technical language

examples.en: a document written in plain English
If you could put it in plain English I might be able to understand.
Teachers should encourage students to write in plain English.

idioms.word: (as) plain as a pikestaff | (as) plain as day | (as) plain as the nose on your face

senses.definition: very obvious

variants.html: (also plains [plural])

senses.definition: a large area of flat land

examples.en: the flat coastal plain of Thassos
Millions of buffalo used to roam freely across the Great Plains.

senses.definition: used to emphasize how bad, stupid, etc. something is

examples.en: plain stupid/wrong

senses.definition: something that you intend to do or achieve

examples.en: Do you have any plans for the summer?

Your best plan (= the best thing to do) would be to go by car.

retirement/travel/wedding plans

senses.definition: a set of things to do in order to achieve something, especially one that has been considered in detail in advance

examples.en: an action plan
a plan of action
a development/management plan
a five-point plan
a three-year plan
These ambitious plans were continually revised.
The company has developed a five-year strategic plan.
We need to make plans for the future.
Both sides agreed to a detailed plan for keeping the peace.
contingency plans for dealing with an epidemic
The government has announced plans to create one million new training places.
to develop/devise a plan
to unveil/outline a plan
to implement a plan
to stick to/change a plan
Let's hope everything will go according to plan.
Under this plan, 98% of all Americans will get a tax cut.

senses.definition: a detailed map of a building, town, etc.

examples.en: Do you have a plan of the museum?

senses.definition: a detailed drawing of a machine, building, etc. that shows its size, shape and measurements

examples.en: The original plans of the building have not survived.

Plans for our extension have been submitted for approval.

senses.definition: a diagram that shows how something will be arranged

examples.en: a seating plan (= showing where each person will sit, for example at a dinner)
a floor plan (= showing how furniture is arranged)

senses.definition: a way of investing money for the future or buying insurance for something

examples.en: a savings plan
a health plan

senses.definition: to think of something you can do to solve a problem or make something happen

examples.en: It's going to be difficult to find the time but I'll make a plan.

senses.definition: used to agree to a suggestion that you think is good
to make detailed arrangements for something you want to do in the future

examples.en: to plan a trip
to plan a wedding/holiday/party

We planned the day down to the last detail.
Everything went exactly as planned.
The whole event had been carefully/meticulously planned.

It's never too early to start planning for the future.

senses.definition: to intend or expect to do something

examples.en: We hadn't planned on going anywhere this evening.

senses.definition: to make a design or an outline for something

examples.en: to plan an essay/a garden

variants.html: (British English also aeroplane)

senses.definition: a flying vehicle with wings and one or more engines

examples.en: a passenger/fighter/military/private plane

a plane ticket
a plane crash
a plane ride/flight/journey

senses.definition: any flat or level surface, or an imaginary flat surface through or joining material objects

examples.en: the horizontal/vertical plane

senses.definition: a level of thought, existence or development

examples.en: With practice, an athlete can reach a higher plane of achievement.

completely flat; level

examples.en: a plane surface

senses.definition: to make a piece of wood smoother or flatter with a plane

examples.en: Plane the surface down first.
Then plane the wood smooth.

senses.definition: to fly without moving the wings, especially high up in the air
to move quickly across water, only just touching the surface

examples.en: The boat planed past in clouds of spray.

senses.definition: a large round object in space that moves around a star (such as the sun) and receives light from it

senses.definition: used to mean ‘the world’, especially when talking about the environment

examples.en: the battle to save the planet

idioms.word: to be on another planet | what planet is somebody on?

senses.definition: used to suggest that somebody’s ideas are not realistic or practical

examples.en: He thinks being a father is easy. What planet is he on?

senses.definition: the act or process of making plans for something

examples.en: The department is responsible for all financial planning.

examples.en: She now works in urban planning.
to submit a planning application

senses.definition: a living thing that grows in the earth and usually has a stem, leaves and roots, especially one that is smaller than a tree or bush

examples.en: All plants need light and water.
flowering plants
native/medicinal/wild plants

senses.definition: a factory or place where power is produced or an industrial process takes place

examples.en: a nuclear power plant
a processing/manufacturing plant

a water treatment plant
a chemical/steel/coal plant

senses.definition: the large machines that are used in industrial processes

examples.en: The company has been investing in new plant and equipment.

senses.definition: something that somebody has deliberately placed among another person’s clothes or possessions in order to make them appear guilty of a crime

examples.en: He claimed that the drugs found in his house were a plant.

senses.definition: a person who joins a group of criminals or enemies in order to get and secretly report information about their activities
to put plants, seeds, etc. in the ground to grow

examples.en: to plant a tree/seed/crop
to plant and harvest rice

senses.definition: to cover or supply a garden, area of land, etc. with plants

examples.en: The children are planting a garden next to the school.
They have planted five acres of vines.

The field had been ploughed and planted with corn.

senses.definition: to place something or yourself in a particular place or position

examples.en: They planted a flag on the summit.

examples.en: He claims that the drugs were planted on him.

senses.definition: to send somebody to join a group, etc., especially in order to make secret reports on its members

examples.en: The police had planted an informer in the gang.

senses.definition: to make somebody think or believe something, especially without them realizing that you gave them the idea

examples.en: He planted the first seeds of doubt in my mind.

senses.definition: a light strong material that is produced by chemical processes and can be formed into shapes when heated. There are many different types of plastic, used to make different objects and fabrics.

examples.en: The pipes should be made of plastic.
a sheet of clear plastic
the plastic industry
recycled plastic
chairs made from plastic
dashboards moulded in plastic

senses.definition: the science of making plastics
a way of talking about credit cards

examples.en: Do they take plastic?

senses.definition: made of plastic

examples.en: a plastic bag/bottle/cup
recyclable plastic containers

senses.definition: easily formed into different shapes

examples.en: Clay is a plastic substance.

senses.definition: that seems artificial; false; not real or sincere

examples.en: TV game show hosts with their banal remarks and plastic smiles

senses.definition: a flat, usually round, dish that you put food on

examples.en: a plate of sandwiches

senses.definition: a whole main course of a meal, served on one plate

senses.definition: a thin flat piece of metal, used especially to join or make something stronger

examples.en: The tanks were mainly constructed of steel plates.

senses.definition: a flat piece of metal with some information on it, for example somebody’s name

senses.definition: the pieces of metal or plastic at the front and back of a vehicle with numbers and letters on it
ordinary metal that is covered with a thin layer of silver or gold

examples.en: The cutlery is plate, not solid silver.

senses.definition: dishes, bowls, etc. that are made of silver or gold

examples.en: the family plate

senses.definition: one of the thin flat pieces of horn or bone that cover and protect an animal

senses.definition: a sheet of metal, plastic, etc. that has been treated so that words or pictures can be printed from it

examples.en: a printing plate

senses.definition: a thin sheet of glass, metal, etc. that is covered with chemicals so that it reacts to light and can form an image, used in larger or older cameras
a thin piece of plastic with wire or artificial teeth attached to it which fits inside your mouth in order to make your teeth straight

variants.text: (also home plate, home base (both British and North American English))
variants.html: (also home plate, home base (both British and North American English))

senses.definition: the place where the person hitting the ball stands and where they must return to after running around all the bases
a flat dish that is used to collect money from people in a church

idioms.word: hand something to somebody on a plate

senses.definition: to give something to somebody without that person making any effort

idioms.word: have enough/a lot/too much on your plate

senses.definition: to have a lot of work or problems, etc. to deal with

examples.en: It's important for world leaders to step up to the plate and honor their commitments on global warming.

senses.definition: to cover a metal with a thin layer of another metal, especially gold or silver

senses.definition: to serve food on a plate

senses.definition: an opportunity or a place for somebody to express their opinions publicly or make progress in a particular area

senses.definition: a type of shoe with a high, thick sole; the sole on such a shoe

senses.definition: the open part at the back of a double-decker bus where you get on or off

examples.en: You'll have to play inside today.

senses.definition: to use an MP3 player, a CD player, etc. to make it possible to hear a song, an album, a CD, etc.

senses.cf: play a part/role (in something/in doing something)

senses.definition: the activity or operation of something; the influence of something on something else

senses.definition: the possibility of free and easy movement

senses.definition: a light, quick movement that keeps changing

senses.definition: to spend time playing with a toy, game, etc.

senses.definition: inside/outside the area allowed by the rules of the game

senses.definition: to emphasize the importance of a particular fact

senses.definition: to try to obtain something; to do things that are intended to produce a particular result

senses.definition: the humorous use of a word or phrase that can have two different meanings
the stage that has been reached in a process, etc. which has not yet been completed

senses.definition: the score in a sports match, especially in cricket
a person who takes part in a game or sport

senses.definition: a machine for producing the sound or pictures that have been recorded on CDs, etc.

senses.definition: a person who plays a musical instrument

senses.definition: to argue in support of somebody/something

a piece of writing in which the words are chosen for their sound and the images they suggest, not just for their obvious meanings. The words are arranged in separate lines, usually with a repeated rhythm, and often the lines rhyme at the end.

senses.definition: a person who writes poems

senses.definition: a quality of beauty, style and feeling

senses.definition: a thing that somebody says or writes giving their opinion or stating a fact

He's just saying that to prove a point (= to show his idea is right).
OK, you've made your point!

It just isn't true. That's the whole point (= the only important fact).

examples.en: Change the text to 10 point.

senses.definition: to repeat an idea, argument, etc. many times to emphasize it, especially when it has already been mentioned or understood

senses.definition: a clear example of the problem, situation, etc. that is being discussed

senses.definition: the more complicated or detailed aspects of something

idioms.word: if/when it comes to the point

senses.definition: used to say what is true in a situation

senses.definition: to be or make sure you do something because it is important or necessary

senses.definition: a matter about which there may be difference of opinion or a lack of understanding

senses.definition: used to say that something is more important than something else

idioms.word: not to put too fine a point on it

senses.definition: perfect; exactly right for the occasion

senses.definition: a place where you go or a person that you speak to when you are dealing with an organization

senses.definition: a place where a journey starts

senses.definition: a thing that somebody considers to be very important for their honour or reputation

senses.definition: used to say that you accept that somebody else is right when they have disagreed with you or criticized you

senses.definition: to show that you are better than somebody, especially by making clever remarks, for example in an argument

senses.definition: a subject that makes you feel angry or upset when it is mentioned

senses.definition: to a degree that can be described as something

senses.definition: to some extent; to some degree but not completely

senses.definition: the way of printing a document in which the top of the page is one of the shorter sides

examples.en: You can print landscape and portrait pages in the same document.

senses.definition: to show somebody/something in a picture; to describe somebody/something in a piece of writing

examples.en: The painting portrays the duke’s third wife.
He was one of the first to portray animals from the New World.
His war poetry vividly portrays life in the trenches.

senses.definition: to describe or show somebody/something in a particular way, especially when this does not give a complete or accurate impression of what they are like

examples.en: Throughout the trial, he portrayed himself as the victim.

senses.definition: to act a particular role in a film or play

examples.en: Her father will be portrayed by Jim Broadbent.

senses.definition: to create a threat, problem, etc. that has to be dealt with

examples.en: to pose a threat/risk/challenge/danger
the threat posed by terrorism
Obesity poses real risks to health and happiness.
The task poses no special problems.
to pose a hazard/obstacle/barrier

senses.definition: to ask a question, especially one that needs serious thought

examples.en: The new play poses some challenging questions.

senses.definition: to sit or stand in a particular position in order to be painted, drawn or photographed

examples.en: The delegates posed for a group photograph.
They posed briefly for pictures before driving off.
They were only too delighted to pose for the cameras.
He was persuaded to pose for his portrait.

senses.definition: to pretend to be somebody in order to trick other people

examples.en: The gang entered the building posing as workmen.

senses.definition: to dress or behave in a way that is intended to impress other people

examples.en: I saw him out posing in his new sports car.

senses.definition: a particular position in which somebody stands, sits, etc., especially in order to be painted, drawn or photographed

examples.en: He adopted a relaxed pose for the camera.

senses.definition: a way of behaving that is not sincere and is intended to impress or trick people

examples.en: This show of concern is just a pose.

senses.definition: to hold your body in a particular way to create a particular impression

examples.en: to strike a dramatic pose
He strikes an attitude of bravery and lonely defiance.

senses.definition: the place where somebody/something is located

examples.en: Where would be the best position for the lights?
From his position on the cliff top, he had a good view of the harbour.
She looked down over the scene from a raised position.
These plants will grow well in a sheltered position.
The hotel stands in an elevated position looking out over the lake.

senses.definition: the place where somebody/something is meant to be; the correct place

examples.en: He took up his position by the door.
Is everybody in position?
The dancers all got into position.
She was learning to change her hand from first to third position (= on the strings of a violin).

senses.definition: the way in which somebody is sitting or standing, or the way in which something is arranged

examples.en: a sitting/standing/kneeling position
My arms were aching so I shifted (my) position slightly.
The soldiers had to stand for hours without changing position.
Keep the box in an upright position.
Make sure that you are working in a comfortable position.
She moved the seat into a reclining position.

senses.definition: the situation that somebody is in, especially when it affects what they can and cannot do

examples.en: The company's financial position is not certain.
The company hopes to maintain its position as market leader.
What would you do in my position?
This put him and his colleagues in a difficult position.
This recent sale puts us in a strong position.
to be in a position of power/strength/authority

examples.cf: in a position to do something
examples.en: I'm afraid I am not in a position to help you.
You are in no position to complain.

senses.definition: an opinion on or an attitude towards a particular subject

examples.en: She has made her position very clear.
to change/reconsider/shift your position
the party’s position on education reforms
My parents always took the position that early nights meant healthy children.

senses.definition: a person or organization’s level of importance when compared with others

examples.en: the position of women in society
the company’s dominant position in the world market
Atkins occupies a remarkable position in the history of photography.
Wealth and position (= high social status) were not important to her.

senses.definition: a job

examples.en: He held a senior position in a large company.
I should like to apply for the position of Sales Director.
They are advertising for a clinic coordinator and hope to fill the position by June.
We need more women in leadership positions.

senses.definition: a place in a race, competition, or test, when compared to others

examples.en: United's 3–0 win moved them up to third position.

senses.definition: the place where somebody plays and the responsibilities they have in some team games

examples.en: What position does he play?
Nakata had to play out of position when the defender was injured.

senses.definition: a place where a group of people involved in fighting have put men and guns

examples.en: They attacked the enemy positions at dawn.
The defence stuck firmly to its position.

senses.definition: to put somebody/something in a particular position

examples.en: She quickly positioned herself behind the desk.
Large television screens were positioned at either end of the stadium.
Position your hands correctly on the shaft of the club.
The company is now well positioned to compete in foreign markets.

senses.definition: good or useful

examples.en: The tests have so far yielded positive results.
The contributions have a positive impact on the lives of hundreds of children.
Overseas investment has had a positive effect on exports.
His family have been a very positive influence on him.
The only positive outcome of that day was that our country came together.
to make a positive contribution to a discussion

senses.definition: expressing agreement or support

examples.en: It's always nice to get positive feedback.
We've had a very positive response to the idea.
The company expects a positive reaction to these new products.
There were some overwhelmingly positive reviews.
I should probably say something positive.

senses.definition: directed at dealing with something or producing a successful result

examples.en: We must take positive steps to deal with the problem.
In the last few years, positive changes have been made.
It will require positive action by all in the industry.

senses.definition: thinking about what is good in a situation; feeling confident and sure that something good will happen

examples.en: a positive attitude/outlook
the power of positive thinking
She tried to be more positive about her new job.
On the positive side, profits have increased.
The report ended on a positive note.
There were times when it was difficult to remain positive.
Analysts remain positive on the outlook for the shares over the long term.
Another positive sign is that many companies have recently raised their dividend payouts.
The goal was to create a positive image of older workers.

senses.definition: showing clear evidence that a particular substance or medical condition is present

examples.en: a positive pregnancy test
The athlete tested positive for steroids.
If your test results are positive, it means that blood was detected.
to be HIV positive
The test proved positive.

senses.definition: completely sure that something is correct or true

examples.en: I can't be positive about what time it happened.
She was positive that he had been there.
I'm absolutely positive it was him.
‘Are you sure?’ ‘Positive.’

senses.definition: giving clear and definite proof or information

examples.en: The results show a positive correlation between exercise and self-esteem.
We have no positive evidence that she was involved.
This is proof positive that he stole the money.

senses.definition: complete and definite

examples.en: He has a positive genius for upsetting people.
It was a positive miracle that we survived.

senses.definition: expressing something that is true, did happen, etc.; not containing words such as ‘no’, ‘not’, ‘never’, etc.

examples.en: A positive statement has a negative question tag.

senses.definition: greater than zero
containing or producing the type of electricity that is carried by a proton

examples.en: a positive charge
the positive terminal of a battery

senses.definition: a good or useful quality or aspect

examples.en: What are the positives and negatives of going this route?
I get a lot of positives from my job.
The deal is seen as a positive for both companies.

senses.definition: the result of a test or an experiment that shows that a substance or condition is present

examples.en: The result can be a false positive—indicating a problem where none actually exists.

senses.definition: a developed film showing light and dark areas and colours as they actually were, especially one printed from a negative
to have or own something

examples.en: He was charged with possessing a shotgun without a licence.
I'm afraid this is the only suitcase I possess.
The gallery possesses a number of the artist's early works.
Belgium was the first European country to possess a fully fledged rail network.

senses.definition: to have a particular quality or feature

examples.en: I'm afraid he doesn't possess a sense of humour.
workers who possess the requisite skills for the task
He credited her with a maturity she did not possess.
Isaak 's songwriting possesses a timeless quality.
Young adults possess incredible purchasing power.

senses.definition: to have a powerful effect on somebody and control the way that they think, behave, etc.

examples.en: A terrible fear possessed her.
I was possessed by a desire to tell her everything.

senses.definition: to make somebody do something that seems strange or unreasonable

examples.en: What possessed him to say such a thing?

senses.definition: something that you own or have with you at a particular time

examples.en: Prisoners were allowed no personal possessions.
One of Jane's most prized possessions was her photo album.
The ring is one of her most treasured possessions.
Please make sure you have all your possessions with you when leaving the plane.

senses.definition: the state of having or owning something

examples.en: The possession of a passport is essential for foreign travel.
They had exclusive possession of the property as tenants.
On her father's death, she came into possession of (= received) a vast fortune.
You cannot legally take possession of the property (= start using it after buying it) until three weeks after the contract is signed.
The manuscript is just one of the treasures in their possession.
The gang was caught in possession of stolen goods.
drug possession
weapons/firearms possession

senses.definition: the state of having control of the ball

examples.en: to win/get/lose possession of the ball
The home team had most of the possession in the first half.
The team was struggling to retain possession of the ball.

senses.definition: the state of having illegal drugs or weapons with you at a particular time

examples.en: She was charged with possession.
They were charged with unlawful possession of firearms.

senses.definition: a country that is controlled or governed by another country

examples.en: The former colonial possessions are now independent states.
the country's overseas possessions

senses.definition: the situation when somebody’s mind is believed to be controlled by the Devil or by an evil spirit

idioms.word: possession is nine tenths of the law

senses.definition: if you already have or control something, it is difficult for somebody else to take it away from you, even if they have the legal right to it
a thing that may happen or be true; the fact that something might happen or be true, but is not certain

examples.en: Bankruptcy is a real possibility if sales don't improve.
What had seemed impossible now seemed a distinct possibility.
Reaching the final seems a remote possibility.
There's a strong possibility that it will rain.
There is now no possibility that she will make a full recovery.
We cannot exclude the possibility that another person may have been involved.
I have considered the possibility that she is dead.
He refused to rule out the possibility of a tax increase.
There is a real possibility of war.
The company has raised the possibility of legal action.
I am excited about the possibility of going to the Olympics.
This is a one-year appointment, with the possibility of renewal for an additional year.

senses.definition: one of the different things that you can do in a particular situation

examples.en: The possibilities are endless.
Selling the house is just one possibility that is open to us.
We have to investigate every possibility.
Police are considering a wide range of possibilities.
to exhaust all the possibilities
She explored the possibility of studying in the US.

senses.definition: something that gives you a chance to achieve something

examples.en: There are countless possibilities for future research.
The course offers a range of exciting possibilities for developing your skills.
In a bookshop, the possibilities for browsing are endless.
Career possibilities for women are much greater than they were fifty years ago.

senses.definition: if something has possibilities, it can be improved or made successful

examples.en: The house is in a bad state of repair but it has possibilities.
He was the first to see the possibilities of the plan.

senses.definition: possible/not possible

examples.en: A successful outcome is not beyond the realms of possibility.
It is not beyond the bounds of possibility that we'll all meet again one day.

senses.definition: that can be done or achieved

examples.en: New technology has made it possible to communicate more easily.

examples.cf: it is possible to do something
examples.en: It is possible to get there by bus.
It's just not physically possible to finish all this by the end of the week.

examples.cf: it is possible for somebody to do something
examples.en: Would it be possible for me to leave a message for her?
This wouldn't have been possible without you.
I'd like the money back by next week if possible.
Try to avoid losing your temper if at all possible (= if you can).
Use public transport whenever possible (= when you can).
The doctors did all that was humanly possible to save him.
We spent every possible moment on the beach.
Expansion was made possible by the investment of government money.
This film was better than I thought possible.

senses.definition: that might exist or happen but is not certain to

examples.en: the possible side effects of the drug
a possible future president
Frost is possible, although unlikely, at this time of year.
It is quite possible that the river will flood again.
It's just possible that I gave them the wrong directions.
‘You might be wrong, of course!’ ‘It’s possible, but I doubt it.’
With the possible exception of the Beatles, no other band has become so successful so quickly.
‘Do you think he’ll resign?’ ‘Anything’s possible where he’s concerned.’
a possible outcome/effect/consequence
We have to look at every possible scenario.

senses.definition: reasonable or acceptable in a particular situation

examples.en: There are several possible explanations.
Please suggest possible ways in which you would improve the existing program.
a possible solution
One possible cause/reason is…

senses.definition: used after adjectives to emphasize that something is the best, worst, etc. of its type

examples.en: It was the best possible surprise anyone could have given me.
Don't leave your packing until the last possible moment.
Jacobs faces the maximum possible sentence of five years imprisonment.

idioms.word: as quickly, much, soon, etc. as possible

senses.definition: as quickly, much, soon, etc. as you can

examples.en: We will get your order to you as soon as possible.
Try to give as much detail as possible in your answer.
She did as much as possible to help him.

idioms.word: the best/worst of all possible worlds

senses.definition: a situation in which you have all the possible advantages/disadvantages together

examples.en: In the best of all possible worlds, you should be able to develop your career and enjoy a rewarding family life.

idioms.word: the best of both worlds/all possible worlds

senses.definition: the benefits of two or more completely different situations that you can enjoy at the same time

examples.en: If you enjoy the coast and the country, you'll get the best of both worlds on this walk.
Maybe in the best of all possible worlds things would be different.

senses.definition: a situation in which you have all the possible disadvantages at the same time
a person or thing that is suitable for a particular job, purpose, etc. and might be chosen

examples.en: Out of all the people interviewed, there are only five possibles.

senses.definition: used to say that something might exist, happen or be true, but you are not certain

examples.en: It was possibly their worst performance ever.
She found it difficult to get on with her, possibly because of the difference in their ages.
‘Will you be around next week?’ ‘Possibly.’
‘I’m sure he didn’t mean to be rude.’ ‘Quite possibly (= you may be right), but the damage has been done.’
Last year, his mother died, possibly due to heart failure.
a popular but possibly dangerous type of extreme diet

senses.definition: used with can/could to emphasize that you are surprised, annoyed, etc. about something

examples.en: You can't possibly mean that!
How could you possibly think that I had anything to do with it!
He turned out to be the nicest guy you could possibly imagine.
What could possibly go wrong?

senses.definition: used with could to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.en: Could you possibly open that window?

senses.definition: used with can/could to say that somebody will do or has done as much as they can in order to make something happen

examples.en: I will come as soon as I possibly can.
They tried everything they possibly could to improve the situation.
We don’t want these rumours to spread if we can possibly avoid it.
I don't see what more he could possibly do.

senses.definition: used with negatives, especially can't/couldn't, to say strongly that you cannot do something or that something cannot or could not happen or be done

examples.en: I can't possibly tell you that!
You can't possibly carry all those bags.
‘Let me buy it for you.’ ‘That's very kind of you, but I couldn't possibly (= accept).’

senses.definition: after

examples.en: a postgraduate
a post-Impressionist
the post-1945 period

variants.text: (also mail North American English, British English)
variants.html: (also mail North American English, British English)

senses.definition: the official system used for sending and delivering letters, packages, etc.

examples.en: I'll send the original to you by post.
I sent it by first-class post.
I'll put the documents in the post to you tomorrow.
My application got lost in the post.

variants.text: (also mail North American English, British English)
variants.html: (also mail North American English, British English)

senses.definition: letters, packages, etc. that are sent and delivered

examples.en: There was a lot of post this morning.
Have you opened your post yet?

senses.definition: an occasion during the day when letters, etc. are collected or delivered

examples.en: to catch/miss the post
The parcel came in this morning's post.
The form should arrive in the post tomorrow.
Payment should be sent by return of post (= immediately).
Do you get a second post here?

senses.definition: a message sent to a discussion group on the internet; a piece of writing that forms part of a blog

examples.en: I love reading her posts because I learn so much.
They have deleted all my posts.
She wrote a post about the experience on her blog.
This post by Mark Brady is very interesting.
The forum does not allow posts from non-members.

senses.definition: a job, especially an important one in a large organization

examples.en: an academic/a government post
She took up a teaching post at Basle University.
to resign (from)/quit/leave a post
We will be creating 15 new posts next year.
The company has been unable to fill the post.
He has held the post for three years.
She was offered a key post in the new government.
He accepted the post of deputy prime minister.

variants.html: (British English usually posting)

senses.definition: an act of sending somebody to a particular place to do their job, especially for a limited period of time

examples.en: an overseas post
The island is rated by diplomats as a hardship post (= one that people do not like to be sent to because it is not a very comfortable place to live).

senses.definition: the place where somebody, especially a soldier, does their job

examples.en: a police/military/customs post
an observation post
Three soldiers were shot dead at a border post.
The guards were ordered not to leave their posts.

senses.definition: a piece of wood or metal that is set in the ground in a position pointing upwards, especially to support something or to mark a point

examples.en: She tied the dog to a post.
corner posts (= that mark the corners of a sports field)
The team’s ‘net’ was a piece of string tied to two posts.

senses.definition: the place where a race finishes, especially in horse racing

examples.en: The first horse past the post wins the race.
She led for most of the way before being pipped at the post (= beaten at the last moment).

senses.definition: one of the two posts that form part of a goal

examples.en: The ball hit the post and bounced in.
He steered a shot between the goalkeeper and the near post.

idioms.word: be driven, pushed, etc. from pillar to post

senses.definition: to be forced to go from one person or situation to another without achieving anything

examples.en: Morale is very low. People have just had enough of being thrown from pillar to post.

senses.definition: very deaf (= unable to hear anything)

variants.html: (North American English mail)

senses.definition: to send a letter, etc. to somebody by post

examples.en: The cost of posting a letter has gone up again.
Have you posted off your order yet?
Is it OK if I post the documents to you next week?
Is it OK if I post you the documents next week?

variants.html: (North American English mail)

senses.definition: to put a letter, etc. into a postbox

examples.en: Could you post this letter for me?

senses.definition: to put something through a hole into a container

examples.en: Let yourself out and post the keys through the letter box.

senses.definition: to put information or pictures on a website

examples.en: More details will be posted on the website tomorrow.
Many thanks to all who have posted comments.
I'll post some pictures when I get back.
to post a video/photo/message/link
The photos have been provided by fans who post on the message board.
I’ve been posting now and again at ‘British Moneymaker’.

senses.definition: to announce something publicly or officially, especially financial information or a warning

examples.en: The company posted a $1.1 billion loss.
A snow warning was posted for Ohio.
The aircraft and its crew were posted missing.

senses.definition: to send somebody to a place for a period of time as part of their job

examples.en: She's been posted to Washington for two years.
Most of our employees get posted abroad at some stage.
Balden was later posted to Luqa as station commander.

senses.definition: to put somebody, especially a soldier, in a particular place so that they can guard a building or area

examples.en: Guards have been posted along the border.
A police officer was posted outside the door to make sure the suspect didn’t leave the building.

senses.definition: to put a notice, etc. in a public place so that people can see it

examples.en: A copy of the letter was posted on the noticeboard.

senses.definition: to pay money to a court so that a person accused of a crime can go free until their trial

examples.en: She was released after posting $100 cash bond and her driver's license.

senses.definition: to regularly give somebody the most recent information about something and how it is developing

examples.en: I’ll keep you posted on his progress.

senses.definition: a large notice, often with a picture on it, that is put in a public place to advertise something

examples.en: campaign/election posters
a poster campaign (= an attempt to educate people about something by using posters)
a wanted poster (= with a picture of a person that the police are looking for)
They put up a poster advertising the concert.

senses.definition: a large picture that is printed on paper and put on a wall as decoration

examples.en: posters of her favourite bands
a film/movie poster

senses.definition: a person who posts a message on a message board (= a place on a website where people can read or write messages)
to arrange for an event, etc. to take place at a later time or date than originally planned

examples.en: The game has already been postponed three times.
We'll have to postpone the meeting until next week.
They have agreed to postpone repayment of the loan to a future unspecified date.
It was an unpopular decision to postpone building the new hospital.

senses.definition: a deep round container used for cooking things in

examples.en: pots and pans
You'll need a large cooking pot with a tight-fitting lid.

senses.definition: a container made of glass, clay or plastic, used for storing food in

examples.en: a pot of jam
a yoghurt pot

senses.definition: a container of various kinds, made for a particular purpose

examples.en: a coffee pot
a pencil pot
Is there any more tea in the pot?

senses.definition: the amount contained in a pot

examples.en: They drank a pot of coffee.
I had such a craving for marmalade when I was pregnant that I ate a whole pot in one day.

senses.definition: a bowl, etc. that is made by a potter

examples.en: The newly made pots are glazed when they are completely dry.

senses.definition: the total amount of money that is bet in a card game
all the money given by a group of people in order to do something together, for example to buy food, or available for a particular purpose
cannabis (= a drug (illegal in many countries) made from the dried leaves and flowers of the hemp plant, which gives the person smoking it a feeling of being relaxed)

examples.en: pot smoking

senses.definition: a shot that somebody fires without aiming carefully

examples.en: He took a pot at the neighbour's cat with his air rifle.

senses.dis_g: (in the game of billiards, pool or snooker)
senses.definition: the act of hitting a ball into one of the pockets around the edge of the table
a pot belly (= a large stomach that sticks out)
a large prize or reward that somebody hopes for but is unlikely to get
to become much less good because people are not working hard or taking care of things

examples.en: I've lived here for years but the place has gone to pot recently

senses.definition: likely to change; in the process of changing

idioms.word: the pot calling the kettle black

senses.definition: used to say that you should not criticize somebody for a fault that you have yourself
when you take pot luck, you choose something or go somewhere without knowing very much about it, but hope that it will be good, pleasant, etc.

examples.en: It's pot luck whether you get good advice or not.
You're welcome to stay to supper, but you'll have to take pot luck (= eat whatever is available).

senses.definition: a very large amount of money

idioms.word: put a quart into a pint pot

senses.definition: to put something into a space that is too small for it

examples.en: Writing a history of the world in a single volume is like putting a quart into a pint pot.

senses.definition: used to say that when you are impatient for something to happen, time seems to pass very slowly
to put a plant into a flowerpot filled with soil

senses.dis_g: (in the games of billiards, pool and snooker)
senses.definition: to hit a ball into one of the pockets (= holes at the corners and edges of the table)

examples.en: He potted the black to take a 7–3 lead.

senses.definition: to kill an animal or a bird by shooting it
a round white vegetable with a brown or red skin that grows underground as part of a plant also called a potato

examples.en: Will you peel the potatoes for me?
roast/fried potatoes
potato salad
leek and potato soup

senses.definition: that can develop into something or be developed in the future

examples.en: potential customers/buyers/investors/clients
We have compiled a list of 10 potential candidates.
the potential benefits of European integration
potential risks
a potential threat
the potential impact of the latest surge in oil prices
First we need to identify actual and potential problems.
Have you looked into the potential side effects of the treatment?
a potential prime minister
a potential source of conflict

senses.definition: the possibility of something happening or being developed or used

examples.en: the potential for change
The European marketplace offers excellent potential for increasing sales.
the huge potential of the American market
The disease has the potential to cause a global health emergency.

senses.definition: qualities that exist and can be developed

examples.en: All children should be encouraged to realize their full potential.
to reach/fulfil/achieve your potential
an artist of great potential
John shows great potential in the swimming pool.
She has great potential as an artist.
her belief in art's potential as a healing agent
He has the potential to become a world-class musician.
We're looking for a trainee with potential.
The house has a lot of potential.
Zambia has large unexploited tourism potential.

senses.definition: the difference in voltage between two points in an electric field or circuit
used to say that something may develop into something

examples.en: a potentially dangerous situation

variants.html: (also specialist pound sterling)

senses.definition: the unit of money in the UK, worth 100 pence

examples.en: a ten-pound note
a pound coin
I've spent £25 on food today.
What would you do if you won a million pounds?
Total losses were estimated at over three million pounds.
The blaze caused thousands of pounds worth of damage.
He built the business into a multimillion-pound food empire.

senses.definition: the unit of money of several other countries

examples.en: His salary will be about 5  000 Egyptian pounds per month.

senses.definition: the value of the British pound compared with the value of the money of other countries

examples.en: the strength/weakness of the pound against other currencies
The pound fell sharply to a record low against the yen.
The pound closed (= finished the day's trading) slightly down at $1.534.
a run on the pound (= when many people sell pounds and the value of the pound falls)

senses.definition: a unit for measuring weight, equal to 0.454 of a kilogram

examples.en: half a pound of butter
They cost two dollars a pound.
I've lost six and a half pounds since I started my diet.
a bronze sculpture weighing 7,000 pounds
They sell organic black soya beans in 25-pound bags.
The couch potato lifestyle is causing many people to pile on the pounds (= gain weight).
She has shed 30 pounds.

senses.definition: a place where vehicles that have been parked illegally are kept until their owners pay to get them back
a place where dogs that have been found in the street without their owners are kept until their owners claim them

idioms.word: in for a penny, in for a pound

senses.definition: used to say that since you have started to do something, it is worth spending as much time or money as you need to in order to complete it

idioms.word: an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of cure

variants.text: (British English prevention is better than cure)
variants.html: (British English prevention is better than cure)

senses.definition: it is better to stop something bad from happening rather than try to deal with the problems after it has happened

idioms.word: (have, get, want, etc.) your pound of flesh

senses.definition: the full amount that somebody owes you, even if this will cause them trouble or difficulty

examples.en: You’re determined to have your pound of flesh, aren’t you?

senses.definition: to hit something/somebody hard many times, especially in a way that makes a lot of noise

examples.en: Heavy rain pounded on the roof.
All she could hear was the sound of waves pounding against the cliffs.
Someone was pounding at the door.
