senses.definition: an occasion when nobody speaks, although people are aware that there are feelings or thoughts to express

examples.en: There was a pregnant pause before she replied.

senses.definition: an unreasonable dislike of or preference for a person, group, custom, etc., especially when it is based on their race, religion, sex, etc.

examples.en: a victim of racial prejudice
Their decision was based on ignorance and prejudice.
There was often prejudice against people with disabilities.
She admitted to a prejudice in favour of British universities.

senses.definition: without affecting any other legal matter

examples.en: They agreed to pay compensation without prejudice (= without admitting guilt).

senses.definition: to influence somebody so that they have an unfair or unreasonable opinion about somebody/something

examples.en: The prosecution lawyers have been trying to prejudice the jury against her.
Poor handwriting might prejudice people against the applicant.

senses.definition: to have a harmful effect on something

examples.en: Any delay will prejudice the child's welfare.

senses.definition: happening before a more important action or event

examples.en: After a few preliminary remarks he announced the winners.
preliminary results/findings/enquiries
the preliminary rounds of the contest
pilot studies preliminary to a full-scale study

senses.definition: a preliminary is an action or event that is done in preparation for something

examples.en: I'll skip the usual preliminaries and come straight to the point.
England was lucky to get through the preliminaries (= the preliminary stages in a sports competition).
Research will be needed as a preliminary to taking a decision.

senses.definition: most important, famous or successful

examples.en: one of the country’s premier chefs
the Premier League/Division

senses.definition: used especially in newspapers, etc. to mean ‘prime minister’

examples.en: She was sworn in as premier last week.

senses.definition: (in Canada) the first minister of a province or territory

variants.html: (also British English, less frequent premiss)

senses.definition: a statement or an idea that forms the basis for a reasonable line of argument

examples.en: the basic premise of her argument
The argument rests on a false premise.
His reasoning is based on the premise that all people are equally capable of good and evil.
The premise on which they worked was that there would always be enough natural resources to support them.

senses.definition: an amount of money that you pay once or regularly for an insurance policy

examples.en: a monthly premium of £66.25

senses.definition: an extra payment added to the basic rate

examples.en: You have to pay a high premium for express delivery.
A premium of 10 per cent is paid out after 20 years.
He was willing to pay a premium for a house near the sea.
There's a risk premium of probably $10 a barrel built into oil prices.
a premium-rate phone number

senses.definition: if something is at a premium, there is little of it available and it is difficult to get

examples.en: Space is at a premium in a one-bedroomed apartment.
Good student accommodation is at a premium.

senses.definition: at a higher than normal price

examples.en: Shares are selling at a premium.

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is particularly important or valuable

examples.en: The company places a high premium on initiative.
They put a high premium on customer loyalty.

senses.definition: very high (and higher than usual); of high quality

examples.en: premium prices/products
Daytime calls are charged at premium rate.

senses.definition: the act or process of getting ready for something or making something ready

examples.en: food preparation
Preparation for the party started early.
Careful preparation for the exam is essential.
No athlete would dream of entering a big race without adequate preparation.
Did you get any chance to do any preparation?
The third book in the series is currently in preparation.
The team has been training hard in preparation for the big game.
She helped in the preparation of several of his manuscripts.

senses.definition: things that you do to get ready for something or make something ready

examples.en: The country is making preparations for war.
Was going to college a good preparation for your career?
We made preparations to move to new offices.
wedding preparations
She flew in from Paris to oversee the final preparations.

senses.definition: a substance that has been specially prepared for use as a medicine, cosmetic, etc.

examples.en: a pharmaceutical preparation
preparations for the hair and skin

senses.definition: to make something or somebody ready to be used or to do something

examples.en: to prepare a report
A hotel room is being prepared for them.
The college prepares students for a career in business.
The training has prepared me to deal with any medical issue.
We all set about preparing for the party.

senses.definition: to make yourself ready to do something or for something that you expect to happen

examples.en: I had no time to prepare.
The whole class is working hard preparing for the exams.
The police are preparing themselves for trouble at the demonstration.
I had been preparing myself for this moment.
Her condition is not improving as we hoped. You must prepare yourselves for the worst.
As I waited, I closed my eyes to mentally prepare myself.
I was preparing to leave.
The troops prepared themselves to go into battle.

senses.definition: to make food ready to be eaten

examples.en: He was in the kitchen preparing lunch.
to prepare meals/food/dinner

senses.definition: to make a medicine or chemical substance, for example by mixing other substances together

examples.en: remedies prepared from herbal extracts

senses.definition: to make it possible or easier for something to be achieved

examples.en: The committee will prepare the ground for next month's meeting.
Early experiments with rockets prepared the ground for space travel.

senses.definition: ready and able to deal with something

examples.en: We'll be better prepared next time.
When they set out they were well prepared.
I was not prepared for all the problems it caused.
In his new job he must be prepared for anything.
He came prepared with a list of questions.

senses.definition: willing to do something

examples.en: We are not prepared to accept these conditions.
How much are you prepared to pay?

senses.definition: done, made, written, etc. in advance

examples.en: The police officer read out a prepared statement.
I usually buy packs of prepared vegetables to save time.
She's clearly reading from prepared notes.

senses.definition: to tell somebody to take a particular medicine or have a particular treatment; to write a prescription for a particular medicine, etc.

examples.en: Valium is usually prescribed to treat anxiety.
He may be able to prescribe you something for that cough.

senses.dis_g: (of a person or an organization with authority)
senses.definition: to say what should be done or how something should be done

examples.en: The prescribed form must be completed and returned to this office.
Police regulations prescribe that an officer's number must be clearly visible.
The syllabus prescribes precisely which books should be studied.

senses.definition: an official piece of paper on which a doctor writes the type of medicine you should have, and which enables you to get it from a chemist's

examples.en: The doctor gave me a prescription for antibiotics.
Antibiotics are only available on prescription.
Antibiotics are only available by prescription.
They are not available without a prescription.
prescription drugs/medication(s)

senses.definition: medicine that your doctor has ordered for you

examples.en: The pharmacist will make up your prescription.

senses.definition: the act of prescribing medicine

examples.en: The prescription of drugs is a doctor's responsibility.

senses.definition: a plan or a suggestion for making something happen or for improving it

examples.en: a prescription for happiness
Both parties will be outlining their prescription for economic recovery.

senses.definition: the fact of being in a particular place

examples.en: He hardly seemed to notice my presence.
Her presence during the crisis had a calming effect.
Your presence is requested at the meeting.
They married in the presence of their family members.

senses.definition: the fact of being in a particular place or thing

examples.en: The test can identify the presence of abnormalities in the unborn child.
One of the first things I note when I walk into a client's home is the presence or absence of pictures around the room.
The company now has a strong presence in Germany.

senses.definition: a group of people, especially soldiers, who have been sent to a place to deal with a particular situation

examples.en: The government is maintaining a heavy police presence in the area.
The United States has a substantial military presence in the country.

senses.definition: a person or spirit that you cannot see but that you feel is near

examples.en: She felt a presence behind her.

senses.definition: the quality of making a strong impression on other people by the way you talk or behave; a person who has this quality

examples.en: a man of great presence
She has a strong voice but absolutely no stage presence.
She has a great screen presence.
He remained a dominant presence in the art world.

idioms.word: in the presence of somebody | in somebody’s presence

senses.definition: with somebody in the same place

examples.en: The document was signed in the presence of two witnesses.
She asked them not to discuss the matter in her presence.
He should never have made those remarks in your presence.

senses.definition: when something exists in a particular place

examples.en: Litmus paper turns red in the presence of an acid.

senses.definition: to do something to make people very aware of the fact that you are there; to have a strong influence on a group of people or a situation

examples.en: She’s only been here a couple of weeks but she is already making her presence felt.
He certainly made his presence felt in the boardroom.

senses.definition: existing or happening now

examples.en: I am not satisfied with the present situation.
The present study has two main aims.
the present owner of the house
a list of all club members, past and present
We do not have any more information at the present time.
A few brief comments are sufficient for present purposes.
You can’t use it in its present condition.

senses.definition: being in a particular place

examples.en: I wasn’t present when the doctor examined him.
The mistake was obvious to all those present.
There were 200 people present at the meeting.
Most fathers wish to be present at the birth of their child.
Simply to be physically present was all that was required.

senses.definition: existing in a particular place or thing

examples.en: The threat of force was always present.
the ever present risk of pollution
Levels of pollution present in the atmosphere are increasing.
Analysis showed that traces of arsenic were present in the body.

variants.text: (North American English all present and accounted for)
variants.html: (North American English all present and accounted for)

senses.definition: used to say that all the things or people who should be there are now there
used after being rude or critical about somebody to say that the people you are talking to are not included in the criticism

examples.en: The people in this office are so narrow-minded, present company excepted, of course.

senses.definition: a thing that you give to somebody as a gift

examples.en: What can I get him for a birthday present?
Christmas/wedding presents
I want to give you a little present.
He gave her the painting as a present.
We have a present for you.
I still need to buy a present for my boyfriend.
That dress was a present from my sister.

senses.definition: the time now

examples.en: You've got to forget the past and start living in the present.
I'm sorry he's out at present (= now).
The book covers the period from the early 1990s to the present.

senses.definition: the form of a verb that expresses an action that is happening now or at the time of speaking
for now; for a short time

examples.en: This house is big enough for the moment, but we'll have to move if we have children.

senses.definition: for now; for a short time

examples.en: This house is big enough for the present, but we'll have to move if we have children.

idioms.word: (there is) no time like the present

senses.definition: now is the best time to do something, not in the future
to show or offer something for other people to look at or consider

examples.en: Are you presenting a paper at the conference?
She presented some data on the 2024 presidential election.
The paper presents no evidence of a link.
The results presented here confirm our prediction.
Findings are presented in Table 9.
He presents a convincing case.
The committee will present its final report to Parliament in June.
Eight options were presented for consideration.

senses.definition: to give something to somebody, especially formally at a ceremony

examples.en: The local MP will start the race and present the prizes.
Last year she was presented with an award for lifetime achievement.
On his retirement, colleagues presented him with a set of golf clubs.
The sword was presented by the family to the museum.

senses.definition: to show or describe something/somebody in a particular way

examples.en: The company has decided it must present a more modern image.
It is essential that we present a united front (= show that we all agree).
You need to present yourself better.
He likes to present himself as a radical politician.
The press presents this as a kind of victory.
The article presents these proposals as misguided.

senses.definition: to cause something to happen or be experienced

examples.en: The course presents an excellent learning opportunity.
Freezing temperatures can present problems.
Each year has presented slightly different challenges.
Use of these chemicals may present a fire risk.
Irradiation presents environmental dangers.
None of these parasites presents a threat to human health.
Your request shouldn't present us with any problems.
I was presented with the opportunity to play abroad.

senses.definition: to suddenly happen or become available

examples.en: One major problem did present itself, though.
As soon as the opportunity presented itself, she would get another job.
Thankfully, a solution presented itself to him surprisingly soon.

senses.definition: to appear in a radio or television programme and introduce the different items in it

examples.en: She used to present a gardening programme on TV.

senses.definition: to produce a show, play, broadcast, etc. for the public

examples.en: Compass Theatre Company presents a new production of ‘King Lear’.
The string orchestra of the Music School of Lemgo will present a concert in the Guildhall.

senses.definition: to introduce somebody formally, especially to somebody of higher rank or status

examples.en: May I present my fiancé to you?

senses.cf: present yourself at, for, in, etc.
senses.definition: to officially appear somewhere

examples.en: You will be asked to present yourself for interview.
She was ordered to present herself in court on 20 May.

senses.definition: to offer or express something in speech or writing

examples.en: Please allow me to present my apologies.

senses.definition: to give somebody a cheque or bill that they should pay

examples.en: A cheque presented by Mr Jackson was returned by the bank.
The builders presented a bill for several hundred pounds.

senses.definition: to have or show particular symptoms

examples.en: The patient presented with a chest complaint.
This illness rarely presents as a chest wall tumour in young patients.
All these patients presented a chief complaint of frequent headaches.

senses.definition: to hold a rifle straight upwards in front of the body as a mark of respect
a meeting at which something, especially a new product or idea, or piece of work, is shown to a group of people

examples.en: The sales manager will give a presentation on the new products.
Several speakers will be making short presentations.
The conference will begin with a keynote presentation by a leading industry figure.
a slide/video/multimedia presentation

senses.definition: the act of showing something or of giving something to somebody

examples.en: The trial was adjourned following the presentation of new evidence to the court.
The presentation of prizes began after the speeches.
The Mayor will make the presentation (= hand over the gift) herself.
Members will be admitted on presentation of a membership card.
a presentation copy (= a free book given by the author or publisher)
a presentation ceremony/evening

senses.definition: the way in which something is offered, shown, explained, etc. to others

examples.en: Improving the product's presentation (= the way it is wrapped, advertised, etc.) should increase sales.
I admire the clear, logical presentation of her arguments.
The main emphasis of the training will be on presentation skills.

senses.definition: the series of computer slides (= images) that are shown with the talk when somebody gives a presentation at a meeting

examples.en: I've put my presentation on a memory stick.

senses.definition: a ceremony or formal occasion during which a gift or prize is given

examples.en: the school's annual presentation evening

senses.definition: a performance of a play, etc. in a theatre
the position in which a baby is lying in the mother’s body just before birth
at the time you are speaking or writing; now

examples.en: The crime is presently being investigated by the police.
These are the courses presently available.

senses.definition: used to show that something happened after a short time

examples.en: Presently, the door opened again and three men stepped out.

senses.definition: used to show that something will happen soon

examples.en: She'll be here presently.

senses.definition: the act of keeping something in its original state or in good condition

examples.en: building/environmental/food preservation
a preservation group/society

senses.definition: the act of making sure that something is kept

examples.en: The central issue in the strike was the preservation of jobs.

senses.definition: the degree to which something has not been changed or damaged by age, weather, etc.

examples.en: The paintings were in an excellent state of preservation.

senses.definition: to keep a particular quality, feature, etc.; to make sure that something is kept

examples.en: He was anxious to preserve his reputation.
Efforts to preserve the peace have failed.
She managed to preserve her sense of humour under very trying circumstances.
He was insistent on preserving the integrity of the brand.

senses.definition: to keep something in its original state in good condition

examples.en: a perfectly preserved 14th-century house
Is he really 60? He's remarkably well preserved.
We need knowledgeable gallery curators to preserve great masterpieces for posterity.
This vase has been preserved intact.

senses.definition: to prevent something, especially food, from decaying (= being destroyed by natural processes) by treating it in a particular way

examples.en: Wax polish preserves wood and leather.
preserved lemons
olives preserved in brine
an attempt to preserve the corpse from decomposition

senses.definition: to keep somebody/something alive, or safe from harm or danger

examples.en: The society was set up to preserve endangered species from extinction.

senses.definition: an activity, a job, an interest, etc. that is thought to be suitable for one particular person or group of people

examples.en: Football is no longer the preserve of men.
I began my career in the days when nursing was a female preserve.
Higher education is no longer the preserve of the wealthy.

senses.definition: a type of jam made by boiling fruit with a large amount of sugar
a type of pickle made by cooking vegetables with salt or vinegar

variants.text: (also reserve British and North American English)
variants.html: (also reserve British and North American English)

senses.definition: a piece of land that is a protected area for animals, plants, etc.
an area of private land or water where animals and fish are kept for people to hunt

examples.en: He bought a 171-acre hunting preserve in upstate New York.

senses.definition: to lead or be in charge of a meeting, ceremony, etc.

examples.en: the presiding judge
They asked if I would preside at the committee meeting.
The party presided over one of the worst economic declines in the country's history (= it was in power when the decline happened).

senses.definition: the job of being president of a country or an organization; the period of time somebody holds this job

examples.en: the current holder of the EU presidency
She hopes to be the first woman elected to the presidency of the United States.
He was a White House official during the Biden presidency.

senses.definition: the leader of a republic, for example the US

examples.en: Several presidents attended the funeral.
the President of the United States
President Biden visited the country twice.
Do you have any comment, Mr President?
France elected a new president in 2017.
Ford became president following Nixon's resignation.
She should run for president.
the former South African president, Nelson Mandela
He was sworn in as President on August 31.

senses.definition: the person in charge of some organizations, clubs, colleges, etc.

examples.en: to be made president of the students’ union
She travels extensively in her role as President of the World Wide Fund for Nature.

senses.definition: the person in charge of a bank or a commercial organization

examples.en: the bank president
the president of Columbia Pictures

senses.definition: connected with the position or activities of a president

examples.en: a presidential campaign/candidate/election
a presidential system of government
a presidential year (= one in which the people vote for the next president of the country)

senses.definition: newspapers and magazines

examples.en: the local/national/foreign press
the popular/tabloid press (= newspapers with a lot of pictures and stories about famous people)
the music/sporting press (= newspapers and magazines about music/sport)
The mainstream press is/are ignoring this story.
Unlike the American, the British press operates on a national scale.
The case has been widely reported in the press.
the freedom of the Press/press freedom (= the freedom to report any events and express opinions)
The event is bound to attract wide press coverage (= it will be written about in many newspapers).
According to French press reports, three people have been killed.
a White House press briefing

variants.html: the press, the Press

senses.definition: the journalists and photographers who work for newspapers and magazines

examples.en: The Press was/were not allowed to attend the trial.
She has been harassed by the press, who desperately need a story.
He told the press that there had been ‘further progress’.
She told them not to talk to the press.

senses.definition: the type or amount of reports that newspapers write about somebody/something

examples.en: The airline has had a bad press recently (= journalists have written unpleasant things about it).
The demonstration got very little press.
His latest novel didn't get (a) very good press (= was not praised in the media).

senses.definition: a machine for printing books, newspapers, etc.; the process of printing them

examples.en: We were able to watch the books rolling off the presses.
These prices are correct at the time of going to press.
a story that is hot off the press (= has just appeared in the newspapers)

senses.definition: a business that prints and publishes books

examples.en: Oxford University Press

senses.definition: a piece of equipment that is used for creating pressure on things, to make them flat or to get liquid from them

examples.en: a trouser press
an olive press

senses.definition: an act of pushing something with your hand or with a tool that you are holding

examples.en: He gave the bell another press.
Those shirts need a press (= with an iron).

senses.definition: a large number of people or things competing for space or movement

examples.en: the press of bodies all moving the same way
Among the press of cars he glimpsed a taxi.

senses.definition: a large cupboard, usually with shelves, for holding clothes, books, etc.
to push part of a device, etc. in order to make it work

examples.en: to press a button/key
He pressed the lid firmly shut.
Press here to open.
She pressed down hard on the gas pedal.

senses.definition: to push something closely against something; to be pushed in this way

examples.en: She pressed her face against the window.
He pressed a handkerchief to his nose.
She pressed her lips together.
Her lips softly pressed my cheek.
His body was pressing against hers.
She pressed down harder on the paper.

senses.definition: to put something in a place by pushing it

examples.en: He pressed a coin into her hand and moved on.
She pressed a finger into the dough.

senses.definition: to put gentle pressure on somebody’s hand or arm, especially to show care or kind feelings

examples.en: He gently pressed her arm, then left.

senses.definition: to move in the direction mentioned by pushing

examples.en: The photographers pressed around the royal visitors.
A host of unwelcome thoughts were pressing in on him.
The crowd pressed forward.

senses.definition: to make strong efforts to persuade or force somebody to do something

examples.en: If pressed, he will admit that he knew about the affair.
The bank is pressing us for repayment of the loan.
They are pressing us to make a quick decision.
Don't let yourself be pressed into doing something you don't like.
I did not press him further on the issue.
‘Are you sure?’ she pressed gently.

senses.definition: to express or repeat something with force

examples.en: I don't want to press the point, but you do owe me $200.
She is still pressing her claim for compensation.
They were determined to press their case at the highest level.

senses.definition: to make something flat or smooth by using force or putting something heavy on top

examples.en: The easiest way to press flowers is between the pages of a book.
Press the soil flat with the back of a spade.

senses.definition: to make clothes smooth using a hot iron

examples.en: My suit needs pressing.
his immaculately pressed suit

senses.definition: to get the juice out of fruit or vegetables by using force or weight
to make something from a material, using pressure

examples.en: to press a CD
The car bodies are pressed out of sheets of metal.

senses.definition: to accuse somebody formally of a crime so that there can be a trial in court

examples.en: Police have brought a charge of dangerous driving against the man.
Many victims of crime are reluctant to press charges against their attackers.
She laid charges against the firm for not complying with the regulations.

variants.text: (also push all the (right) buttons British and North American English)
variants.html: (also push all the (right) buttons British and North American English)

senses.definition: to do exactly the right things to please somebody

examples.en: a new satirical comedy show that presses all the right buttons

senses.definition: to say hello to people by shaking hands
to get as much advantage as possible from a situation by attacking or arguing in a determined way

examples.en: to press home an attack/an argument/a point
Simon saw she was hesitating and pressed home his advantage.

senses.definition: to use somebody/something for a purpose that they were not trained or intended for because there is nobody or nothing else available

examples.en: Every type of boat was pressed into service to rescue passengers from the sinking ferry.

senses.definition: to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you

examples.en: The prime minister pressed the panic button yesterday as Britain’s economy plunged deeper into crisis.

senses.definition: to push the reset button on a machine or device

examples.en: When the game is over, press reset to start a new game.

senses.definition: to make an important change in your life, career, etc. by starting again with a fresh approach

examples.en: Working from home during Covid gave many people a chance to press reset and make changes in their lives.

senses.definition: the act of trying to persuade or to force somebody to do something

examples.en: The pressure for change continued to mount.
We are determined to keep up the pressure on the other member states.

examples.cf: pressure on somebody to do something
examples.en: There is intense pressure on her to resign.
In every society there is strong pressure to conform.
Do you feel any pressure to dress in a certain way?
We must bring pressure to bear on our government to reverse this decision.
The company is facing increasing pressure from shareholders
The government eventually bowed to popular pressure (= they agreed to do what people were trying to get them to do).

senses.definition: difficulties and worries that are caused by the need to achieve or to behave in a particular way

examples.en: You need to be able to handle pressure in this job.
She was unable to attend because of the pressure of work.
How can anyone enjoy the pressures of city life?
The economic pressures on small businesses are intense.

senses.definition: the force or weight with which something presses against something else

examples.en: The nurse applied pressure to his arm to stop the bleeding.
The barriers gave way under the pressure of the crowd.
Last year he had brain surgery to relieve pressure from a blood clot.

senses.definition: the force produced by a particular amount of gas or liquid in a container or a limited space; the amount of this

examples.en: air/water pressure
Check the tyre pressure (= the amount of air in a tyre) regularly.
a pressure gauge (= an instrument used for measuring the pressure of a liquid or a gas)

senses.definition: the effect that something has on the way a situation develops, especially when this causes problems

examples.en: This puts upward pressure on prices.
The high unemployment rate was exerting downward pressure on wage growth.
These measures are intended to relieve the pressure on the prison system.
They raised the starting threshold for income tax to ease the pressure on family budgets.

senses.definition: the force of the atmosphere on the earth’s surface

examples.en: A band of high/low pressure is moving across the country.

idioms.word: put pressure on somebody (to do something)

senses.definition: to force or to try to persuade somebody to do something

examples.en: Advertisements put pressure on girls to be thin.

senses.definition: if a liquid or a gas is kept under pressure, it is forced into a container so that when the container is opened, the liquid or gas escapes quickly

examples.en: Draught beer is pumped out of the barrel under pressure.

senses.definition: being forced to do something

examples.en: The director is under increasing pressure to resign.
Hospital staff are coming under pressure to work longer hours.

senses.definition: made to feel anxious about something you have to do

examples.en: The team performs well under pressure.
He's felt under pressure since his wife had the operation.

variants.html: (British English also pressurize)

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to do something, especially by making them feel that they have to or should do it

examples.en: No one has the right to pressure you. You can always say no.
Don't let yourself be pressured into making a hasty decision.
His father pressured him to accept a job in the bank.

senses.definition: respected and admired as very important or of very high quality

examples.en: a prestigious award
a highly prestigious university
My parents wanted me to go to a more prestigious university.
the city’s most prestigious and exclusive hotel
The Gold Cup is one of the most prestigious events in the racing calendar.

senses.definition: used to say that you think that something is probably true

examples.en: Presumably this is where the accident happened.
You'll be taking the car, presumably?
I couldn't concentrate, presumably because I was so tired.
Presumably you’ll be leaving the children at home.

senses.definition: to suppose that something is true, although you do not have actual proof

examples.en: They are very expensive, I presume?
‘Is he still abroad?’ ‘I presume so.’
I presumed (that) he understood the rules.
Little is known of the youngest son; it is presumed that he died young.
I presumed him to be her husband.

senses.definition: to accept that something is true until it is shown not to be true, especially in court

examples.en: Twelve passengers are missing, presumed dead.
In English law, a person is presumed innocent until proved guilty.
We must presume innocence until we have proof of guilt.
We must presume them to be innocent until we have proof of guilt.

senses.definition: to accept something as true or existing and to act on that basis

examples.en: The course seems to presume some previous knowledge of the subject.

senses.definition: to behave in a way that shows a lack of respect by doing something that you have no right to do

examples.en: I wouldn't presume to tell you how to run your own business.

senses.definition: to behave in a particular way, in order to make other people believe something that is not true

examples.en: I'm tired of having to pretend all the time.
Of course I was wrong; it would be hypocritical to pretend otherwise.
He pretended to his family that everything was fine.
We pretended (that) nothing had happened.
She pretended (that) she was his niece.
I pretended to be asleep.
He pretended not to notice.
She didn't love him, though she pretended to.
She pretended an interest she did not feel.

senses.definition: to imagine that something is true as part of a game

examples.en: They didn't have any real money so they had to pretend.
Let’s pretend (that) we’re astronauts.

senses.definition: to claim to be, do or have something, especially when this is not true

examples.en: I can't pretend to any great musical talent.
I don’t pretend (that) I know much about the subject, but…
The book doesn't pretend to be a great work of literature.

senses.definition: not real, imaginary

examples.en: pretend cakes

senses.definition: to some extent; fairly

examples.en: The game was pretty good.
I'm pretty sure I'll be going.
It's pretty hard to explain.
I'm going to have to find a new apartment pretty soon.

senses.definition: very

examples.en: That performance was pretty impressive.
Things are looking pretty good!
The idea sounds pretty cool.
We were pretty disappointed with the quality of the food.

senses.definition: to be in a good situation, especially when others are not

examples.en: With profits at record levels, the company’s certainly sitting pretty this year.

variants.html: (British English also pretty nearly)

senses.definition: almost; almost completely

examples.en: One dog looks pretty much like another to me.
He goes out pretty well every night.
The first stage is pretty near finished.

senses.dis_g: (used most often about a woman or girl)
senses.definition: attractive without being very beautiful

examples.en: a pretty face
a very pretty child
You look so pretty in that dress!
She's very attractive, though not conventionally pretty.

senses.definition: attractive and pleasant to look at or to listen to without being large, beautiful or impressive

examples.en: pretty clothes
a pretty garden
Lydia—what a pretty name!
That's a pretty flower—what's it called?
The canal looked prettiest at night.
He was hired to make the company pretty and then sell it off.

senses.definition: very pretty

examples.en: She’s as pretty as a picture.

variants.html: (also come to such a pass)

senses.definition: to reach a sad or difficult state

examples.en: I never thought things would come to this pretty pass.
Things have come to a pretty pass when we can’t afford to pay the heating bills!

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you have particular skills or qualities

examples.en: ‘I didn't know you could play the piano.’ ‘I'm not just a pretty face, you know!’

senses.definition: not pleasant to look at

examples.en: You should have seen him in his swimming trunks—not a pretty sight!

senses.definition: a lot of money

examples.en: I bet that cost you a pretty penny.

senses.definition: to exist or be very common at a particular time or in a particular place

examples.en: We were horrified at the conditions prevailing in local prisons.
Those beliefs still prevail among certain social groups.

senses.definition: to be accepted, especially after a struggle or an argument

examples.en: Justice will prevail over tyranny.
Fortunately, common sense prevailed.

senses.definition: to defeat an opponent, especially after a long struggle

examples.en: In a one-sided final, Spain prevailed against title-holder Croatia 40–34.
They wasted two penalties but still prevailed 2–1.

senses.definition: the fact of existing or being very common at a particular time or in a particular place

examples.en: an increase in the prevalence of obesity in many countries

senses.definition: to stop somebody from doing something; to stop something from happening

examples.en: The accident could have been prevented.
Maddie would have joined the army if an injury had not prevented her.
The government took steps to prevent a scandal.
He is prevented by law from holding a licence.
Nothing would prevent him from speaking out against injustice.
Nothing would prevent him speaking out against injustice.

senses.definition: the act of stopping something bad from happening

examples.en: accident/crime prevention
the prevention of disease
a fire prevention officer
a diabetes prevention programme

variants.text: (US English an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of cure)
variants.html: (US English an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of cure)

senses.definition: it is better to stop something bad from happening rather than try to deal with the problems after it has happened

examples.en: Prevention is better than cure, so start looking after your heart now.
Prevention is better than cure, so start taking care of yourself.

senses.definition: happening or existing before the event or object that you are talking about

examples.en: No previous experience is necessary for this job.
The car has had only one previous owner.
She is his daughter from a previous marriage.
I was unable to attend because of a previous engagement.
The judge will take into consideration any previous convictions.
We dealt with this in a previous chapter.
We had met on two previous occasions.
Most previous studies have focused on the elderly.
Today's teens are more health conscious than previous generations.

senses.definition: immediately before the time you are talking about

examples.en: the previous year/month/week/night
I couldn't believe it when I heard the news. I'd only seen him the previous day.
He went jogging on Friday, despite the doctor’s warnings the previous day.

senses.definition: at a time before the time that you are talking about

examples.en: The building had previously been used as a hotel.
As previously reported, the couple separated in May.
The book contains a number of photographs not previously published.
I had visited them three days previously.
a previously unknown species

senses.definition: an animal, a bird, etc. that is hunted, killed and eaten by another

examples.en: The lion will often stalk its prey for hours.
birds of prey (= birds that kill for food)

senses.definition: a person who is harmed or tricked by somebody, especially for dishonest purposes

examples.en: Socially isolated young people are easy prey for extremists.

senses.definition: to be killed and eaten by another animal or bird

examples.en: Many small birds and rodents fall prey to the domestic cat.

senses.definition: to be harmed or affected by something bad

examples.en: Since the attack, he had fallen prey to irrational fears.
She knew she must not fall prey to his charm.
The new government has fallen prey to corruption and fraud.

senses.definition: to make somebody think and worry about it all the time

examples.en: The thought that he could have helped more preyed on his mind.
It's been preying on my mind ever since it happened.

senses.definition: the amount of money that you have to pay for something

examples.en: Boat for sale, price £8 000
house/oil/share prices
rising/falling prices
to increase/lower/reduce prices
We will have to raise ticket prices.
The company has announced that it is cutting prices.
In the past year, house prices have fallen.
The price of crude oil has risen over the last few months.
to charge a high/reasonable/low price for something
to pay/charge a price for something
He managed to get a good price for the car.
Retail prices for food at the supermarket rose just under two per cent in the first quarter.
Can you give me a price for the work (= tell me how much you will charge)?
Children over five must pay (the) full price for the ticket.
I'm only buying it if it's the right price (= a price that I think is reasonable).
How much are these? They don't have a price on them.
Most new technology comes down in price with time.
a rise/an increase/a fall/a drop in price
They sell quality art supplies at discount prices.
I don't think you'll be able to sell it for that price.
price rises/increases/hikes/cuts

senses.definition: the unpleasant things that you must do or experience in order to achieve something or as a result of achieving something

examples.en: Criticism is part of the price of leadership.
Loneliness is a high price to pay for independence in your old age.
Giving up his job was a small price to pay for his children's happiness.
The team paid a heavy price for its lack of preparation.
Being recognized wherever you go is the price you pay for being famous.
His success came at a high price.

senses.definition: the numbers that tell you how much money you will receive if the horse that you bet on wins the race

examples.en: Six to one is a good price for that horse.

senses.definition: whatever the cost or the difficulties may be

examples.en: We want peace at any price.

senses.definition: costing a lot of money

examples.en: You can buy strawberries all year round, but at a price.
Food is available, at a price.

senses.definition: involving something unpleasant

examples.en: He'll help you—at a price!

senses.definition: extremely valuable or important

variants.html: (also cheap at twice the price)

senses.definition: so good or useful that the cost does not seem too much

examples.en: To buy all the recommended equipment is expensive, but as an investment for the future it is cheap at the price.

senses.definition: you can persuade anyone to do something by giving them more money or something that they want
used to say that no amount of money would persuade you to do or to sell something

examples.en: I wouldn't work for her again—not at any price!

idioms.word: pay the/a penalty/price (for something/for doing something)

senses.definition: to suffer because of bad luck, a mistake or something you have done

examples.en: He looked terrible this morning. I think he's paying the penalty for all those late nights.
They're now paying the price for past mistakes.
She thinks that any inconvenience is a price worth paying for living in such a beautiful place.

senses.definition: an amount of money that is offered for capturing or killing somebody

examples.en: Ever since he killed the gang’s leader, there has been a price on his head.

senses.definition: to say how much money something valuable is worth

examples.en: They haven't yet put a price on the business.
You can't put a price on that sort of loyalty.
You can't put a price on happiness.

senses.definition: used to say that you think that something you have achieved may not be worth all the problems and difficulties it causes

examples.en: What price fame and fortune?

senses.definition: used to say that something seems unlikely

examples.en: What price England winning the World Cup?

senses.definition: to fix the price of something at a particular level

examples.en: The main courses are all reasonably priced.
These goods are priced too high.
Their printers are competitively priced.
The tickets are priced at $100 each.
A dominant firm will price aggressively in markets where it faces new competitors.

senses.definition: to write or stick tickets on goods to show how much they cost
to compare the prices of different types of the same thing

examples.en: We priced various models before buying this one.

idioms.word: price yourself/something out of the market

senses.definition: to charge such a high price for your goods, services, etc. that nobody wants to buy them

examples.en: Some leading UK firms are pricing themselves out of the market.

senses.definition: a feeling of being pleased or satisfied that you get when you or people who are connected with you have done something well or own something that other people admire

examples.en: The sight of her son graduating filled her with pride.
He felt a glow of pride as people stopped to admire his garden.
Success in sport is a source of national pride.
I take (a) pride in my work.
They have a strong sense of pride in their work.
Their reputation for fairness is a matter of pride.
We take great pride in offering the best service in town.
I looked with pride at what I had achieved.

senses.definition: a person or thing that makes people feel pleased or satisfied

examples.en: The new sports stadium is the pride of the town.

senses.definition: the feeling of respect that you have for yourself

examples.en: Pride would not allow him to accept the money.
Her pride was hurt.
Losing his job was a real blow to his pride.
It's time to swallow your pride (= hide your feelings of pride) and ask for your job back.

senses.definition: the feeling that you are better or more important than other people

examples.en: She was full of pride and arrogance and despised ordinary people.
His male pride would not let him admit that a woman had defeated him.

senses.definition: a group of lions

examples.en: This pride of lions is/are resting after a hunt.

senses.definition: a person or thing that causes somebody to feel very pleased or satisfied

examples.en: The car is her pride and joy.
He loves that boat—it's his pride and joy.

senses.definition: if you have too high an opinion of yourself or your abilities, something will happen to make you look stupid
the position in which something is most easily seen, that is given to the most important thing in a particular group

examples.en: The photo was given pride of place on the mantelpiece.

senses.definition: a person who is qualified to perform religious duties and ceremonies in the Roman Catholic, Anglican and Orthodox Churches

examples.en: a parish priest
the ordination of women priests
The candles had been blessed by a priest.
the priest who was celebrating Mass
Only one or two new priests were ordained each year.

senses.definition: a person who performs religious ceremonies in some religions that are not Christian

examples.en: a Hindu/Buddhist priest

senses.definition: mainly

examples.en: a course designed primarily for specialists
The problem is not primarily a financial one.
The report is primarily concerned with aircraft safety.
The person primarily responsible is the project manager.

senses.definition: connected with the education of children between the ages of about five and eleven

examples.en: primary teachers
primary education

senses.definition: main; most important; basic

examples.en: our primary objective/goal/purpose
The primary aim of this course is to improve your spoken English.
Our primary concern must be the children.
Good healthcare is of primary importance.
The film's primary focus is on two families.
What is the primary reason for global warming?

senses.definition: developing or happening first; earliest

examples.en: Researchers are conducting studies to determine the primary causes of this phenomenon.

senses.definition: (in the US) an election in which people in a particular area vote to choose a candidate for a future important election

examples.en: the Illinois primary
the presidential primaries
He ran in the open primary for election as a state senator.
the next round of primaries

senses.definition: main; most important; basic

examples.en: My prime concern is to protect my property.
Winning is not the prime objective in this sport.
The care of the environment is of prime importance.
He's the police's prime suspect in this case.

senses.definition: of the best quality; excellent

examples.en: prime (cuts of) beef
The store has a prime position in the mall.

senses.definition: a prime example of something is one that is typical of it

examples.en: The building is a prime example of 1960s architecture.

senses.definition: most likely to be chosen for something; most suitable

examples.en: The house is isolated and a prime target for burglars.

senses.definition: the time in your life when you are strongest or most successful

examples.en: a young woman in her prime

These flowers are long past their prime.

senses.definition: a number that can be divided exactly only by itself and 1, for example 7, 17 and 41
to prepare somebody for a situation so that they know what to do, especially by giving them special information

examples.en: They had been primed with good advice.
She was ready and primed for action.
He had primed his friends to give the journalists as little information as possible.

senses.definition: to make something ready for use or action

examples.en: The bomb was primed, ready to explode.

senses.definition: to prepare wood, metal, etc. for painting by covering it with a special paint that helps the next layer of paint to stay on
to encourage the growth of a new or weak business or industry by putting money into it
a male member of a royal family who is not king, especially the son or grandson of the king or queen

examples.en: the royal princes
Prince William
the Prince of Wales

senses.definition: the male ruler of a small country or state that has a royal family; a male member of this family, especially the son or grandson of the ruler

examples.en: the prince of Orange
Prince Albert of Monaco

senses.definition: (in some European countries) a nobleman
a man who is thought to be one of the best in a particular field

examples.en: the prince of comedy

senses.definition: (1958-2016) a US pop singer and actor. He was born Prince Rogers Nelson in Minneapolis. In 1993 he changed his name into a symbol that nobody could pronounce, so he was called 'the Artist Formerly Known as Prince'. He changed his name back to Prince in 2000. He shocked some people with his sexual songs and performances on stage. He was the star of the film Purple Rain (1984) and won an Oscar for its music. He also wrote the music for Batman (1989).

(1619-82) an English soldier. He was the grandson of King James I and is best remembered for commanding the Royalist cavalry (= soldiers on horses) during the English Civil War. He was defeated at the battles of Marston Moor and Naseby, but escaped abroad, returning to England after the Restoration. He later helped to form the Hudson's Bay Company and the Royal Society.
a female member of a royal family who is not a queen, especially the daughter or granddaughter of the king or queen

examples.en: the royal princesses
Princess Anne

senses.definition: the wife of a prince

examples.en: the Princess of Wales

senses.definition: a young woman who has always been given everything that she wants, and who thinks that she is better than other people
used by some men as a form of address to a girl or young woman

examples.en: Is something the matter, princess?

senses.definition: most important; main

examples.en: The principal reason for this omission is lack of time.
New roads will link the principal cities of the area.
Tourist revenue is now our principal source of wealth.
My principal concern is to get the job done fast.
The violins have the principal tune.

senses.definition: the person who is in charge of a college or (in Scotland and Canada) a university

examples.en: Peter Brown, principal of St John’s College

variants.html: (British English head teacher)

senses.definition: a teacher who is in charge of a school

examples.en: Principal Ray Smith
The regulations have been opposed by local high school principals.

senses.definition: an amount of money that you lend to somebody or invest to earn interest

examples.en: The principal must be repaid in full within ten years.

senses.definition: the person who has the most important part in a play, an opera, etc.

examples.en: The performance of the two principals is disappointing.

senses.definition: a person that you are representing, especially in business or law

examples.en: The shareholders are principals and the managers are agents.

senses.definition: a moral rule or a strong belief that influences your actions

examples.en: He has high moral principles.
Stick to your principles and tell him you won't do it.
I refuse to lie about it; it's against my principles.
He doesn't invest in the arms industry on principle.
She refuses to allow her family to help her as a matter of principle.

senses.definition: a law, a rule or a theory that something is based on

examples.en: The same principles apply to both humans and animals.
an important legal principle
‘You learn general principles from studying particular things,’ he asserts.
the basic principles of car maintenance
There are three fundamental principles of teamwork.
to learn the basic/general principles of something
the principles of justice/law
the principles and practice of writing reports
draft principles for the management of shared natural resources
a document setting out principles for resolving the dispute
The principle behind it is very simple.
Discussing all these details will get us nowhere; we must get back to first principles (= the most basic rules).
The court derived a set of principles from this general rule.

senses.definition: a belief that is accepted as a reason for acting or thinking in a particular way

examples.en: The welfare of the child is the guiding principle of the family courts.

The principle of equality is enshrined in the Constitution.
the application of the principle that men and women should receive equal pay for equal work

the principle that free education should be available for all children

senses.definition: a general or scientific law that explains how something works or why something happens

examples.en: O'Sullivan was among the first chemists to apply scientific principles to brewing beer.
the principle that heat rises
A tidal current turbine is similar in principle to a windmill.

senses.definition: if something can be done in principle, there is no good reason why it should not be done although it has not yet been done and there may be some difficulties

examples.en: In principle there is nothing that a human can do that a machine might not be able to do one day.

senses.definition: in general but not in detail

examples.en: They have agreed to the proposal in principle but we still have to negotiate the terms.

senses.definition: to produce letters, pictures, etc. on paper using a machine that puts ink (= coloured liquid) on the surface

examples.en: I'm printing a copy of the document for you.

Each card is printed with a different message.

senses.definition: to produce books, newspapers, etc. by printing them in large quantities

examples.en: They printed 30 000 copies of the book.

senses.definition: to publish something in printed form

examples.en: The photo was printed in all the national newspapers.

senses.definition: to produce a photograph on paper from a digital file or from film

examples.en: Photographs can be printed from a digital file or from a negative.

senses.definition: to write without joining the letters together

examples.en: Print your name and address clearly in the space provided.

In some countries children learn to print when they first go to school.

senses.definition: to make a mark on a soft surface by pressing

examples.en: The tracks of the large animal were clearly printed in the sand.

senses.definition: to make a design on a surface or cloth by pressing a surface against it which has been coloured with ink or dye

examples.en: They had printed their own design on the T-shirt.
a T-shirt printed with their own design

senses.definition: used to describe a business that makes a lot of money with little effort

idioms.word: not worth the paper it’s written/printed on

senses.definition: having no value, especially legally, or because one of the people involved has no intention of doing what they said they would
what is published in books, newspapers, etc.

examples.en: the power of the printed word

senses.definition: letters, words, numbers, etc. that have been printed onto paper

examples.en: The tiny print was hard to read without my glasses.
in large/bold print
The terms of delivery appear at the bottom of the invoice in small print.
The print quality of the new laser printer is superb.
the print edition/version of the dictionary
television and print ads

senses.definition: used to refer to the business of producing newspapers, magazines and books

examples.en: the print media
print unions

senses.definition: a mark left by your finger, foot, etc. on the surface of something

examples.en: His prints were found on the gun.
There were paw prints everywhere.

senses.definition: a picture that is cut into wood or metal then covered with ink (= coloured liquid for printing, drawing, etc.) and printed onto paper; a picture that is copied from a painting using photography

examples.en: a framed set of prints
a Renoir print

senses.definition: a photograph produced from film

examples.en: How many sets of prints would you like?
a colour print

senses.definition: cotton cloth that has a pattern printed on it; this pattern

examples.en: a cotton print dress
a floral print

senses.definition: to be published

examples.en: By the time this gets into print, they'll already have left the country.

senses.definition: still available from the company that publishes it

examples.en: Is this edition still in print?

senses.definition: printed in a book, newspaper, etc.

examples.en: It was the first time he had seen his name in print.

senses.definition: no longer available from the company that publishes it

examples.en: Her first novel is now out of print.
The shop specializes in out-of-print books.

senses.definition: a machine for printing text on paper, especially one connected to a computer

examples.en: a colour printer
a printer cartridge

senses.definition: a person or a company whose job is printing books, etc.
a place where books, etc. are printed
the act of producing letters, pictures, patterns, etc. on something by pressing a surface covered with ink (= coloured liquid for printing, drawing, etc.) against it

examples.en: the invention of printing
colour printing
a printing business/firm
the printing industry/trade
production and printing costs
They used 108 different printing characters.

senses.definition: the act of printing a number of copies of a book at one time

examples.en: The book is in its sixth printing.

senses.definition: a type of writing when you write all the letters separately and do not join them together
happening or existing before something else or before a particular time

examples.en: Although not essential, some prior knowledge of statistics is desirable.
This information must not be disclosed without prior written consent.
Visits are by prior arrangement.
Please give us prior notice if you need an evening meal.
She will be unable to attend because of a prior engagement.

senses.definition: already existing and therefore more important

examples.en: They have a prior claim to the property.

senses.definition: before something

examples.en: during the week prior to the meeting

senses.definition: a person who is in charge of a group of monks or nuns living in a priory
(in an abbey) a person next in rank below an abbot or abbess
something that you think is more important than other things and should be dealt with first

examples.en: a high/low priority
Education is a top priority.
Our first priority is to improve standards.
National security is our main priority.
Public sector reform is a key priority.
Financial security was high on his list of priorities.
You need to get your priorities right (= decide what is important to you).
You need to get your priorities straight.
The department must start setting priorities.

senses.definition: the most important place among various things that have to be done or among a group of people

examples.en: Club members will be given priority.

A clean ocean must have priority over the profits of polluting industries.

senses.definition: the right of a vehicle to go before other traffic at a particular place on a road

examples.en: Buses have priority at this junction.

senses.definition: a building where people are kept as a punishment for a crime they have committed, or while they are waiting for trial

examples.en: She went to prison for tax evasion.
He was sent to prison for five years.
She is in prison, awaiting trial.
Her son is in prison for murder.
He served four years in prison for killing a man.
He's just out of prison, after ten years inside.
When did she get out of prison?
to be released from prison
On his release from prison he tried hard to find a decent job.
a maximum-security prison
a federal/state prison
a prison sentence/term
a prison cell
the prison population (= the total number of prisoners in a country)
a prison officer
a prison guard
Ten prison officers and three inmates needed hospital treatment following the riot.

senses.definition: the system of keeping people in prisons

examples.en: the prison service/system
The government insists that ‘prison works’ and plans to introduce a tougher sentencing policy for people convicted of violent crime.

senses.definition: a place or situation from which somebody cannot escape

examples.en: His hospital room had become a prison.

senses.definition: a person who is kept in prison as a punishment, or while they are waiting for trial

examples.en: The number of prisoners serving life sentences has fallen.
They called for the prisoners to be released.
They are demanding the release of all political prisoners.
international minimum standards for the treatment of prisoners

senses.definition: a person who has been captured, for example by an enemy, and is being kept somewhere

examples.en: He was taken prisoner by rebel soldiers.

senses.definition: the state of being alone and not watched or interrupted by other people

examples.en: She was longing for some peace and privacy.

senses.definition: the state of being free from the attention of the public

These policies are designed to protect the privacy of your personal information.
We need to have access to health records while safeguarding patient privacy.

senses.definition: belonging to or for the use of a particular person or group; not for public use

examples.en: The sign said, ‘Private property. Keep out.’

a private jet
Those are my father's private papers.

The villa has its own private beach.

senses.definition: intended for or involving a particular person or group of people, not for people in general or for others to know about

examples.en: You shouldn't listen to other people's private conversations.

senses.definition: that you do not want other people to know about

examples.en: She was scared of revealing her private thoughts and feelings.

senses.definition: owned or managed by an individual person or an independent company rather than by the state

examples.en: a private firm/business/hospital

a former soldier working in private security

a programme to return many of the state companies to private ownership

senses.definition: provided for a fee by an individual person or an independent organization rather than by the state

examples.en: She gives private English lessons at weekends.
If I can afford it, I think I'll go private (= pay for medical care rather than use the government service).

senses.definition: working or acting for yourself rather than for the state or for a group or company

examples.en: a private contractor/investigator
a private citizen/individual

senses.definition: not connected with your work or official position

examples.en: a politician’s private life
She claimed she was acting in a private capacity.
He was on a private trip to Japan.

senses.definition: where you are not likely to be interrupted; quiet

examples.en: Let's go somewhere a bit more private.
They found a private corner where they could talk.

senses.definition: not wanting to share thoughts and feelings with other people

examples.en: He's a very private person.

senses.definition: that you receive from property or other sources but do not have to earn

examples.en: He has a private income.

senses.definition: a soldier of the lowest rank in the army

examples.en: Private (John) Smith

senses.definition: private parts (= a polite way of referring to the sexual organs without saying their names)
with nobody else present

examples.en: Is there somewhere we can discuss this in private?

variants.html: (British English also privatisation)

senses.definition: the act of selling a business or an industry so that it is no longer owned by the government

examples.en: There were fears that privatization would lead to job losses.

senses.definition: a special right or advantage that a particular person or group of people has

examples.en: Education should be a universal right and not a privilege.
You can enjoy all the benefits and privileges of club membership.

senses.definition: the rights and advantages that rich and powerful people in a society have

examples.en: As a member of the nobility, his life had been one of wealth and privilege.

senses.definition: something that you are proud and lucky to have the opportunity to do

examples.en: I hope to have the privilege of working with them again.
It was a great privilege to hear her sing.

senses.definition: a special right to do or say things without being punished

examples.en: parliamentary privilege (= the special right of members of parliament to say particular things without risking legal action)
breach of privilege (= the breaking of rules about what a member of parliament can say and do)

senses.definition: to give somebody/something special rights or advantages that others do not have

examples.en: education policies that privilege the children of wealthy parents

senses.definition: an award that is given to a person who wins a competition, race, etc. or who does very good work

examples.en: She was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
He won first prize in the woodwind section.
The prize went to the grey long-haired cat.
She has received numerous prizes for her work.
There are no prizes for guessing (= it is very easy to guess) who she was with.
a cash prize of $5 000
The grand prize is a family trip to Hawaii.
His film took the top prize at Cannes last year.
I won £500 in prize money.
a prize fund of £20 000
Win a car in our prize draw!

senses.definition: something very important or valuable that is difficult to achieve or obtain

examples.en: World peace is the greatest prize of all.
The presidency is the ultimate prize.

senses.dis_g: (especially of an animal, a flower or a vegetable)
senses.definition: good enough to win a prize in a competition

examples.en: prize cattle

senses.definition: being a very good example of its kind

examples.en: a prize student
He's a prize specimen of the human race!
She's a prize idiot (= very silly).

senses.definition: to value something highly

examples.en: an era when honesty was prized above all other virtues
Oil of cedarwood is highly prized for its use in perfumery.

variants.html: (also prise especially in British English)

senses.definition: to use force to separate something from something else
how likely something is to happen

examples.en: The probability is that prices will rise rapidly.
There seemed to be a high probability of success.

senses.definition: a thing that is likely to happen

examples.en: A fall in interest rates is a strong probability in the present economic climate.
It now seems a probability rather than just a possibility.

senses.definition: a ratio showing the chances that a particular thing will happen

examples.en: There is a 60 per cent probability that the population will be infected with the disease.

senses.definition: (considering) the evidence on both sides of an argument, to find the most likely reason for or result of something

examples.en: The balance of evidence suggests the Liberal party's decline began before the First World War.
The coroner thought that on the balance of probabilities, the pilot had suffered a stroke just before the crash.

senses.definition: (considering) the evidence on both sides of an argument, to find the most likely reason for or result of something

examples.en: The coroner thought that on the balance of probabilities, the pilot had suffered a stroke just before the crash.

senses.definition: it is very likely that

examples.en: In all probability he failed to understand the consequences of his actions.
In all probability she wouldn't come even if we invited her.

senses.definition: likely to happen, to exist or to be true

examples.en: the probable cause/explanation/outcome
highly/quite/most probable
It is probable that the disease has a genetic element.

senses.definition: a person or an animal that is likely to win a race or to be chosen for a team

examples.en: All four players are probables for the national team.

senses.definition: used to say that something is likely to happen or to be true

examples.en: You're probably right.
I think that's probably true.
It'll probably be OK.
It was the best known and probably the most popular of her songs.
‘Is he going to be there?’ ‘Probably.’
‘I bet he's responsible for this mess.’ ‘Very probably.’
‘Do we need the car?’ ‘Probably not.’
As you probably know, I'm going to be changing jobs soon.

senses.definition: a complete and careful investigation of something

examples.en: a police probe into the financial affairs of the company

senses.definition: a spacecraft without people on board that obtains information and sends it back to earth
a long, thin metal tool used by doctors for examining inside the body
a small device put inside something and used by scientists to test something or record information
to ask questions in order to find out secret or hidden information about somebody/something

examples.en: He didn't like the media probing into his past.
a TV programme that probed government scandals in the 1990s

senses.definition: to touch, examine or look for something, especially with a long, thin instrument

examples.en: The doctor probed the wound for signs of infection.
Searchlights probed the night sky.

senses.definition: a thing that is difficult to deal with or to understand

examples.en: big/serious/major problems
She has a lot of health problems.
financial/social/technical problems
Let me know if you have any problems.
The government must address the problem of child poverty.
We cannot tackle this problem effectively on our own.
We are dealing with a serious problem here.
Money isn't going to solve the problem.
to fix a problem
If he chooses Mary it's bound to cause problems.
to pose/create a problem
The problem first arose in 2018.
There is a problem with this argument.
the problem of youth homelessness
Most students face the problem of funding themselves while they are studying.
Unemployment is a very real problem for graduates now.
It’s a nice table! The only problem is (that) it’s too big for our room.
Part of the problem is the shape of the room.

There's no history of heart problems (= disease connected with the heart) in our family.
the magazine’s problem page (= containing letters about readers’ problems and advice about how to solve them)

senses.definition: a question that can be answered by using logical thought or mathematics

examples.en: mathematical problems
to find the answer to the problem
The teacher set us 50 problems to do.
I have five problems to do for homework.

senses.definition: to disagree with or object to something/somebody

examples.en: I have no problem with you working at home tomorrow.
We are going to do this my way. Do you have a problem with that? (= showing that you are impatient with the person that you are speaking to)
Do you have a problem with her?

senses.definition: used to show that you do not care about somebody else’s difficulties

examples.en: If they can't afford to go, that's not my problem.

senses.definition: used to show that you are happy to help somebody or that something will be easy to do

examples.en: ‘Can I pay by credit card?’ ‘Yes, no problem.’

senses.definition: used after somebody has thanked you or said they are sorry for something

examples.en: ‘Thanks for the ride.’ ‘No problem.’

senses.definition: used to show that you think a person should deal with their own difficulties

examples.en: ‘My parents will be furious!’ ‘That’s your problem.’

senses.definition: used to show that you think somebody is being unreasonable

examples.en: What's your problem?—I only asked if you could help me for ten minutes.

senses.definition: causing problems for other people or yourself

examples.en: She was a problem child, always in trouble with the police.
a new approach to problem drinking
One out of every five people is a problem drinker.

senses.definition: difficult to deal with or to understand; full of problems; not certain to be successful

examples.en: The situation is more problematic than we first thought.
Which are the most problematic countries in the world for journalists?

senses.definition: a way of doing something, especially the usual or correct way

examples.en: emergency/safety/disciplinary procedures

senses.definition: the official or formal order or way of doing something, especially in business, law or politics

examples.en: court/legal/parliamentary procedure

senses.definition: a medical operation

examples.en: a routine surgical procedure
to perform/undergo a procedure

senses.definition: to continue doing something that has already been started; to continue being done

examples.en: We're not sure whether we still want to proceed with the sale.

senses.definition: to do something next, after having done something else first

examples.en: He outlined his plans and then proceeded to explain them in more detail.

senses.definition: to move or travel in a particular direction

examples.en: The marchers proceeded slowly along the street.

examples.en: court/legal/judicial proceedings

senses.definition: an event or a series of actions

examples.en: The Mayor will open the proceedings at the City Hall tomorrow.

senses.definition: the official written report of a meeting, etc.

examples.en: His paper is published in the new issue of the proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

senses.definition: the money that you receive when you sell something or organize a performance, etc.; profits

examples.en: She sold her car and bought a piano with the proceeds.

senses.definition: the treatment of raw material, food, etc. in order to change it, preserve it, etc.

examples.en: the food processing industry
a sewage processing plant

senses.definition: the process of dealing officially with a document, request, etc.

examples.en: errors in the processing of financial transactions

senses.definition: a machine, person or company that processes things

examples.en: The company is Ireland's largest dairy processor.

senses.definition: a part of a computer that controls all the other parts of the system

examples.en: The president proclaimed a state of emergency.

examples.en: This building, more than any other, proclaims the character of the town.

senses.definition: to make things to be sold, especially in large quantities

examples.en: Our company mainly produces goods for export.

senses.definition: to grow or make something as part of a natural process; to have a baby or young animal

senses.definition: to show something or make something appear from somewhere

senses.definition: a person or company that arranges for somebody to make a programme for radio or television, or a record, CD, etc.

senses.definition: a thing that is grown, produced or created, usually for sale

senses.definition: a film, play or broadcast that is prepared for the public; the act of preparing a film, play, etc.

senses.definition: making goods or growing crops, especially in large quantities

senses.definition: doing or achieving a lot

senses.definition: resulting in something or causing something

senses.definition: a type of job that needs special training or skill, especially one that needs a high level of education

senses.definition: all the people who work in a particular type of profession

senses.definition: the traditional jobs that need a high level of education and training, such as being a doctor or a lawyer
