We hope to see some real progress by March.
James is making steady progress in his recovery.
Police are making significant progress in fighting computer crime.
The two sides have made very slow progress in resolving the dispute.
There's been no sign of progress on this issue.
The company is making progress towards this target.
They asked for a progress report on the building work.

senses.definition: movement forwards or towards a place

examples.en: She watched his slow progress down the steep slope.
There wasn't much traffic so we made good progress.
We watched the ship's stately progress out of the docks.

senses.definition: happening at this time

examples.en: Work on the new offices is now in progress.
Please be quiet—examination in progress.

senses.definition: to improve or develop over a period of time; to make progress

examples.en: The course allows students to progress at their own speed.
Work on the new road is progressing slowly.
Things are progressing well.
to progress rapidly in your career
They are anxious to progress with the plan.
She started off playing the recorder and then progressed to the clarinet.
He soon progressed from the basics to more difficult work.

senses.definition: to move forward

examples.en: The line of traffic progressed slowly through the town.
Cases can take months to progress through the courts.

senses.definition: to go forward in time

examples.en: The weather became colder as the day progressed.
The visiting team's confidence increased as the game progressed.

senses.definition: in favour of new ideas, modern methods and change

examples.en: progressive schools

senses.definition: happening or developing steadily

examples.en: a progressive reduction in the size of the workforce
a progressive muscular disease

senses.definition: connected with the form of a verb (for example I am waiting or It is raining) that is made from a part of be and the present participle. Progressive forms are used to express an action that continues for a period of time.
at a higher percentage as the total amount of money being taxed increases

examples.en: Supporters of a progressive income tax argue that it is fairer.
The government made the tax more progressive, ensuring that higher earners pay more.

senses.definition: a person who is in favour of new ideas, modern methods and change

examples.en: political battles between progressives and conservatives

senses.definition: to stop something from being done or used especially by law

examples.en: Federal law prohibits discrimination based on age.
Soviet citizens were prohibited from travelling abroad.
Company policy prohibits posting clearly abusive content.

senses.definition: to make something impossible to do

examples.en: The high cost of equipment prohibits many people from taking up this sport.

senses.definition: a piece of work involving careful study of a subject over a period of time, done by school or college students

examples.en: a history project
My class is doing a project on medieval towns.
The final term will be devoted to project work.

senses.definition: a planned piece of work that is designed to find information about something, to produce something new, or to improve something

examples.en: We worked on various projects together.
About 300 schools are involved in the project.
to fund/finance a project
to start/launch/initiate a project
to undertake/complete a project
a building/construction project
They've set up a research project to investigate the harmful effects of air pollution.
Work has begun on a project to build a new hospital.
They are taking part in a project on reducing food waste.
a project manager/team

senses.definition: a set of aims, ideas or activities that somebody is interested in or wants to bring to people’s attention

examples.en: The party attempted to assemble its aims into a focused political project.

senses.definition: a group of houses or apartments built for poor families, usually with government money

examples.en: I was raised in the projects.

senses.definition: to estimate what the size, cost or amount of something will be in the future based on what is happening now

examples.en: A growth rate of 4 per cent is projected for next year.
Spending cuts will help to reduce huge projected deficits in future years.
The overall cost is projected at $11 billion.
Unemployment is projected to rise to over 5 per cent next year.
It is projected that the unemployment rate will fall.

senses.definition: to plan an activity, a project etc. for a time in the future

examples.en: The next edition of the book is projected for publication in March.
The projected housing development will go ahead next year.

senses.definition: to make light, an image, etc. fall onto a flat surface or screen

examples.en: They projected the digital image onto the model's surface.
Images are projected onto the retina of the eye.
The videos were projected onto two screens.
Old photographs were projected on the wall behind her.

senses.definition: to stick out beyond an edge or a surface

examples.en: a building with balconies projecting out over the street

senses.definition: to present somebody/something/yourself to other people in a particular way, especially one that gives a good impression

examples.en: They sought advice on how to project a more positive image of their company.
She projects an air of calm self-confidence.
He projected himself as a man worth listening to.

senses.definition: to send or throw something up or away from yourself

examples.en: Actors must learn to project their voices.
the powerful men who would project him into the White House

senses.definition: an estimate or a statement of what figures, amounts, or events will be in the future, or what they were in the past, based on what is happening now

examples.en: to make forward/backward projections of population figures
Sales have exceeded our projections.
Calculations are based on a projection of existing trends.

senses.definition: the act of putting an image of something onto a surface; an image that is shown in this way

examples.en: the projection of three-dimensional images on a computer screen
laser projections

senses.definition: a solid shape or object as represented on a flat surface

examples.en: map projections

senses.definition: something that sticks out from a surface

examples.en: tiny projections on the cell

senses.definition: the act of making your voice, a sound, etc. audible (= able to be heard) at a distance

examples.en: voice projection

senses.definition: the act of imagining that somebody else is thinking the same as you and is reacting in the same way
the act of giving a form and structure to inner thoughts and feelings

examples.en: The idea of God is a projection of humans' need to have something greater than themselves.

senses.definition: important or well known

examples.en: a prominent politician
He played a prominent part in the campaign.
She was prominent in the fashion industry.
Last month a group of prominent citizens of the town formed themselves into a committee to deal with the issue.

senses.definition: easily seen

examples.en: The church tower was a prominent feature in the landscape.
The story was given a prominent position on the front page.

senses.definition: sticking out from something

examples.en: a prominent nose
prominent cheekbones

senses.definition: to tell somebody that you will definitely do or not do something, or that something will definitely happen

examples.en: ‘We haven't got time to go to the park.’ ‘But you promised!’
The college principal promised to look into the matter.
‘Promise not to tell anyone!’ ‘I promise.’
They arrived at 7.30 as they had promised.
The government has promised a full investigation into the disaster.
I'll see what I can do but I can't promise anything.
The brochure promised (that) the local food would be superb.
You promised me (that) you’d be home early tonight.
He promised the money to his grandchildren.
He promised his grandchildren the money.
I've promised myself some fun when the exams are over.
‘I'll be back soon,’ she promised.

senses.definition: to make something seem likely to happen; to show signs of something

examples.en: It promises to be an exciting few days.
There were dark clouds overhead promising rain.

senses.definition: used as a way of encouraging or warning somebody about something

examples.en: I can promise you, you'll have a wonderful time.
If you don't take my advice, you'll regret it, I promise you.

senses.definition: to make promises that will be impossible to keep

examples.en: Politicians promise the earth before an election, but things are different afterwards.

senses.definition: a statement that tells somebody that you will definitely do or not do something

examples.en: to make/keep/fulfil/break a promise
You haven't gone back on your promise, have you?
He simply broke every single promise he ever made me.
The minister was under attack for a series of broken promises.
She kept her promise to visit her aunt regularly.
He fulfilled a campaign promise to end the war.
He had now to deliver on his promises to the Canadian electorate.
These are empty promises from a party not in a position to honour them.
It is unlikely that these laws will be changed, despite promises by the Prime Minister.
The government failed to keep its promise of lower taxes.
They were lured by government promises of either money or other benefits.
Do I have your promise that you won't tell anyone about this?

senses.definition: a sign that somebody/something will be successful

examples.en: Her work shows great promise.
Their research holds considerable promise.
He failed to fulfil his early promise.
Their future was full of promise.
Stem cell research offers real promise for the treatment of currently incurable diseases.

senses.definition: a sign, or a reason for hope that something may happen, especially something good

examples.en: The day dawned bright and clear, with the promise of warm, sunny weather.
The dog approached, attracted by the promise of food.
Organic food seems to hold out the promise of healthy living.

senses.definition: the act of performing a task quickly and carelessly, especially of washing or cleaning something quickly
showing signs of being good or successful

examples.en: He was voted the most promising new actor for his part in the movie.
The weather doesn't look very promising.
The research produced promising results.

senses.definition: to help sell a product, service, etc. or make it more popular by advertising it or offering it at a special price

examples.en: The band have gone on tour to promote their new album.
This trade fair will help businesses from Malawi to promote their products.
The area is being promoted as a tourist destination.

senses.definition: to help something to happen or develop

examples.en: to promote democracy/peace/understanding/health
I applaud his efforts to promote world peace.
to promote the development/use of something
policies to promote economic growth
a campaign to promote awareness of environmental issues
The exhibition was intended to promote interest in contemporary sculpture.
We think football can help to promote the idea of a multicultural and multiethnic society.
Vietnam has actively promoted foreign investment.

senses.definition: to move somebody to a higher rank or more senior job

examples.en: She worked hard and was soon promoted.
He has been promoted to sergeant.
He was an experienced officer who had been promoted from the ranks.

examples.cf: promote somebody from something to something
examples.en: She was promoted from finance director to chief executive.

senses.definition: to move a sports team from playing with one group of teams to playing in a better group

examples.en: They were promoted to the First Division last season.

senses.definition: a move to a more important job or rank in a company or an organization

examples.en: The new job is a promotion for him.
Her promotion to Sales Manager took everyone by surprise.
a job with excellent promotion prospects

senses.definition: a move by a sports team from playing in one group of teams to playing in a better group

examples.en: the team’s promotion to the First Division

senses.definition: activities done in order to increase the sales of a product or service; a set of advertisements for a particular product or service

examples.en: Her job is mainly concerned with sales and promotion.
We are doing a special promotion of French cheeses.
We're doing a major book promotion at key bookshops this week.

senses.definition: activity that encourages people to believe in the value or importance of something, or that helps something to succeed

examples.en: a society for the promotion of religious tolerance
The new health promotion clinic will provide free check-ups.

senses.definition: to make somebody decide to do something; to cause something to happen

examples.en: The discovery of the bomb prompted an increase in security.
His speech prompted an angry outburst from a man in the crowd.
Her father's struggles with mental health prompted her to pursue psychology as a career.

senses.definition: to encourage somebody to speak by asking them questions or suggesting words that they could say

examples.en: She was too nervous to speak and had to be prompted.
The program will prompt you to enter data where required.
‘And then what happened?’ he prompted.

senses.definition: to follow the text of a play and remind the actors what the words are if they forget their lines
done without delay

examples.en: Prompt action was required as the fire spread.
Prompt payment of the invoice would be appreciated.

senses.definition: acting without delay; arriving at the right time

examples.en: Please be prompt when attending these meetings.

senses.definition: a word or words said to an actor, to remind them what to say next when they have forgotten
a sign on a computer screen that shows that the computer has finished doing something and is ready for more instructions
an instruction given to an artificial intelligence program to tell it what you want it to produce

examples.en: Here's a list of AI prompts to help cure your writer's block.

senses.definition: exactly at the time mentioned

examples.en: The meeting will begin at ten o'clock prompt.

senses.definition: to make the sound of a word or letter in a particular way

examples.en: to pronounce a word/syllable/vowel/consonant
Very few people can pronounce my name correctly.
The ‘b’ in lamb is not pronounced.
I found it difficult to pronounce the name of the port.

senses.definition: to give a judgement, opinion or statement formally, officially or publicly

examples.en: to pronounce an opinion
The judge will pronounce sentence today.
I hesitate to pronounce judgement in such a case.
She pronounced him the winner of the competition.
I now pronounce you husband and wife (= in a marriage ceremony).
She was pronounced dead on arrival at the hospital.
The jury pronounced him guilty of first-degree murder.
He pronounced the country to be in a state of war.
She pronounced that an error had been made.
‘It's pneumonia,’ he pronounced gravely.
The committee has pronounced in favour of the merger.
The judge pronounced for (= in favour of) the defendant.
My opinion in this case is that I must pronounce against this claim.

senses.definition: very obvious, easy to notice or strongly expressed

examples.en: He walked with a pronounced limp.
She has very pronounced views on art.

senses.definition: information, documents, etc. that show that something is true

examples.en: conclusive/definitive/scientific proof
The police suspected him of dealing drugs, but they didn't have any proof.
to require/need proof
Can you provide any proof of identity?
Keep the receipt as proof of purchase.
These results are a further proof of his outstanding ability.
There is no proof that the knife belonged to her.
Today's unemployment figures are proof positive the government's economic plan isn't working.
In criminal cases the burden of proof (= requirement to provide proof) is on the prosecution.
plans to lower the standard of proof required to convict people of crimes under the Terrorism Act

senses.definition: the process of testing whether something is true or a fact

examples.en: Is the claim capable of proof?

senses.definition: a way of proving that a statement is true or that what you have calculated is correct
a copy of printed material which is produced so that mistakes can be corrected

examples.en: She was checking the proofs of her latest novel.

senses.definition: a standard used to measure the strength of alcoholic drinks
to show by your actions or qualities that a particular fact is true

examples.en: These figures are living proof of the government's incompetence.
He is living proof that age is no barrier to new challenges.

idioms.word: the proof of the pudding (is in the eating) | the proof is in the pudding

senses.definition: you can only judge if something is good or bad when you have tried it
that can resist the damaging or harmful effects of something

examples.en: The sea wall was not proof against the strength of the waves.

senses.definition: that can resist or protect against the thing mentioned

examples.en: rainproof/windproof clothing
The car has childproof locks on the rear doors.
an inflation-proof pension plan

senses.definition: to put a special substance on something, especially cloth, to protect it against water, fire, etc.

examples.en: proofed canvas

senses.definition: to produce a test copy of a piece of printed work so that mistakes can be corrected

examples.en: She edits and proofs his work.

senses.definition: ideas or statements that may be false or present only one side of an argument that are used in order to gain support for a political leader, party, etc.

examples.en: enemy propaganda
a propaganda campaign

senses.definition: right, appropriate or correct; according to the rules

examples.en: We should have had a proper discussion before voting.
Please follow the proper procedures for dealing with complaints.
Manufacturers provide these directions to indicate the proper use of their products.
It is vital that they're given the proper training.
The Government is failing to deliver proper care and treatment to people with dementia.
Nothing is in its proper place.
He is never referred to by his proper name in the play.

senses.definition: that you consider to be real and of a good enough standard

examples.en: I haven't had a proper meal in days.
Eat some proper food, not just toast and jam!
When are you going to get a proper job?

senses.definition: socially and morally acceptable

examples.en: It is right and proper that parents take responsibility for their children's attendance at school.
The development was planned without proper regard to the interests of local people.
He is always perfectly proper in his behaviour.

senses.definition: according to the most exact meaning of the word

examples.en: The celebrations proper always begin on the last stroke of midnight.

senses.definition: complete

examples.en: We're in a proper mess now.

senses.definition: belonging to a particular type of thing; natural in a particular situation or place

examples.en: They should be treated with the dignity proper to all individuals created by God.

senses.definition: completely; to the greatest extent possible

examples.en: That's messed things up good and proper.

senses.definition: in a way that is correct and/or appropriate

examples.en: How much money do we need to do the job properly?
The television isn't working properly.
The baby was put on a ventilator to help her lungs function properly.
Make sure the letter is properly addressed.
Businesses should ensure that staff are properly trained in how to use new systems.
Paine believed that 'Liberty, properly understood, consists in the power of doing whatever does not injure another.'

senses.definition: in a way that is socially or morally acceptable

examples.en: You acted perfectly properly in approaching me first.
When will these kids learn to behave properly?

senses.definition: really; in fact

examples.en: He had usurped powers that properly belonged to parliament.
The subject is not, properly speaking (= really), a science.

senses.definition: a thing or things that are owned by somebody; a possession or possessions

examples.en: personal/stolen property
This building is government property.
Be careful not to damage other people's property.

senses.definition: land and buildings

examples.en: The price of property has risen enormously.
A sign indicates that it is now private property.
commercial/residential property
property prices/values/taxes
a property developer/owner
property development/investment
a slump in the property market
The storms caused millions of pounds worth of property damage.

senses.definition: a building or buildings and the surrounding land

examples.en: to own/buy/purchase/acquire/sell a property
rental/investment properties
There are a lot of empty properties in the area.

senses.definition: a quality or characteristic that something has

examples.en: Compare the physical properties of the two substances.
a plant with medicinal properties
The substance has properties similar to those of plastic.
The difference occurs because of local variation in soil properties.

senses.definition: a part or share of a whole

examples.en: Water covers a large proportion of the earth's surface.
Loam is a soil with roughly equal proportions of clay, sand and silt.
A significant proportion of the books have been translated from other languages.
A higher proportion of Americans go on to higher education than is the case in Britain.

senses.definition: the relationship of one thing to another in size, amount, etc.

examples.en: The proportion of men to women in the college has changed dramatically over the years.
The basic ingredients are limestone and clay in the proportion 2:1.
The room is very long in proportion to (= relative to) its width.

senses.definition: the correct relationship in size, degree, importance, etc. between one thing and another or between the parts of a whole

examples.en: You haven't drawn the figures in the foreground in proportion.
The head is out of proportion with the body.
an impressive building with fine proportions
There is an entrance hall of perfect proportions, twice as long as it is wide.
Always try to keep a sense of proportion (= of the relative importance of different things).

senses.definition: the measurements of something; its size and shape

examples.en: This method divides the task into more manageable proportions.
a food shortage that could soon reach crisis proportions
a room of fairly generous proportions

senses.definition: the equal relationship between two pairs of numbers, as in the statement ‘4 is to 8 as 6 is to 12’
to react to something in a sensible way and not think it is worse or more serious than it really is

examples.en: The problem of hooliganism should be kept in proportion. Only a small number of young people act in this way.

senses.definition: larger, more serious, etc. in relation to something than is necessary or appropriate

examples.en: They earn salaries out of all proportion to their ability.
The media have blown the incident up out of all proportion.

senses.definition: a formal suggestion or plan; the act of making a suggestion

examples.en: to submit/present/put forward a proposal
to consider/discuss a proposal
to accept/approve/support/reject a proposal
a proposal to build more office accommodation
His proposal that the system should be changed was rejected.
The proposal for a new high-speed railway met with strong opposition.
When will the minister publish his proposals on reform of the health service?
two recent proposals by Vancouver City Council
Reaction to the proposals from technology companies has so far been muted.
Under these proposals, the Commission will be significantly strengthened.
The Republicans in Congress will vote for the president's budget proposal.

senses.definition: an act of formally asking somebody to marry you

examples.en: She accepted his proposal of marriage.
a marriage proposal

senses.definition: to suggest a plan, an idea, etc. for people to think about and decide on

examples.en: The government proposed changes to the voting system.
The Board of Directors is proposing an amendment to Article I.
The three countries had proposed a plan for him to hand over power to a chosen successor.
What would you propose?
Other services will not be affected by the proposed legislation.
It is one of several proposed hospital developments around town.
Since the idea was first proposed, no action has been taken.
a proposed reform/rule/law/project
This year we propose a tax increase of 3.9 percent.
She proposed that the book be banned.
She proposed that the book should be banned.
It was proposed that the president be elected for a period of two years.
He proposed changing the name of the company.

examples.cf: it is proposed to do something
examples.en: It was proposed to pay the money from public funds.

senses.definition: to intend to do something

examples.en: What do you propose to do now?
How do you propose getting home?
We do not propose to take any further action in the matter.

senses.definition: to ask somebody to marry you

examples.en: He was afraid that if he proposed she might refuse.
She proposed to me!
to propose marriage

senses.definition: to suggest something at a formal meeting and ask people to vote on it

examples.en: I propose Tom Ellis for chairman.
He was proposed for the job of treasurer.
to propose a motion (= to be the main speaker in support of an idea at a formal debate)

senses.definition: to suggest an explanation of something for people to consider

examples.en: She proposed a possible solution to the mystery.

idioms.word: propose a toast (to somebody) | propose somebody’s health

senses.definition: to ask people to wish somebody health, happiness and success by raising their glasses and drinking

examples.en: I'd like to propose a toast to the bride and groom.

senses.definition: an idea or a plan of action that is suggested, especially in business

examples.en: I'd like to put a business proposition to you.
He was trying to make it look like an attractive proposition.

senses.definition: a thing that you intend to do; a problem, task or person to be dealt with

examples.en: Getting a work permit in the UK is not always a simple proposition.

senses.definition: (in the US) a suggested change to the law that people can vote on

examples.en: How did you vote on Proposition 8?

senses.definition: a statement that expresses an opinion

examples.en: Her assessment is based on the proposition that power corrupts.
The book puts forward a number of extreme propositions about the nature of language.

senses.definition: a statement of a theorem, and an explanation of how it can be proved

examples.en: First of all we need to examine whether this proposition is true.

senses.definition: to say in a direct way to somebody that you would like to have sex with them

examples.en: She was propositioned by a strange man in the hotel lounge.

senses.definition: to officially charge somebody with a crime in court

examples.en: The police decided not to prosecute.
Trespassers will be prosecuted (= a notice telling people to keep out of a particular area).
The company was prosecuted for breaching the Health and Safety Act.

senses.definition: to be a lawyer in a court case for a person or an organization that is charging somebody with a crime

examples.en: the prosecuting counsel/lawyer/attorney
James Spencer, prosecuting, claimed that the witness was lying.

senses.definition: to continue taking part in or doing something

examples.en: They had overwhelming public support to prosecute the war.

senses.definition: the process of trying to prove in court that somebody is guilty of a crime (= of prosecuting them); the process of being officially charged with a crime in court

examples.en: Prosecution for a first minor offence rarely leads to imprisonment.
He threatened to bring a private prosecution against the doctor.

senses.definition: a person or an organization that prosecutes somebody in court, together with the lawyers, etc.

examples.en: He was a witness for the prosecution.
The prosecution has/have failed to prove its/their case.
defence and prosecution
a prosecution lawyer

senses.definition: the act of making something happen or continue
a public official who charges somebody officially with a crime and prosecutes them in court

examples.en: the public/state prosecutor

senses.definition: a lawyer who leads the case against a defendant in court

examples.en: The prosecutor rose to give the opening address.

senses.definition: the possibility that something will happen

examples.en: There is no immediate prospect of peace.
They faced the prospect of defeat in the elections.
There was insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction.
It's a move that raises the prospect of a takeover battle for the airline.
Her family is having to come to terms with the increasingly unlikely prospect of ever finding her.
There's a reasonable prospect that his debts will be paid.
A place in the semi-finals is in prospect (= likely to happen).

senses.definition: an idea of what might or will happen in the future

examples.en: an exciting prospect
Travelling alone around the world is a daunting prospect.
Her heart sank at the prospect of marriage to a man she loathed.
The prospect of becoming a father filled him with alarm.
I don't relish the prospect of having to share an office.
I'm very excited at the prospect of joining the team.

senses.definition: the chances of being successful

examples.en: good job/employment/career prospects
industries with excellent growth prospects
At 25 he was an unemployed musician with no prospects.
Long-term prospects for the economy have improved.
The war undermines future prospects for economic growth.
Their prospects of success are slight.
What are the prospects of promotion in this job?
We are highly optimistic about the future prospects of the company.

senses.definition: a person who is likely to be successful in a competition or in a particular career

examples.en: She is one of Canada's best prospects for a gold medal.
a list of the hot new prospects on the literary scene

senses.definition: a wide view of an area of land, etc.

examples.en: a delightful prospect of the lake

senses.definition: to search an area for gold, minerals, oil, etc.

examples.en: Thousands moved to the area to prospect for gold.
to prospect for new clients

senses.definition: expected to do something or to become something

examples.en: a prospective buyer
I had a phone call from a prospective client today.

senses.definition: expected to happen soon

examples.en: They are worried about prospective changes in the law.
On learning of a prospective sale, the lawyer should call the client as soon as possible.

senses.definition: the state of being successful, especially in making money

examples.en: Our future prosperity depends on economic growth.
The country is enjoying a period of peace and prosperity.

senses.definition: to make sure that somebody/something is not harmed, injured, damaged, etc.

examples.en: to protect children/citizens/civilians/consumers/workers
Our aim is to protect the jobs of our members.
the section of the treaty that protects the rights of employees
Each company is fighting to protect its own commercial interests.
A majority of Democrats believe that such regulations protect the public.
Troops have been sent to protect aid workers against attack.
They huddled together to protect themselves from the wind.
a paint that helps protect against rust
Vitamin B12 may have a role in protecting from heart disease.

senses.definition: to introduce laws that make it illegal to kill, harm or damage a particular animal, area of land, building, etc.

examples.en: a protected area/species
the need to protect the environment
Polar bears have been protected by law in Norway since 1973.
The plant is protected under the Wildlife and Countryside Act.

senses.definition: to help an industry in your own country by taxing goods from other countries so that there is less competition

examples.en: protected markets

senses.definition: to provide somebody/something with insurance against fire, injury, damage, etc.

examples.en: Many policies do not protect you against personal injury.

senses.definition: to limit access to data, a web page, etc., for example by using passwords or encryption (= special codes)

examples.en: Security products are designed to protect information from unauthorized access.
All these pages are password-protected.

senses.definition: the act of protecting somebody/something; the state of being protected

examples.en: Wear clothes that provide adequate protection against the wind and rain.
His straw hat offered some protection from the sun.
We seek to ensure the protection of human rights.
the conservation and protection of the environment
They are campaigning for better protection for workers.
She carries a gun in her bag for personal protection.
He asked to be put under police protection.
These people remain under the protection of the United Nations.
data protection laws
the importance of environmental protection

senses.definition: a thing that protects somebody/something against something

examples.en: The plastic sheeting is not a complete protection against the rain.
The trench served as a protection from enemy gunfire.
He wears a helmet as protection.
Fill the cooling system with antifreeze as a protection against frost.
They wore the charm as a protection against evil spirits.

senses.definition: insurance against fire, injury, damage, etc.

examples.en: Our policy offers complete protection against fire and theft.

senses.definition: the system of helping an industry in your own country by taxing foreign goods

examples.en: The government is ready to introduce protection for the car industry.

senses.definition: the system of paying criminals so that they will not attack your business or property

examples.en: to pay protection money
to run a protection racket

senses.definition: providing or intended to provide protection

examples.en: Workers should wear full protective clothing.
a protective layer of varnish
The ozone layer forms a protective barrier against the sun's rays.

senses.definition: having or showing a wish to protect somebody/something

examples.en: He put a protective arm around her shoulders.

senses.definition: intended to give an advantage to your own country’s industry

examples.en: protective tariffs

senses.definition: a substance, found within all living things, that forms the structure of muscles, organs, etc. There are many different proteins and they are an essential part of what humans and animals eat to help them grow and stay healthy.

examples.en: essential proteins and vitamins
protein deficiency
Peas, beans and lentils are a good source of vegetable protein.
Gluten is a protein found in wheat and other grains.

senses.definition: the expression of strong dislike of or opposition to something; a statement or an action that shows this

examples.en: to hold/organize/join a protest
violent/anti-war protests
The riot began as a peaceful protest.
mass/street protests
a protest march/movement
Unions have called for a day of protest on 24 February.
The announcement raised a storm of protest.
There have been mounting protests at the treatment of asylum seekers by the government.
The director resigned in protest at the decision.
People rioted in the streets in protest.
protests over plans to close the museum
She accepted the charge without protest.
The workers staged a protest against the proposed changes in their contracts.
They have decided not to attend the Bonn conference as a protest.
The strike began the day before as a protest against the proposed cuts.
The building work will go ahead, despite protests from local residents.
The country has undergone two weeks of protests by workers and students.

senses.definition: unwillingly and after expressing disagreement

examples.en: She wrote a letter of apology but only under protest.
The strikers returned to work, but under protest.

senses.definition: to say or do something to show that you disagree with something or think it is bad, especially publicly

examples.en: There's no use protesting, I won't change my mind.
They were taken away protesting loudly.
Students took to the streets to protest against the decision.

Tenants have been protesting about conditions in their block of flats.

In college she protested the war in Vietnam.

senses.definition: to state clearly that something is true, especially when you have been accused of something or when other people do not believe you

examples.en: She has always protested her innocence.

senses.definition: a person who makes a public protest

examples.en: Thousands of protesters marched through the city.

senses.definition: a system of fixed rules and formal behaviour used at official meetings, usually between governments

examples.en: a breach of protocol

senses.definition: the first or original version of an agreement, especially a treaty between countries, etc.; an extra part added to an agreement or treaty

examples.en: the first Geneva Protocol

senses.definition: a set of rules that control the way data is sent between computers
a plan for performing a scientific experiment or medical treatment
feeling pleased and satisfied about something that you own or have done, or are connected with

examples.en: proud parents
the proud owner of a new car

examples.cf: proud of somebody/something/yourself for doing something
examples.en: He was proud of himself for not giving up.
I feel very proud to be a part of the team.
I'm proud to say you're my son.
We are proud to present this award to you.

senses.definition: causing somebody to feel proud

examples.en: This is the proudest moment of my life.

senses.definition: feeling that you are better and more important than other people

examples.en: She comes across as proud and arrogant.

senses.definition: having respect for yourself and not wanting to lose the respect of others

examples.en: They were a proud and independent people.
Don't be too proud to ask for help.

senses.definition: beautiful, tall and impressive

examples.en: The sunflowers stretched tall and proud to the sun.

senses.definition: very proud/pleased

examples.en: Now he's passed his driving test, he's as proud as Punch.

senses.definition: to treat somebody very well by giving them a lot of good food, entertainment, etc.

examples.en: The college did us proud at the centenary dinner.

senses.definition: to do something that makes you proud of yourself or that makes other people proud of you
to use facts, evidence, etc. to show that something is true

examples.en: They hope this new evidence will prove her innocence.
‘I know you're lying.’ ‘Prove it!’
He felt he needed to prove his point (= show other people that he was right).
Are you just doing this to prove a point?
What are you trying to prove?

The prosecution has failed to prove its case.
She continued to prove her worth to the team.
Just give me a chance and I'll prove it to you.
This proves (that) I was right.
She was determined to prove everyone wrong.
In this country, you are innocent until proven guilty.
You've just proved yourself to be a liar.
This just proves what I have been saying for some time.
Can it be proved that he did commit these offences?

senses.definition: if something proves dangerous, expensive, etc. or if it proves to be dangerous, etc., you discover that it is dangerous, etc. over a period of time

examples.en: The strategy has proved successful.
The new system has proved popular with our clients.

I have some information that may prove useful.
The opposition proved too strong for him.
The play proved a great success.
Shares in the industry proved a poor investment.
His lack of experience may prove a problem in a crisis.
The promotion proved to be a turning point in her career.
Their fears proved to be groundless.

senses.definition: to show other people how good you are at doing something or that you are capable of doing something

examples.en: He constantly feels he has to prove himself to others.

senses.definition: to show other people that you are a particular type of person or that you have a particular quality

She proved herself to be a skilful negotiator.

senses.definition: to swell (= become larger or rounder) before being baked because of the action of yeast; to leave bread dough to prove

examples.en: While the dough is proving, crumble the feta and chop the olives.

idioms.word: the exception that proves the rule

senses.definition: people say that something is the exception that proves the rule when they are stating something that seems to be different from the normal situation, but they mean that the normal situation remains true in general

examples.en: Most electronics companies have not done well this year, but ours is the exception that proves the rule.

senses.definition: to give something to somebody or make it available for them to use

examples.en: Please provide the following information.
The exhibition provides an opportunity for local artists to show their work.
She did not provide any evidence to substantiate the claims.

Please answer questions in the space provided.
Refreshments will be provided.
We are here to provide a service for the public.
We are here to provide the public with a service.

senses.definition: to state that something will or must happen

senses.definition: one of the areas that some countries are divided into with its own local government

examples.en: the provinces of Canada
the central province of Ghor

senses.definition: all the parts of a country except the capital city

examples.en: The show will tour the provinces after it closes in London.
a shy young man from the provinces

senses.definition: a person’s particular area of knowledge, interest or responsibility

examples.en: Such decisions are normally the province of higher management.

senses.definition: connected with one of the large areas that some countries are divided into, with its own local government

examples.en: provincial assemblies/elections

senses.definition: connected with the parts of a country that do not include the capital city, especially when these are regarded as lacking culture or modern ideas

examples.en: a provincial town

senses.definition: unwilling to consider new or different ideas or things

examples.en: In spite of his education and travels, he has remained very provincial.

senses.definition: a person who lives in or comes from a part of the country that is not near the capital city, especially when regarded as lacking culture or modern ideas
the act of supplying somebody with something that they need or want; something that is supplied

examples.en: housing provision

senses.definition: preparations that you make for something that might or will happen in the future

examples.en: He had already made provisions for (= planned for the financial future of) his wife and children before the accident.

senses.definition: supplies of food and drink, especially for a long journey

examples.en: We have enough provisions to last us two weeks.

senses.definition: a condition or an arrangement in a legal document

examples.en: The same provisions apply to foreign-owned companies.

senses.definition: to supply somebody/something with enough of something, especially food, to last for a particular period of time

examples.en: The main business of the port is to provision passing ocean liners.

senses.definition: to cause a particular reaction or have a particular effect

senses.definition: to say or do something that you know will annoy somebody so that they react in an angry way

senses.definition: relating to psychiatry or to mental illnesses

examples.en: psychiatric disorders
a psychiatric hospital/nurse/patient
psychiatric treatment

senses.definition: connected with a person’s mind and the way in which it works

senses.definition: connected with the study of psychology

examples.en: psychological research

senses.definition: the best time to do something in order for it to be successful

senses.definition: a scientist who studies and is trained in psychology

examples.en: to see a psychologist
to go to a psychologist
an educational psychologist
a clinical psychologist (= one who treats people with a mental illness)

a child psychologist
a sports psychologist

senses.definition: the scientific study of the mind and how it influences behaviour

examples.en: clinical/educational/child/sport psychology

senses.definition: the kind of mind that somebody has that makes them think or behave in a particular way

examples.en: the psychology of small boys

senses.definition: how the mind influences behaviour in a particular area of life

examples.en: the psychology of interpersonal relationships

variants.html: (also formal public house)

senses.definition: a building where people go to drink and meet their friends. Pubs serve alcoholic and other drinks, and often also food.

examples.en: We're all going to the pub after work.

the landlord of the local pub

the public purse (= the money that the government can spend)

senses.definition: known to people in general

senses.definition: where there are a lot of people who can see and hear you

senses.definition: to be something that everyone knows, especially in a particular community or group

senses.definition: to tell people about something that is a secret

senses.definition: to start selling shares on the stock exchange
well known to many people through television, newspapers, the internet, etc.

examples.en: She doesn't want her children growing up in the public eye.

senses.definition: ordinary people in society in general

when other people, especially people you do not know, are present

senses.definition: the act of printing a book, a magazine, etc. and making it available to the public; a book, a magazine, etc. that has been published

examples.en: to publish a book/novel/magazine/paper

examples.en: to publish a story/letter/comment/review

senses.definition: to make information available to the public

senses.definition: to have your work printed and sold to the public

senses.definition: the profession or business of preparing and printing books, magazines, CD-ROMs, etc. and selling or making them available to the public

examples.en: a job in publishing
a publishing house/company

senses.definition: to take hold of something and use force in order to move it or try to move it towards yourself

examples.en: You push and I'll pull.

examples.en: In this area oxen are used to pull carts.

senses.definition: to damage a muscle, etc. by using too much force

senses.definition: to move a switch, etc. towards yourself or down in order to operate a machine or piece of equipment

examples.en: Pull the lever to start the motor.

senses.cf: pull (something) to the right/the left/one side
senses.definition: to move or make a vehicle move to the side

examples.en: The wheel is pulling to the left.

senses.definition: to work hard and use a lot of power

examples.en: The old car pulled hard as we drove slowly up the hill.

senses.definition: to use oars to move a boat along

examples.en: They pulled towards the shore.

senses.definition: to attract the interest or support of somebody/something

examples.en: They pulled in huge crowds on their latest tour.

senses.definition: to attract somebody sexually and get them to spend the evening with you

examples.en: He can still pull the girls.

senses.definition: to succeed in playing a trick on somebody, committing a crime, etc.

senses.definition: to cancel an event; to stop showing an advertisement, etc.

senses.definition: used to say that it is very difficult to make somebody do something

examples.en: It's like pulling teeth trying to get him to talk.

senses.definition: to criticize somebody, or their work or ideas, very severely

idioms.word: pull/drag yourself up by your (own) bootstraps

senses.definition: to improve your situation yourself, without help from other people
to produce an expression on your face to show that you do not like somebody/something or in order to make somebody laugh

examples.en: What are you pulling a face at now?
Do you think it’s funny to make faces behind my back?

senses.definition: to trick somebody
to have different aims that cannot be achieved together without causing problems

examples.en: There are different considerations, often pulling in different directions.

idioms.word: pull it/something out of the bag

senses.definition: to succeed in doing something difficult by making an extra effort or doing something clever or surprising

examples.en: We managed to pull it out of the bag despite not being at our best for most of the game.

senses.definition: to play a joke on somebody, usually by making them believe something that is not true

idioms.word: pull the other one (—it’s got bells on)

senses.definition: used to show that you do not believe what somebody has just said
to make the greatest effort possible to achieve something
to put an end to somebody’s project, a plan, etc.

examples.en: The television company pulled the plug on the series after only five episodes.

senses.definition: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody

examples.en: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

idioms.word: pull something/a rabbit out of the hat

senses.definition: to suddenly produce something as a solution to a problem
to make use of your place or status in society or at work to make somebody do what you want

idioms.word: pull the rug (out) from under somebody’s feet

senses.definition: to take help or support away from somebody suddenly
to try to improve your performance, work, behaviour, etc.

examples.en: You're going to have to pull your socks up.

variants.html: (North American English also pull wires)

senses.definition: to use your influence in order to get an advantage for somebody
to control events or the actions of other people

variants.html: (British English up sticks)

senses.definition: to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else

senses.definition: to work as hard as everyone else in a job, an activity, etc.

senses.definition: to hide your real actions or intentions from somebody by making them believe something that is not true
an act of trying to make something move by taking hold of it and using force to bring it towards you

examples.en: I gave the door a sharp pull and it opened.

senses.definition: a strong physical force that makes something move in a particular direction

senses.definition: the fact of something attracting you or having a strong effect on you

senses.definition: power and influence over other people

senses.definition: an act of taking a deep breath of smoke from a cigarette, etc. or a deep drink of something

senses.definition: a difficult walk up a steep hill

examples.en: It's a long pull up to the summit.

senses.definition: an injury to a muscle caused by using too much force
something such as a handle or rope that you use to pull something

examples.en: a bell/door pull

senses.definition: trying to find a sexual partner

examples.en: pulse waves

senses.definition: the seeds of some plants that are eaten as food, such as peas and lentils

examples.en: I punched the button to summon the elevator.

senses.definition: to be or try to be more successful than others in doing something that normally requires more skill, experience, money, etc. than you have

examples.en: This player seems to be able to constantly punch above her weight.
He punched above his weight as the party’s foreign affairs spokesman.

senses.definition: a hard hit made with the fist (= closed hand)

examples.en: a punch in the face
Hill threw a punch at the police officer.
a knockout punch
He shot out his right arm and landed a punch on Lorrimer's nose.

senses.definition: the power to interest people

examples.en: It's a well-constructed crime story, told with speed and punch.

senses.definition: a tool or machine for cutting holes in paper, leather or metal

examples.en: a hole punch

senses.definition: a hot or cold drink made by mixing water, fruit juice, spices and usually wine or another alcoholic drink
to get or do something before somebody else can
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
to have a powerful effect on somebody

examples.en: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

senses.definition: to express something less strongly than you are able to, for example to avoid upsetting or shocking somebody

examples.en: Her articles certainly don't pull any punches.

senses.definition: to adapt yourself to a difficult situation

a British humorous magazine, established in 1841, which took its name from the character Punch in Punch and Judy shows. It became Britain's leading magazine for humorous political and social comment, and included drawings by famous artists such as John Tenniel. It was originally published every week. In the 1980s it began losing readers to other magazines such as Private Eye. It stopped appearing in 1992 but appeared again from 1996 to 2002.
very pleased/proud

examples.en: Now he’s passed his driving test, he’s as pleased as Punch.

senses.definition: to make somebody suffer because they have broken the law or done something wrong

examples.en: Those responsible for this crime will be severely punished.
My parents used to punish me by not letting me watch TV.
to punish a criminal/an offender/a perpetrator
She will be punished for her crimes.
He was punished for refusing to answer their questions.
Damages are not designed to punish, but to compensate for the loss sustained.

senses.definition: to set the punishment for a particular crime

examples.en: In those days murder was always punished with the death penalty.

senses.definition: to blame yourself for something that has happened
an act or a way of punishing somebody

examples.en: to inflict/impose/mete out punishment
to deserve/face/escape punishment
What is the punishment for murder?
I felt sure that it was a punishment for my sin.
Punishments for killing the king's deer were severe.
There is little evidence that harsher punishments deter any better than more lenient ones.
The punishment should fit the crime.
He was sent to his room as a punishment.
She had to tidy the classroom as punishment for being late.
new approaches to the punishment of offenders

senses.definition: rough treatment

examples.en: The carpet by the door takes the most punishment.

senses.definition: a category of very severe punishment that is banned under US law

examples.en: This important case confronts the issue of what constitutes cruel and unusual punishment.
Detainees are subjected to malnutrition, forced labor, and to other cruel and unusual punishments.

senses.definition: a type of loud and aggressive rock music popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s

examples.en: a punk band

senses.definition: a person who likes punk music and dresses like a punk musician, for example by wearing metal chains, leather clothes and having brightly coloured hair

examples.en: a punk haircut

senses.definition: a young man or boy who behaves in a rude or violent way
a person who is being taught, especially a child in a school

examples.en: school pupils
a former/past pupil
How many pupils does the school have?
She now teaches only private pupils.
Spending per pupil will rise.

senses.definition: a person who is taught artistic, musical, etc. skills by an expert

examples.en: Charpentier took pupils and taught them composition and accompanying.
The painting is by a pupil of Rembrandt.

senses.definition: the small round black area at the centre of the eye

examples.en: Her pupils were dilated.

senses.definition: to buy something

examples.en: Please ensure that you purchase your ticket in advance.
to purchase an item/a product
to purchase a property/home
We recently purchased a home just outside Las Vegas.
The equipment can be purchased from your local supplier.
The tickets can only be purchased in advance from our website.
They purchased the land for $1 million.
Victory was purchased (= achieved) at too great a price.

senses.definition: the act or process of buying something

examples.en: to make a purchase (= buy something)
Keep your receipt as proof of purchase.
The company would not reveal the original purchase price of the stores.
Many developers were delaying the purchase of land until later in the year.
The company has just announced its £27 million purchase of Park Hotel.
An illustrated catalogue is available for purchase.
Our intention is to increase purchases from local suppliers.
Such massive purchases by single investors were extremely rare.

senses.definition: something that you have bought

examples.en: major purchases, such as a new car
Figures suggest that consumers return one in five online purchases.
If you are not satisfied with your purchase we will give you a full refund.

senses.definition: a strong hold on something with the hands or feet, for example when you are climbing

examples.en: She tried to get a purchase on the slippery rock.

senses.definition: not mixed with anything else; with nothing added

examples.en: pure gold
ties made of pure silk
These shirts are 100% pure cotton.
The patient was given pure oxygen to breathe.
Classical dance in its purest form requires symmetry and balance.
One movie is classified as pure art, the other as entertainment.
The metal needs to be very pure.

senses.definition: clean and not containing any harmful substances

examples.en: a bottle of pure water
The air was sweet and pure.
Much of the population still does not have access to pure drinking water.

senses.definition: complete and total

examples.en: They met by pure chance.
She laughed with pure joy.
That woman is pure evil.
These reports are pure speculation (= there is no evidence that they are true).
It was a pure accident. I'm not blaming anybody.
It was pure coincidence that all the absences occurred at the same time.

senses.definition: very clear; perfect

examples.en: beaches of pure white sand
a pure voice

senses.definition: without evil thoughts or actions, especially sexual ones; morally good

examples.en: to lead a pure life
His motives were pure.
to be pure in body and mind

senses.definition: about increasing knowledge of the subject rather than using knowledge in practical ways

examples.en: pure mathematics
technology as opposed to pure science subjects

senses.definition: not mixed with any other type of animal or plant

examples.en: These cattle are one of the purest breeds in Britain.

senses.definition: used after the noun that it refers to in order to emphasize that there is nothing but the thing you have just mentioned involved in something

examples.en: It's laziness, pure and simple.
The man wants revenge, pure and simple.

senses.definition: only; completely

examples.en: I saw the letter purely by chance.
The charity is run on a purely voluntary basis.
She took the job purely and simply for the money.
The fireplace in the bedroom is purely decorative.

senses.definition: having the colour of blue and red mixed together

examples.en: a purple flower/dress
His face was purple with rage.
The effort was making her face turn purple.
It produces lovely dark purple berries around this time of year.

senses.definition: writing or a piece of writing that is too grand in style
the colour of blue and red mixed together

examples.en: His hair was dyed a bright shade of purple.
She was dressed in purple.
His eyes were a deep purple.
She wore purple and black.
the startling pinks and purples of the dresses

senses.definition: the intention, aim or function of something; the thing that something is supposed to achieve

examples.en: Our campaign's main purpose is to raise money.
The plan achieved its primary purpose, if nothing else.
The purpose of the book is to provide a complete guide to the university.
Giving too much advance notice would defeat the purpose of the inspection.

examples.cf: for the purpose of doing something
examples.en: A meeting was called for the purpose of appointing a new treasurer.
I moved to London for the sole purpose of working with her.
I have included this data for the purpose of comparison.

examples.cf: with the purpose of doing something
examples.en: This project was launched with the purpose of increasing the number of visitors to the region.
I could find no practical purpose for this app.
The space station serves several purposes.
The experiments serve no useful purpose (= are not useful).

senses.definition: what is needed in a particular situation

examples.en: These gifts count as income for tax purposes.
The building was originally used for commercial purposes.
For the purposes of this study, the three groups have been combined.

senses.definition: meaning that is important and valuable to you

examples.en: Volunteer work gives her life a sense of purpose.
He believes he has finally found a purpose in life.

senses.definition: the ability to plan something and work successfully to achieve it

examples.en: He has enormous confidence and strength of purpose.

senses.definition: (of an institution, a system, a thing, etc.) suitable for the function or purpose that it was designed for

examples.en: The minister argued that the education system wasn’t fit for purpose.
The new executive flats are fully equipped and fit for purpose.
I returned the goods as they weren’t fit for purpose.

senses.definition: used when you are stating what the reality of a situation is

examples.en: There's still another ten minutes of the game to go, but for practical purposes it's already over.

senses.definition: not by accident; deliberately

examples.en: I did it on purpose, knowing it would annoy her.
He slammed the door on purpose.

variants.text: (North American English usually for all intents and purposes)
variants.html: (North American English usually for all intents and purposes)

senses.definition: in the effects that something has, if not in reality; almost completely

examples.en: By 1981 the docks had, to all intents and purposes, closed.
The two items are, for all intents and purposes, identical.

senses.definition: with little/no useful effect or result

examples.en: The government had spent a lot on education but to little or no purpose.

senses.definition: to do something or try to achieve something over a period of time

examples.en: to pursue a goal
to pursue an aim/objective
How can we most effectively pursue these aims?
We intend to pursue this policy with determination.
She wishes to pursue a medical career.
I was determined to pursue my dream of becoming an actor.
Many communities are aggressively pursuing plans to preserve open spaces.
I wasn't sure I wanted to pursue dance as a career.
He continues to pursue a soft policy on crime.

senses.definition: to continue to discuss, find out about or be involved in something

examples.en: to pursue an agenda/a strategy/a claim
to pursue legal action
The Crown Prosecution Service is unwilling to pursue the case.
We have decided not to pursue the matter.
She wanted the freedom to pursue her own interests.
He was still pursuing his studies.
Other companies are pursuing the same course.
The government has actively pursued a campaign against the militants.
‘But’, he pursued, ‘you still haven't answered the question.’

senses.definition: to follow or go after somebody/something, especially in order to catch them

examples.en: She left the theatre, hotly pursued by the press.
Police pursued the car at high speed.
Jake has been pursuing her (= trying to have a relationship with her) for months.

senses.definition: the act of looking for or trying to get something

examples.en: the pursuit of happiness/knowledge/profit
She travelled the world in pursuit of her dreams.

senses.definition: the act of following or going after somebody, especially in order to catch them

examples.en: We drove away with two police cars in pursuit (= following).
I galloped off on my horse with Rosie in hot pursuit (= following quickly behind).

senses.definition: something that you give your time and energy to, that you do as a hobby

examples.en: outdoor/leisure/artistic pursuits

senses.definition: to use your hands, arms or body in order to make somebody/something move forward or away from you; to move part of your body into a particular position

examples.en: We pushed and pushed but the piano wouldn't move.
Push hard when I tell you to.
You push and I'll pull.
She pushed at the door but it wouldn't budge.
He walked slowly up the hill pushing his bike.
Somebody pushed me and I fell over.
When you push the gate, it doesn't open.
She pushed the cup towards me.
He pushed his chair back and stood up.
I tried to hug him but he pushed me away.
She pushed her face towards him.
I pushed the door open.

senses.definition: to use force to move past somebody/something using your hands, arms, etc.

examples.en: People were pushing and shoving to get to the front.
The fans pushed against the barrier.
Try and push your way through the crowd.

senses.definition: to press a switch, button, etc., for example in order to make a machine start working

examples.en: I pushed the button for the top floor.
The operator must have accidentally pushed the switch on the joystick.
She pushed a lever and the machine responded.
Push the red button to open the doors.

senses.definition: to affect something so that it reaches a particular level or state

examples.en: This development could push the country into recession.
The rise in interest rates will push prices up.
Little pent-up demand exists to push the economy forward this year.
The surplus has helped push world prices to as little as 55 euros per tonne.
Such a huge population increase will continue to push food prices higher.
Rising inflation pushes down real interest rates.

senses.definition: to persuade or encourage somebody to do something that they may not want to do

examples.en: He made it clear that he would resist any attempt to push him into early retirement.
My teacher pushed me into entering the competition.
No one pushed you to take the job, did they?

senses.definition: to make somebody work hard

examples.en: The music teacher really pushes her pupils.
Lucy should push herself a little harder.
He keeps pushing himself to get better.

senses.definition: to put pressure on somebody and make them angry or upset

examples.en: Her parents are very tolerant, but sometimes she pushes them too far.
He felt he was being pushed to the limit of his self-control.

senses.definition: to try hard to persuade people to accept or agree with a new idea, buy a new product, etc.

examples.en: The interview gave him a chance to push his latest movie.
She didn't want to push the point any further at that moment.
He continues to push his own political agenda.
Sales promotion is designed to push certain products.
The two governments are pushing for economic reform in the region.
They're pushing hard for a ban on GM foods.

senses.definition: to sell illegal drugs
to move forward quickly through an area

examples.en: The army pushed (on) towards the capital.

senses.definition: to be nearly 40, 50, etc. years old
to be dead and buried in the ground
to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you

examples.en: The prime minister pressed the panic button yesterday as Britain’s economy plunged deeper into crisis.

variants.text: (also press all the (right) buttons especially in British English)
variants.html: (also press all the (right) buttons especially in British English)

senses.definition: to do exactly the right things to please somebody

examples.en: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

senses.definition: to spend a lot of money on enjoying yourself or celebrating something
to attempt to go beyond what is allowed or thought to be possible

examples.en: We aim to push the boundaries of what we can achieve.
She pushes her physical limits through various endurance challenges.

senses.definition: to go beyond the limits of what is allowed or thought to be possible

examples.en: He is a performer who consistently pushes the envelope of TV comedy.

senses.definition: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past

examples.en: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

senses.definition: to force somebody to lose control of their behaviour, usually after a particular event or series of events

examples.en: No one knows exactly what caused his breakdown, but losing his job may have pushed him over the edge.

senses.definition: to react in a sudden or extreme way to something unexpected that has frightened you

examples.en: The prime minister pushed the panic button yesterday as Britain's economy plunged deeper into crisis.

idioms.word: push something to the back of your mind

senses.definition: to try to forget about something unpleasant

examples.en: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

senses.definition: an act of pushing something/somebody

examples.en: She gave him a gentle push.
The car won't start. Can you give it a push?
At the push of a button (= very easily) he could get a whole list of names.

senses.definition: a large and determined military attack

examples.en: a final push against the enemy
The firm has begun a major push into the European market.

senses.definition: a determined effort to achieve something

examples.en: The push for reform started in 2007.

senses.definition: an act of encouraging somebody to do something

examples.en: He wants to open his own business, but needs a push in the right direction to get him started.

senses.definition: used to say that something is possible, but only with difficulty

examples.en: We can provide accommodation for six people at a push.

senses.definition: to dismiss somebody/to be dismissed from your job

examples.en: They gave him the push after only six weeks.

senses.definition: to end a romantic relationship with somebody; to be told that a romantic relationship with somebody is over

examples.en: He was devastated when his girlfriend gave him the push.

senses.definition: when there is no other choice; when everything else has failed
to move something into a particular place or position

examples.en: Put the cases down there, please.
Did you put sugar in my coffee?
Put your hand up if you need more paper.

senses.definition: to move something into a particular place or position using force

examples.en: He put his fist through a glass door.

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something to go to a particular place

examples.en: Her family put her into a nursing home.
It was the year the Americans put a man on the moon.

senses.definition: to attach or fix something to something else

examples.en: We had to put new locks on all the doors.

senses.definition: to write something or make a mark on something

examples.en: Put your name here.
Friday at 11? I'll put it in my diary.
I couldn't read what she had put.

senses.definition: to bring somebody/something into the state or condition mentioned

examples.en: I was put in charge of the office.
The incident put her in a bad mood.
Put yourself in my position. What would you have done?
I tried to put the matter into perspective.
Don't go putting yourself at risk.
I am determined to put things right.
It was time to put their suggestion into practice.
This new injury will put him out of action for several weeks.
He put Ray on guard with a gun.

senses.definition: to make somebody/something feel something or be affected by something

examples.en: Her new job has put a great strain on her.
They put pressure on her to resign.
It's time you put a stop to this childish behaviour.

senses.definition: to express or state something in a particular way

examples.en: She put it very tactfully.
Put simply, we accept their offer or go bankrupt.
Simply put, the film is a masterpiece.
I was, to put it mildly, annoyed (= I was extremely angry).
Putting it bluntly, the project was a disaster.
He was too trusting—or, to put it another way, he had no head for business.
The meat was—how shall I put it?—a little overdone.
As T.S. Eliot puts it…
She had never tried to put this feeling into words.
Can you help me put this letter into good English, please?
I thought you put your points very well.

senses.definition: to give or attach a particular level of importance, trust, value, etc. to something

examples.en: Our company puts the emphasis on quality.
He put a limit on the amount we could spend.

senses.definition: to consider somebody/something to belong to the class or level mentioned

examples.en: I'd put her in the top rank of modern novelists.

senses.definition: to throw the shot

idioms.word: I wouldn’t put it past somebody (to do something)

senses.definition: used to say that you think somebody is capable of doing something wrong, illegal, etc.
to have many sexual partners
to suggest something to somebody to see if they can argue against it

examples.en: I put it to you that you are the only person who had a motive for the crime.

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to believe something that is not true

examples.en: Don't try to put one over on me!

senses.definition: to force somebody to experience something difficult or unpleasant

examples.en: They really put me through it (= asked me difficult questions) at the interview.

senses.definition: used when comparing or contrasting somebody/something with a group of other people or things to mean ‘combined’ or ‘in total’

examples.en: Your department spent more last year than all the others put together.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to stop just talking about something and actually do it, show it, etc.
a game, etc. that you have to think about carefully in order to answer it or do it

examples.en: a crossword puzzle
a book of puzzles for children

senses.definition: something that is difficult to understand or explain

examples.en: The deeper meaning of the poem remains a puzzle.
The detectives were beginning to solve the murder. All the pieces of the puzzle were falling neatly into place.

variants.html: (British English jigsaw, jigsaw puzzle)

senses.definition: a picture printed on cardboard (= very thick, stiff card) or wood, that has been cut up into a lot of small pieces of different shapes that you have to fit together again
to make somebody feel confused because they do not understand something

examples.en: What puzzles me is why he left the country without telling anyone.
